Sheet1.Question: Equal volumes of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ and an unknown gas at the same temperature and pressure have masses of $5.50 \mathrm{~g}$ and $4.00 \mathrm{~g}$, respectively. Determine the molar mass of the unknown gas.
Sheet1.Answer:
Use the Avogadro's Hypothesis: Let the molar mass of the gas be $M$.
Equal volumes at the same pressure and temperature contain the same number of moles,
Moles of $\mathrm{CO}_{2} \quad=\quad 5.50 / 44.0 ;$ Moles of unknown gas $=$
$4.00 / \mathrm{M}$
Hence $\mathrm{M}=(44.0 / 5.50) * 4.00$
$=32.0$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Answer:
Total mol of gases originally present $\quad=\quad 11.0$
Since the gases do not react, pressure exerted by each mole of gas $=$
$330 / 11.0$
$=30.0 \mathrm{kPa}$
Mol of argon needed $\quad=(380-330) / 30.0 \quad=\quad 1.67 \mathrm{~mol}$

Sheet1.Question: Two sparingly soluble metal hydroxides $\mathrm{MOH}$ and $\mathrm{Q}(\mathrm{OH})_{2}$, have solubility products of $9.00^{*} 10^{-14}$ and $1.08 * 10^{-19}$, respectively. Find the solubility of each hydroxide and indicate which is more soluble.
Sheet1.Answer:
Solubility of $\mathrm{MOH}=\sqrt{9.00 * 10^{-14}}=3.00^{*} 10^{-7} \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$.
Solubility of $\mathrm{Q}(\mathrm{OH})_{2} \quad=\quad \sqrt[3]{\frac{108}{4} * 10^{-21}} \quad=3.00^{*} 10^{-7} \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$
Hence, they are of equal solubility.

Sheet1.Question: Some radioactive nuclei decay by beta emission. What is the process equivalent to and how does it affect atomic and mass numbers?

Sheet1.Question: If it is the intention to prepare metallic sodium by electrolysis, which electrolyte is better and why: concentrated sodium chloride solution or fused sodium chloride?

Sheet1.Question: $20.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ of nitrogen gas kept at a temperature of $87.0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and a pressure of $95.0 \mathrm{kPa}$ is allowed to cool to $-3.00^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ at a pressure of $100 \mathrm{kPa}$. Calculate the new volume of the gas.
Sheet1.Answer:
Use the Ideal Gas Equation: $\mathrm{P}_{1} \mathrm{~V}_{1} / T_{1} \quad=\quad \mathrm{P}_{2} \mathrm{~V}_{2} / T_{2} ; \quad \mathrm{V}_{2}=$ $\mathrm{V}_{1}\left(\mathrm{P}_{1} / \mathrm{P}_{2}\right)\left(T_{2} / T_{1}\right)$
$$
\mathrm{P}_{1}=95.0 \mathrm{kPa} ; \quad \mathrm{V}_{1}=20.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3} ; \quad \mathrm{T}_{1}=360 \mathrm{~K} ; \mathrm{P}_{2}=100 \mathrm{kPa} ; \quad \mathrm{T}_{2}=
$$
$270 ; \quad V_{2}=?$
$$
\mathrm{V}_{2}=(20.0 * 95.0 * 270) /(360 * 100)=14.25=14.3 \mathrm{dm}^{3}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: An element $X$ exists as tetra-atomic molecules $X_{4}$. If $X$ has two natural isotopes, how many peaks will be observed in its Mass Spectrum? The spectrum is recorded such that there is no fragmentation.
Sheet1.Answer:
5 peaks.
Assume isotopes $\mathrm{X}_{1}, \mathrm{X}_{2}$
Molecules that are possible are:
$$
\mathrm{X}_{1}-\mathrm{X}_{1}-\mathrm{X}_{1}-\mathrm{X}_{1} ; \quad \mathrm{X}_{1}-\mathrm{X}_{1}-\mathrm{X}_{1}-\mathrm{X}_{2} ; \quad \mathrm{X}_{1}-\mathrm{X}_{1}-\mathrm{X}_{2}-\mathrm{X}_{2} ; \quad \mathrm{X}_{1}-\mathrm{X}_{2}-\mathrm{X}_{2}-\mathrm{X}_{2} ; \quad \mathrm{X}_{2}-\mathrm{X}_{2}-\mathrm{X}_{2}-\mathrm{X}_{2}
$$

Sheet1.Question: A $2.00 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ flask is filled with argon gas at $27.0{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ until the pressure is $70.0 \mathrm{kPa}$. Calculate the total pressure when $6.40 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ gas at $27.0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is added to the flask. Ideal Gas constant $\mathrm{R}$ is $8.31 \mathrm{JK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. $\mathrm{O} \quad=\quad 16.0$
Sheet1.Answer:
Moles of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ in $6.40 \mathrm{~g} \quad=\quad 6.40 / 32.0=0.200$
Pressure of $0.200 \mathrm{~mol}$ of $\mathrm{O}_{2} ; \quad \mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{O} 2} \quad=\quad(\mathrm{nRT}) / \mathrm{V}$
$\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{O} 2}=(0.200 * 8.31 * 300) / 2.0=8.31 * 30.0 \quad=\quad 249.3 \mathrm{kPa}$
Total pressure $=(70.0+249.3) \mathrm{kPa} \quad=\quad 319 \mathrm{kPa}$

Calcium ethanedioate has a solubility product of $4.00 * 10^{-10}$ at about $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
Calculate the solubility of this salt in water and in $0.100 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3} \mathrm{Ca}^{2+}$ solution.
Account for the difference if any.

In water Ksp of $\mathrm{CaC}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}=4.00^{*} 10^{-10} ; \quad \quad \quad$ Solubility $=\sqrt{ }\left(4.00^{*} 10^{-}\right.$
$\left.{ }^{10}\right)$
Hence $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right]$ or $\left[\mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}{ }^{2-}\right]=2.00 * 10^{-5} \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$
In 0.100 moldm $^{-3} \mathrm{Ca}^{2+}$ :
$\mathrm{Ksp}=[0.100]\left[\mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}{ }^{2-}\right]=4.00 * 10^{-10}$
$\left[\mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}^{2-}\right]=4.00 * 10^{-9} \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$

Sheet1.Answer:
mmoles of $\mathrm{Ag}+$ present $=150 * 0.250=37.5$
mmoles of $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$present $=2 * 100 * 0.185=37.0$
$\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$is the limiting amount.
Therefore, mmoles of $\mathrm{AgCl}$ to be precipitated $\quad=\quad$ 37.0.

Sheet1.Question: State Charles' Law.
Sheet1.Answer: The volume of a given quantity of gas is directly proportional to its temperature at constant pressure. (Accept $\mathrm{P} \propto \mathrm{V}$ at constant $\mathrm{n}$ and $\mathrm{T}$ )
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: The hybridization of the bonding orbitals of carbon in methane and oxygen in water are the same but bond angles are different. Why?
Sheet1.Answer: The orbitals of carbon in the methane molecule and of oxygen in the water molecule both undergo $\mathrm{sp}^{3}$ hybridisation. In the case of oxygen two of the hybrid orbitals contain pairs of nonbonding electrons. There is therefore repulsion between these two non-bonding orbitals which in turn compress the bonding orbitals thus reducing the $\mathrm{H}-\mathrm{O}-\mathrm{H}$ bond angle to less than $109.5^{\circ}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: When meat is salted, bacteria cannot grow on it. Suggest a reason for this
Sheet1.Answer: The salt lowers the meat's osmotic potential so that water is withdrawn, by osmosis from bacterial cytoplasm and so kills the bacteria.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Why are seeds such a significant evolutionary development?
Sheet1.Answer: The evolution of seeds allowed plants to decrease their dependency upon water for reproduction. Seeds contain an embryo that can remain dormant until conditions are favorable when it grows into a diploid sporophyte. Seeds are transported by the wind, water, or by animals to encourage reproduction and reduce competition with the parent plant.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: How do white blood cells differ from red blood cells with respect to their function?
Sheet1.Answer: White cells ingest bacteria or make antibodies. Red cells carry oxygen.

Sheet1.Question: A metal alloy made from aluminium (Al), magnesium $(\mathrm{Mg})$, copper $(\mathrm{Cu})$ and steel has the composition: Al $18.0 \% ; \quad \mathrm{Mg} \quad 12.0 \% ; \quad \mathrm{Cu} \quad 25.0 \%$. The rest is steel, which is $98.5 \%$ iron and $1.50 \%$ carbon. Calculate the mass in gram of carbon in a $2.00 \mathrm{~kg}$ alloy.
Sheet1.Answer:
\% steel $\quad=100-(18.0+12.0+25.0)=45.0$
Therefore, in $2.00 \mathrm{~kg}$ alloy, mass of steel $=450 * 2=900 \mathrm{~g}$
Mass of carbon $=(1.5 / 100){* 900}=13.5 \mathrm{~g}$

Whereas the water molecules in the salt $\mathrm{ZnSO}_{4} \cdot 7 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ are not taken into consideration when determining the oxidation number of zinc, the water molecules in the complex ion $\left[\mathrm{V}\left(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\right)_{6}\right]^{3+}$ have to be considered when determining the oxidation state of vanadium.

Sheet1.Question: How are photosynthesis and respiration related to each other?
Sheet1.Answer: The end product of Photosynthesis is glucose that is used in cellular respiration to make ATP. The glucose is then turned back into carbon dioxide, which is used in photosynthesis. While water is broken down to form oxygen during photosynthesis, in cellular respiration oxygen is combined with hydrogen to form water.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: The concentration of the tissue fluid, which bathes all cells in the body, is kept more or less constant. Why is this important?
Sheet1.Answer: If the tissue fluid became more dilute, the cells would absorb water by osmosis and swell up. If the tissue fluid became more concentrated, the cells would lose water by osmosis, shrink and become dehydrated, possibly to a point where metabolism was no longer possible.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What is the principle underlying the use of cyanobacteria in agricultural fields for crop improvement?
Sheet1.Answer: Many species of cyanobacteria can carry out nitrogen fixation in soil. Hence, they are used in agricultural fields for crop improvement.

Sheet1.Question: State the converse of the statement 'a regular polygon is equilateral' and determine if the converse is true or not.
Sheet1.Answer: 'An equilateral polygon is regular'. Converse is false.

Sheet1.Question:
A chemical reaction produces 4.00 moles of oxygen gas. What volume will the oxygen gas occupy at a room temperature of $27.0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ if the pressure is maintained at $100 \mathrm{kPa}$ throughout the experiment? Molar volume of a gas at STP $=22.4 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$;
Gas constant $\quad=8.31 \mathrm{JK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$
Sheet1.Answer:
Use Charles' law: $\mathrm{V} \quad \alpha \mathrm{T} \quad$ at constant pressure and number of moles.
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{V}_{1}=4.00 * 22.4 ; \mathrm{T}_{1}=273 ; \mathrm{V}_{2}=? ; \\
& \mathrm{T}_{2}=300 \\
& \mathrm{~V}_{2}=\left(\mathrm{T}_{2} / \mathrm{T}_{1}\right) * \mathrm{~V}_{1}=(300 / 273) * 4.00 * 22.4=\mathbf{9 8 . 5 \mathbf { d m } ^ { 3 }}
\end{aligned}
$$
OR Use the Ideal Gas Equation; $\quad \mathrm{V}=(\mathrm{n} * \mathrm{R} * \mathrm{~T}) / \mathrm{P}$
$\mathrm{V}=(4.00 * 8.31 * 300) / 100=99.7 \mathbf{d m}^{3}$
(Accept either of the two answers)
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: How many pi bonds are present in the $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$ molecule?
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Explain why even though both phenol and ethanol contain the $\mathrm{OH}$ group, phenol is an acidic, but ethanol is not.
Sheet1.Answer: Phenol is an acid because when it loses a proton the conjugate base, the phenoxide ion, is stabilised by resonance whereas the conjugate base of ethanol, the ethoxide ion, is not stabilised by resonance.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Find the stationary point of $y=(2 x+1) /(x-2)$
Sheet1.Answer:
NO STATIONARY POINT
$\left[d y / d x=(2(x-2)-1(2 x+1)) /(x-2)^{2}=-5 /(x-2)^{2} \neq 0\right.$, no stationary point $]$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Two angles of a cyclic quadrilateral measure $53^{\circ}$ and $115^{\circ}$ respectively. Find the measures of the 2 remaining angles.
Sheet1.Answer:
$127^{\circ}, 65^{\circ}$
[supplement of $53^{\circ}$ is $127^{\circ}$, supplement of $115^{\circ}$ is $65^{\circ}$, hence $127^{\circ}, 65^{\circ}$ ]
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: The common name of okro is simpler than its scientific name Abelmoschus esculentus. Why then is the simpler common name not used instead of the complex scientific name in biology?
Sheet1.Answer: The common name 'okro' is an English word and this can have different names in different languages. Hence, instead of using simple common names; It is preferred to use scientific names that may appear complicated but universally accepted.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: How does a gap junction facilitate intercellular communication?
Sheet1.Answer: Gap junctions allow small signaling molecules to pass from one cell to another and thus they facilitate intercellular communication

Sheet1.Question: Two half - cells, $\mathrm{M}^{+} / \mathrm{M}$ and $\mathrm{Q}^{+} / \mathrm{Q}$ where $\mathrm{M}$ and $\mathrm{Q}$ are metals, have the electrode potentials 1.20 and $\quad-0.850$ volts, respectively. Which of the two metals can react with dilute mineral acid to release hydrogen gas? Give your reason.
Sheet1.Answer: Q. The potential for the reaction $\mathrm{Q} \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{Q}^{+}+\mathrm{e}$ is positive whereas the potential for the similar reaction of $M$ is negative. The one with the positive oxidation potential can oxidise $\mathrm{H}^{+}$to $\mathrm{H}_{2}$.

Sheet1.Question: Give the main difference in the definitions of an acid according to the Arrhenius Theory and according to the Bronsted-Lowry Theory.
Sheet1.Answer: The Arrhenius concept of acid is limited to a substance that increases $\mathrm{H}^{+}$ concentration in water but Bronsted-Lowry concept makes any proton donor an acid irrespective of the medium.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Butane isomerises to 2-methylpropane or isobutane in an equilibrium process. If a $1.00 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ flask is charged with 2.00 mole of butane at $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and the gas allowed to come to equilibrium, calculate the equilibrium concentration of butane and isobutane at $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ given that the equilibrium constant, $\mathrm{K}_{c}$ is 2.50 .
Sheet1.Answer:
$\quad$ Butane $\quad \rightleftharpoons \quad$ isobutane $\quad \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{c}}=2.50$
Initial: $\quad 2.00$ moldm $^{-3}$
$0.00 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$
At eq.: $\quad 2.00-x$ moldm $^{-3} \quad x$ moldm $^{-3}$
$\mathrm{K}_{c}=\mathrm{x} /(2.00-\mathrm{x})=2.50 ; \quad \mathrm{x}=5.00-2.50 \mathrm{x}$
$$
\begin{array}{lll}
3.50 x=5.00 ; & x & =1.43 . \\
\text { Hence concentration of butane, } 2.00-\mathrm{x} & =0.570 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3} \text {; } \\
\text { Concentration of isobutane, } \mathrm{x} & =1.43 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3} .
\end{array}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Why is it that jams and dried meats often do not require refrigeration to prevent spoilage?
Sheet1.Answer: Enzymes and microorganisms that cause spoilage work best in wet conditions. Dried food is thus better preserved. / The sugar in jam reduces hydration by thickening. The thicker the jam, the longer it takes to spoil, the juicier the jam, the sooner it will spoil. / low water activity
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Population growth is always finite or determinate. Under what circumstances is population growth maximal?
Sheet1.Answer: Population growth could be infinite when there are unlimited resources, such as space food and shelter, and where there are no deaths due to natural disasters.

Sheet1.Question: Why is it important for the mammalian lung never to become completely empty?
Sheet1.Answer: If this residual volume did not exist and the lungs emptied completely, the lung tissues would stick together and the energy necessary to re-inflate the lung could be too great to overcome. Therefore, there is always some air remaining in the lungs.

Sheet1.Question: A flask contains $0.200 \mathrm{~mol}$ of nitrogen gas, $0.100 \mathrm{~mol}$ of oxygen gas and $0.300 \mathrm{~mol}$ of argon gas at a total pressure of $240 \mathrm{kPa}$. How many moles of oxygen gas must be added to the flask to raise the total pressure to $300 \mathrm{kPa}$ ?
Sheet1.Answer:
Since the gases do not react the Dalton's Law of Partial Pressures apply.
Moles of gas giving the pressure of $240 \mathrm{kPa}=0.600 ; \quad$ Additional kPa needed $=60$
Moles of oxygen required to add $60.0 \mathrm{kPa}=(60.0 / 240) * 0.600$
$$
=0.150 \mathrm{~mol} \text {. }
$$

Sheet1.Question: A body moves from a point $5 \mathrm{~m}$ due east to a point $3 \mathrm{~m}$ due west in $40 \mathrm{~s}$. Find the average velocity of the body.
Sheet1.Answer:
$0.2 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$ due west
$$
v_{\text {avg }}=\Delta r / \Delta t=(-3 \mathrm{~m} \hat{\imath}-5 \mathrm{~m} \hat{\imath}) \div 40 \mathrm{~s}=-0.2 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1} \hat{\imath}=0.2 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1} \text { due west }
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: A metal cation forms a precipitate when $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}$ is bubbled through its solution. If it takes a fairly long time for the precipitate to form, which alternative reagent will you use to get rapid results?
Sheet1.Answer:
A solution of sodium or potassium sulphide.
Reason : For a solution of $\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{~S}$ or $\mathrm{K}_{2} \mathrm{~S}$, the salt is fully ionised and $\mathrm{S}^{2-}$ concentration is high. $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}$ is a weak acid and it does not provide high enough concentration of sulphide ions.

Sheet1.Question: If it takes helium 20 seconds to diffuse from point $A$ to point $B$ in a tube in the laboratory, how long in seconds will it take a gas of molar mass 64 to diffuse over the same distance, assuming temperature is constant? $\quad \mathrm{He}=4$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\quad$ Rate $=$ distance $/$ time $\left(\mathrm{d} / \mathrm{t}_{1}\right)$
For equal distance; $\quad$ Rate $_{1} /$ Rate $_{2}=\quad \mathrm{t}_{2} / \mathrm{t}_{1}=\quad \sqrt{ }\left(\mathrm{M}_{2} / \mathrm{M}_{1}\right)$
$\mathrm{t}_{2}=\mathrm{t}_{1} * \sqrt{ }\left(\mathrm{M}_{2} / \mathrm{M}_{1}\right)=20 * \sqrt{ }(64 / 4)=80 \mathrm{~s}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: If it takes helium 20 seconds to diffuse from point $A$ to point $B$ in a tube in the laboratory, how long in seconds will it take a gas of molar mass 64 to diffuse over the same distance, assuming temperature is constant? $\quad \mathrm{He}=4$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\quad$ Rate $=$ distance $/$ time $\left(\mathrm{d} / \mathrm{t}_{1}\right)$
For equal distance; $\quad$ Rate $_{1} /$ Rate $_{2}=\quad \mathrm{t}_{2} / \mathrm{t}_{1}=\quad \sqrt{ }\left(\mathrm{M}_{2} / \mathrm{M}_{1}\right)$
$\mathrm{t}_{2}=\mathrm{t}_{1} * \sqrt{ }\left(\mathrm{M}_{2} / \mathrm{M}_{1}\right)=20 * \sqrt{ }(64 / 4)=80 \mathrm{~s}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: A projectile is launched at an angle above the horizontal from the top of a tower of height $h$. What must be the launch angel above the horizontal so that the projectile falls farthest from the top of the tower for a given launch speed?
Sheet1.Answer:
$45^{\circ}$
This is just the well-known result. The optimal launch angle for maximum range from the foot of the tower is $\sqrt{\left(2 g h+u^{2}\right) /\left(2 g h+2 u^{2}\right)}$ and tends to zero as tower height is increased at fixed launch $\operatorname{speed}^{u}$

Sheet1.Question: The concentration of the tissue fluid, which bathes all cells in the body, is kept more or less constant. Why is this important?
Sheet1.Answer: If the tissue fluid became more dilute, the cells would absorb water by osmosis and swell up. If the tissue fluid became more concentrated, the cells would lose water by osmosis, shrink and become dehydrated, possibly to a point where metabolism is no longer possible.

Sheet1.Question: When meat is salted, bacteria cannot grow on it. Suggest a reason for this.
Sheet1.Answer: The salt lowers the meat's osmotic potential so that water is withdrawn, by osmosis, from bacterial cytoplasm and so kills the bacteria.

Sheet1.Question: In a colony of honey bees the queen is the only fertile female. If the queen loses its egg-laying capacity, how does the colony get a new queen?

Sheet1.Question: What is the weight of a floating object which displaces $0.5 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$ of water?
Sheet1.Answer:
$5000 \mathrm{~N}$
$$
W=\text { weight of water displaced }=\rho V g=1000 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3} \times 0.5 \mathrm{~m}^{3} \times 10 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}=5000 N
$$

Sheet1.Question: Give one property shared by chloroplasts and mitochondria.
Sheet1.Answer:
- Both of them are bounded by two selectively permeable membranes composed of lipoprotein sub-units.
- They contain ribosomes and DNA attached to their inner membrane.
- Both of them are cellular organelles that grow and reproduce within the cell.

Sheet1.Question: A parallel plate capacitor has capacitance $20 \mathrm{pF}$. Find the change in capacitance when the distance between the plates is decreased by $1 \%$
Sheet1.Answer:
$0.2 \mathrm{pF}$
$$
\delta C=\frac{\partial\left(\epsilon_{0} A / d\right)}{\partial d} \delta d=-C \delta d / d=20 \mathrm{pF} \times 0.01=0.2 \mathrm{pF}
$$

Sheet1.Question: A particle initially at the point $r_{0}=3 \hat{j} m$ moves in such a manner that its velocity is given by $v(t)=a t^{4} \hat{i}+b t^{2} \hat{j}$ where $a=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-5}$ and $b=6 \mathrm{~ms}^{-3}$. Find the position of the particle at $t=1 \mathrm{~s}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$(2 \hat{i}+5 \hat{j}) m$
$$
r=r_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} v(t) d t=3 \hat{j} m+\left(\frac{1}{5} a t^{5} \hat{i}+\frac{1}{3} b t^{3} \hat{j}\right) \vee \dot{i}_{0}^{1 s}=(2 \hat{i}+5 \hat{j}) m i
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question:
Consider the following electrodes and their respective potentials: $\mathrm{Zn}^{2+} / \mathrm{Zn},-0.760 \mathrm{~V}$ and $\mathrm{Cr}^{3+} / \mathrm{Cr}_{\text {, }}$ -
$0.740 \mathrm{~V}$. Of the four species, $\mathrm{Zn}^{2+}, \mathrm{Cr}^{3+}, \mathrm{Zn}$ and $\mathrm{Cr}$, name the strongest reducing agent.
Sheet1.Answer:
Zn. [It has to be an electron donor. The cations cannot donate electrons]
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\mathrm{Zn}-2 \mathrm{e} \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{Zn}^{2+},+0.760 \mathrm{~V}\right. \\
& \left.\mathrm{Cr} \quad-\quad 3 \mathrm{e} \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{Cr}^{3+} \quad+0.740 \mathrm{~V}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: State Le Chatelier's Principles.
Sheet1.Answer:
The Principle states that a change in one of the variables that describes a system in equilibrium produces a change in the position of the equilibrium that counteracts the effect of this change. OR
If a condition is changed in a system in equilibrium, the position of the equilibrium will change in such a way as to restore the original condition.

Birds - Butterfly larvae - ants - grass seeds
Sheet1.Answer: Grass seeds $\rightarrow$ ants $\rightarrow$ butterfly larvae $\rightarrow$ birds

Sheet1.Question: The terminal voltage of a battery is $16 V$ when a $250 \Omega$ resistor is connected across its terminals and $15 \mathrm{~V}$ when a $150 \Omega$ resistor is connected across its terminals. Find the internal resistance of the battery.
Sheet1.Answer:
$28 \Omega$
$$
r=\frac{\left(V_{2}-V_{1}\right) R_{1} R_{2}}{R_{1} V_{2}-R_{2} V_{1}}=\frac{(16 V-15 V) \times 150 \Omega \times 250 \Omega}{250 \Omega \times 15 V-150 \Omega \times 16 V}=28 \Omega
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The refractive index of a type of glass is 1.74 at $515 \mathrm{~nm}$. Find the speed of $515 \mathrm{~nm}$ light waves in the glass.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Two very long parallel wires separated by $0.40 \mathrm{~m}$ each carries a current of $5.0 \mathrm{~A}$. Find the magnitude of the force exerted on a $2.0 \mathrm{~m}$ segment of one of the wires by the other.
Sheet1.Answer:
$2.5 \times 10^{-5} N$
$$
F=\mu_{0} I_{1} I_{2} l / 2 \pi r=4 \pi \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{Hm}^{-1} \times 5.0 \mathrm{~A} \times 5.0 \mathrm{~A} \times 2.0 \mathrm{~m} /(2 \pi \times 0.40 \mathrm{~m})=2.5 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~N}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: State Hund's Rule.

$$

$$

Sheet1.Answer:

$$

$$

Sheet1.Question: Explain why the salt $\mathrm{Nal}$ is less ionic than $\mathrm{NaCl}$.
Sheet1.Answer: The $\mathrm{I}^{-}$ion is a much bigger ion than the $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$ion. The polarizability of the $\mathrm{I}^{-}$ion is therefore greater than that of $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$ion. The $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$ion is able to distort/pull the negative charge on the $\mathrm{I}^{-}$better than that on the $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$ion. [Note: The difference cannot be attributed to the difference in electronegativities: $\mathrm{Cl} \quad 2.87 ; \quad \mathrm{I}$ 2.36]

Sheet1.Question: A $+5 n C$ charge is located at the origin and a $-5 n C$ charge is located on the $y$-axis at $y=2 m$. Find the electric field on the $y$-axis at $y=1 \mathrm{~m}$.
Sheet1.Answer: $90 \mathrm{Vm}^{-1} \hat{j}$ or $90 \mathrm{Vm}^{-1}$ in the positive $y$ direction $E=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}}\left[\frac{q_{1}\left(r-r_{1}\right)}{\left|r-r_{1}\right|^{3}}+\frac{q_{2}\left(r-r_{2}\right)}{\left|r-r_{2}\right|^{3}}\right]=\left(9.0 \times 10^{9} m F^{-1}\right) \times 5 \times 10^{-9} C \times\left[\frac{\hat{j}}{|1 m \hat{j}-0|^{2}}+\frac{\hat{j}}{|1 m \hat{j}-2 m \hat{j}|^{2}}\right]=90 \mathrm{Vm}^{-1} \hat{j}$

Sheet1.Question: Define chemical equilibrium.

1

$30 n N \hat{k}$
$$
F=q v \times B=-5 n C \times\left(3 \hat{j} m^{-1}\right) \wedge(2 \hat{i} T)=(30 n N) \hat{k}
$$
Or $30 \mathrm{nN}$ in the positive $\mathrm{z}$ direction.

u_{m}=B^{2} / 2 \mu_{0}=\left(\frac{\mu_{0} I R^{2}}{2\left(x^{2}+R^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}\right)^{2} \vee \dot{i}_{x=0}\left(2 \mu_{0}\right)^{-1}=\mu_{0} I^{2} / 8 R^{2} \dot{c}
$$

Sheet1.Question: Alumina is electrolyzed in its molten form as a solution in molten cryolite, $\mathrm{Na}_{3} \mathrm{AlF}_{6}$. What is the purpose of having cryolite in the molten alumina?
Sheet1.Answer: The cryolite (serves as an impurity) and lowers the melting point of alumina. Less energy is therefore required to keep the alumina in the molten form.

Sheet1.Question: Why does the rate of photosynthesis decrease at higher temperatures?
Sheet1.Answer: Photosynthesis is an enzyme-controlled reaction. The rate of photosynthesis decreases at higher temperatures because at high temperatures the enzymes become denatured (destroy).

Sheet1.Question: Why is insulin not given orally but is injected into the body?
Sheet1.Answer: Insulin is a protein by composition so if it is given orally it will get digested in the stomach and will not be able to perform its function.

Sheet1.Question: Why is sexual reproduction so common among organisms?
Sheet1.Answer: The variation that sexual reproduction creates among offspring is very important to the survival and reproduction of those offspring.

Sheet1.Question: Most plants close their stomata to conserve water on a hot, dry day. What impact will this have on photosynthesis?
Sheet1.Answer: The level of carbon dioxide (a reactant) will fall, and the level of oxygen (a product) will rise. As a result, the rate of photosynthesis will slow down.

Sheet1.Question: Which postulate or postulates of the Kinetic Molecular Theory explain Charles' Law that states that at a constant pressure, the volume of a given mass of a gas is proportional to the absolute temperature? State the postulate(s)
Sheet1.Answer:
(i) The average kinetic energy of a gas particle depends on the absolute temperature of the gas and nothing else.
(ii) Collisions between gas particles or collisions with the walls of the containers are perfectly elastic.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Answer:
$x=\pi / 2$
$[2 \sin x \cos x-2 \cos x=2 \cos x(\sin x-1)=0, \cos x=0$, then $x=\pi / 2, \sin x=1$ then $x=$ $\pi / 2]$

Sheet1.Question: What is the basis for designating $\mathrm{C}_{3}$ and $\mathrm{C}_{4}$ pathways of photosynthesis?
Sheet1.Answer: The number of carbon atoms in first stable product of carbon dioxide fixation is the basis for designating $C_{3}$ and $C_{4}$ pathways of photosynthesis.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Humans inhale oxygen when they breathe and exhale carbon dioxide. What is the role of oxygen?
Sheet1.Answer: The oxygen inhaled is the final electron acceptor in the electron transport chain and allows aerobic respiration to proceed, (which is the most efficient pathway for harvesting energy in the form of ATP from food molecules).
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Mycorrhiza is a mutualistic association between two organisms. How do the organisms gain from the association?
Sheet1.Answer: The plant obtains phosphate and other minerals, such as zinc and copper, from the association while fungus obtains nutrients, such as sugars, from the plant root.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: A stationary hydrogen atom makes a transition from the first excited state to the ground state and emits a photon. What is the recoil kinetic energy of the atom? The mass of a hydrogen atom is $1.0078 u$ and $1 u=931.49 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$
Sheet1.Answer:
$5.5 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{eV}$
$K_{\text {recoil }}=\left(E_{f}-E_{i}\right)^{2} / 2 m c^{2}=\left[13.6 e V \times\left(1^{-2}-2^{-2}\right)\right]^{2} /\left(2 \times 1.0078 \times 931.49 \times 10^{6} e V\right)=5.5 \times 10^{-8} e V=8.9 \times 10^{-27}J$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics, Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Why does one feel blinded for a short while on coming out of a dark room?
Sheet1.Answer: It is due to the constriction of the pupil to prevent the entry of light into the eye, and also the pigment rhodopsin is bleached to reduce the sensitivity of the $\operatorname{rods}$

Sheet1.Question: What resistance value must be used with a moving coil ammeter with full-scale deflection at $0.20 \mathrm{~A}$ and internal resistance of $100 \Omega$ to read currents up to $10 A$ and how must it be connected?
Sheet1.Answer:
$2.0 \Omega$ in parallel
$$
R_{\text {shunt }}=R_{i} I_{d} l\left(I_{\max }-I_{d}\right)=100 \Omega \times 200 \mathrm{~mA} /(10 \mathrm{~A}-200 \mathrm{~mA})=2.0 \Omega
$$
Or "a $2.0 \Omega$ shunt."

Sheet1.Question: Xerophytes have their leaves modified into spines or reduced in size. How does this help the plants?
Sheet1.Answer: Xerophytes grow in areas where water is scarce. Their leaves are modified into spines or reduced in size in order to decrease the rate of transpiration

Sheet1.Question: Explain why the sclera of the human eye is distinctly visible but not visible in other mammals.
Sheet1.Answer: In humans the colour of the sclera contrasts with the smaller size and dark colour of the iris which makes it distinctly visible, but in other mammals the sclera gets camouflaged with the colour and larger size of the iris and is therefore not visible.

Sheet1.Question: A magnetic dipole of dipole moment $5 \hat{j} A m^{2}$ is located in a magnetic field of flux density $8 \hat{k} T$. Find the torque and the energy of the dipole.
Sheet1.Answer:
Torque equals $40 \hat{i} \mathrm{~N}$; energy equals zero
$N=m B=\left(5 \hat{j} A m^{2}\right)(8 \hat{k} T)=40 \hat{i} N m ; U=-m \cdot B=0$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Find the tension in the string of an Atwood machine with a pulley of negligible friction and rotational inertia which is operated with a $3 \mathrm{~kg}$ mass and a $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ counter mass.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The mass $m$ of a droplet moving through a static cloud changes by accretion with time $t$ at the rate $\frac{d m}{d t}=5 \mu \mathrm{gs}^{-1}+0.1 t \mu g \mathrm{~s}^{-2}$. What is the mass of the droplet at $t=10 \mathrm{~s}$ if its initial mass is $5 \mu g$ ?
Sheet1.Answer:
$60 \mu g$
$$
m=m_{0}+\int_{0}^{10 s} d m / d t d t=5 \mu g+\left(5 t \mu g s^{-1}+0.05 t^{2} \mu g s^{-2}\right) i_{0}{t=10 s}=5 \mu g+5 \times 10 \mu g+0.05 \times 100 \mu g=60 \mu g i
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Why is vivipary an undesirable character for annual crop plants?
Sheet1.Answer: The seeds cannot be stored under normal conditions for the next crop season
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Chlorophyll a is the primary pigment for light reaction. What is the role of accessory pigments in photosynthesis?
Sheet1.Answer:
They absorb wavelength of light not absorbed by chlorophyll a and transfer the energy to chlorophyll.
They also protect chlorophyll a from photo-oxidation.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Birds find shelter and build nests on trees without harming the trees. What is the term for the symbiotic relationship between the birds and the trees?
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Name the last element in Group (VI) or 16 of the Periodic Table.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Which group of organic compounds are likely to be found in meats grilled on charcoal and what are the longterm effects of these on humans?
Sheet1.Answer: Compounds: Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons. $\quad$ Long term effects: Cancer
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Aqua Regia is a solution known to dissolve gold. What is its composition.
Sheet1.Answer: It is a 1: 3 mixture of concentrated $\mathrm{HNO}_{3}$ and concentrated $\mathrm{HCl}$ by volume.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Find the value of $x$ if the matrix $A=\left(\begin{array}{cc}x+2 & -4 \\ -2 & x-2\end{array}\right)$ has no inverse.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question:
A binary operation $*$ is defined on the set $\mathrm{R}$ of real numbers by
$a * b=a+b-a b$ (Assume $a, b \neq 1$ ). Find the identity e.
Sheet1.Answer: e $=0 \quad[e * a=e+a-e a=a, e(1-a)=0, e=0$, since $a \neq 1]$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Find the coordinates of the vertex as well as the equation of the axis of symmetry of the quadratic curve $y=3 x^{2}-12 x+10$
Sheet1.Answer: $(2,-2)$ and $x=2 \quad\left[3\left(x^{2}-4 x\right)+10=3\left(x^{2}-4 x+4\right)+10-12=\right.$ $3(x-2)^{2}-2$, hence vertex is $(2,-2)$ and axis of symmetry is $x=2$ ]
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: What is the length of a simple pendulum whose period is $2.00 \mathrm{~s}$ at a location where local gravity is $9.811 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2} ?$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Find the change in entropy when $2.0 \mathrm{~kg}$ of steam at $100{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ condenses quasi-statically to water at $100{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The specific latent heat of vaporization of water is $2265 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The aerodynamic drag force on a spherical object moving through a gaseous atmosphere depends jointly only on the radius $r$ of the object, its speed $v$, and the density $\rho$ of the atmosphere. Give the power of $r$, of $v$ and of $\rho$ in the aerodynamic drag force expression.
Sheet1.Answer:
Power of $r$ is 2 , power of $v$ is 2 , and power of $\rho$ is 1
$F_{D} \propto r^{a} \rho^{b} v^{c} \Rightarrow M L T^{-2}=L^{a-3 b+c} M^{b} T^{-c}$ so $c=2, b=1, a=1+3 b-c=2$.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The cells at the root tip of a certain plant was found to contain 24 chromosomes. What will be the number of chromosomes in the aleurone cells of the plant?
Sheet1.Answer: 36 (Thirty six). The outermost layer of the endosperm (3n) of a seed is called the aleurone layer. Since the aleurone layer is triploid the number of chromosome will be 36 , as root tip cells are diploid (2n) 24 ells.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: A large proportion of oxygen remains unused in the human blood even after oxygen uptake by the body tissues. What happens to the remaining oxygen?
Sheet1.Answer: This remaining oxygen acts as a reserve during muscular exercise.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: People normally look for lawn mowers to mow their lawns so as to prevent the overgrowth of their lawn grass. Name the tissue which is responsible for this overgrowth.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Explain why one cannot write down the Rate Law of a reaction merely from the balanced equation.
Sheet1.Answer: The reaction may involve several steps and it is the slowest step that determines the rate law.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Why does the extraction of gold start with the concentration of the metal?
Sheet1.Answer: The metal exists in its uncombined state in the ore.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What is the hybridization of the bonding orbitals of fluorine in hydrogen fluoride?
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Find the zeros of the function $f(x)=x^{3}-4 x$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Express as a single logarithm $\log \left(x^{3}+27\right)-\log \left(x^{2}-3 x+9\right)$ and simplify.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Find the period $T$ of the trigonometric function $y=\tan (2 x-\pi)$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: A Veronica bucket is in the shape of a truncated right circular cone with an inside bottom radius of $0.20 \mathrm{~m}$, an inside top radius of $0.30 \mathrm{~m}$ and an inside full vertical depth of $0.60 \mathrm{~m}$. Estimate the weight of the bucket when it is full of water. The mass of the empty bucket is $1.5 \mathrm{~kg}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: What is the wavelength of each of the photons produced when an electron at rest and a positron at rest undergo annihilation?
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: A uniform solid cylindrical rod of mass $M$ and length $L$ at rest on a smooth horizontal table is kicked at one end by an impulse I perpendicular to the rod axis. What is the initial speed of the kicked end?
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Why is RuBisCo enzyme the most abundant enzyme in the world?
Sheet1.Answer: Because this enzyme is responsible for photosynthesis and is present in all green parts of plants.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: A mature mammalian erythrocyte lacks nucleus. What functional advantage does that provide?
Sheet1.Answer: The presence of nucleus would occupy space and reduce the oxygen carrying capacity. (The nucleus is also not required as a mature $R B C$ does not divide).
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Why do plants have more dead tissues compared to animals?
Sheet1.Answer: Plants don't have skeletons, and each cell must support itself or receive direct support from tissues around it, in order for the plant to remain upright. Hence plants need the hard, dead cells to remain upright.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question:
Consider the following reaction:
$4 \mathrm{NH}_{3(\mathrm{~g})}+5 \mathrm{O}_{2(\mathrm{~g})} \rightarrow 4 \mathrm{NO}_{(\mathrm{g})}+6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{(\mathrm{g})}$
$\mathrm{NH}_{3(\mathrm{~g})}$ -46.1; $\mathrm{NO}_{(\mathrm{g})}$ (g) 90.3; $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{(\mathrm{g})}$ -242
Use the following standard enthalpies of formation all in $\mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$ to calculate the enthalpy of reaction.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What is the meaning of the term EFFLORESCENCE?
Sheet1.Answer: The loss of water from a hydrate (or water of crystallisation) when the substance is exposed to air at normal/room temperatures.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What is FRASCH PROCESS?
Sheet1.Answer: It is a method or process for extracting elemental sulphur from underground deposits. (Sulphur is melted with superheated water and the molten sulphur is forced upward using air under pressure).
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Solve the trigonometric equation $2 \sin x-1=0$ for $0<x<2 \pi$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: If $x^{2}+2 x y-y^{2}=10$, find $d y / d x$
Sheet1.Answer:
$d y / d x=(x+y) /(y-x) \quad[2 x+2(y+x d y / d x)-2 y d y / d x=0$,
$2(x+y)=2(d y / d x)(y-x), d y / d x=(x+y) /(y-x)]$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Given the functions $f(x)=\sqrt{ }(x-1)$ and $g(x)=x^{2}$, find the domain of $f(g(x))$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: An atom in a stationary symmetric diatomic molecule with a bond length $L$ and atoms each of mass $m$ is kicked by an impulsive force $F$ perpendicular to the molecular axis in a collision that lasts $\delta t$. What is the initial speed of the kicked atom assuming the bond is rigid?
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The current in a series $L-R$ circuit with $R=15 \Omega$ is $25 A 1.2 \mathrm{~s}$ after a $50 \mathrm{~V}$ voltage step is applied to the circuit. Find $L$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$26 H$
$$
L=-R t / \ln (1-I R / V)=-15 \Omega \times 1.2 \mathrm{~s} / \ln [1-25 \mathrm{~A} /(50 \mathrm{~V})]=26 H
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: What is the de Broglie wavelength of an electron of kinetic energy $1.0 \mathrm{MeV}$ ?
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Explain why it would not be possible to date the fossil of an organism that existed 100 million years ago using the decay of carbon-14.
Sheet1.Answer: A fossil that is 100 million years old has almost no carbon-14 left in it, the amount will be too small to be detected. Therefore carbon-14 dating would not give a reliable date or age.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What does biochemical oxygen demand measure?
Sheet1.Answer: It measures the amount of dissolved oxygen required by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material in a water sample (at certain temperature over a specific time period.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Why is it important to cut a plant stem at an angle under water during an experiment to determine the effect of environmental conditions on transpiration rate using a simple photometer?
Sheet1.Answer: The reason why the stem is cut it under water is to prevent air bubbles entering the xylem vessel and block movement of water. It is cut at an angle in order to increase surface area for water uptake by the xylem.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question:
Calculate the percentage carbon in the $\propto$-amino acid, 2 -amino propanoic acid.
$\mathrm{O}=16.0 ; \mathrm{N}=14.0 ; \mathrm{C}=12.0 ; \mathrm{H}=1.00$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Amino acids exist especially in the solid state as dipolar salts. Why?
Sheet1.Answer: There is internal proton transfer from the acid functional group to the amino functional group so that within the molecule there are $\mathrm{COO}^{-}$and $\mathrm{NH}_{3}^{+}$groups.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: State any two types of industrial application of electrolysis, giving an example each to illustrate your answer.
Sheet1.Answer:
Any two of
(1) Extraction of metals
Example: Group 1 and 2 metals from molten salts. $\mathrm{Na}$ from $\mathrm{NaCl}$ etc.
(2) Electrolysis to purify metals
Example: Copper, gold, silver aluminium.
(3) Electroplating
Example: Plating of steel with chromium, $\quad$ plating of copper with gold.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Given that $\sin A=12 / 13$ and $A$ is obtuse, find $\cos A$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Find the measure of the angle between the vectors $\mathbf{a}=5 \mathbf{i}+3 \mathbf{j}$ and $\mathbf{b}=3 \mathbf{i}-5 \mathbf{j}$
Sheet1.Answer:
$90^{\circ}$
[a.b $=15-15=0$, the vectors $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ are perpendicular, hence angle is $90^{\circ}$ ]

Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: What evidence do scientists use to show that dinosaurs once existed on Earth?
Sheet1.Answer: Fossils that were formed when the dinosaurs died / animals like sharks, birds and crocodiles that show certain related characteristics to dinosaurs. (any one of them)
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Why should the turgor pressure of the guard cells affect the opening and closing of the stomatal pore?
Sheet1.Answer: When the guard cells are turgid, they swell and bend outward. As a result, the stomatal aperture opens. When they are flaccid, the tension from the wall is released and the stomatal aperture closes.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: A mature mammalian erythrocyte lacks mitochondria. What advantage does that provide?
Sheet1.Answer: Mitochondria is absent so that oxygen is not utilized by the $R B C$ and all the oxygen is transported to target areas. / Lack of mitochondria helps in the way that $R B C$ would not consume any oxygen that it is transporting.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: If it takes 52.0 seconds for a gas of molar mass 64.0 to effuse from a vessel through a pinhole, how long will it take methane gas to effuse from the same vessel at the same pressure and temperature? $\quad \mathrm{C}=12.0 ; \quad \mathrm{H}=1.00$
Sheet1.Answer:
From Grahams Law of Effusion
Rate of effuse $\propto \vee \frac{1}{M}$
But Rate $\propto \frac{1}{t} ; \quad$ Therefore, time of effusion, $\mathrm{t} \propto \sqrt{M}$
$$
\frac{52.0}{2}=26.0 \mathrm{~s}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Explain why metals can be beaten into flat sheets.
Sheet1.Answer: Metals are malleable because in the metal lattice, ions are surrounded by mobile electrons arranged in layers. When a force is applied longitudinally, the layers slip over one another in the longitudinal direction. When the force is applied laterally, layers slip laterally.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Give the expression for the half-life of a radioisotope.
Sheet1.Answer: $\quad t_{\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{0.693}{k}$; where $\mathrm{k}$ is the decay constant.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text: $200 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of 0.100 moldm ${ }^{-3}$ lead(II) trioxonitrate(V) are added to $300 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $0.150 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$ of potassium chloride.
Sheet1.Question: Calculate the concentration of the trioxonitrate $(\mathrm{V})$ ions in moldm ${ }^{-3}$ in the mixed solution.
Sheet1.Answer:
Concentration of the $\mathrm{NO}_{3}^{-}$ions before the two solutions were mixed $=0.200 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$
Dilution of $\mathrm{NO}_{3}^{-}$is from $200 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ to $500 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$. Dilution factor $\quad=\quad 2$ in 5
Concentration of the $\mathrm{NO}_{3}{ }^{-}$ions in the mixture $=\frac{2}{5} * 0.200=0.0800$ moldm $^{-3}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text: $200 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of 0.100 moldm ${ }^{-3}$ lead(II) trioxonitrate(V) are added to $300 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $0.150 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$ of potassium chloride.
Sheet1.Question: Calculate the concentration of $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$ions in the mixed solution.
Sheet1.Answer:
For the $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$ions, dilution is from $300 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ to $500 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$. Dilution factor $\quad$ in 5
Concentration of the $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$ions $=\quad \frac{3}{5} * 0.150=0.0900 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What are microsomes?
Sheet1.Answer: Microsomes are small vesicles formed by the breakdown of ER membrane into fragments

Sheet1.Question: In which compartment of plant cells do the light-independent reactions of photosynthesis take place?
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

a) Cytoplasm
b) Ribosomes
c) ER compartments
d) Golgi apparatus

Sheet1.Question: The position vector of a particle is given in terms of time $t$ by $r(t)=a \hat{i}+b t \hat{j}+(c t-\delta) \hat{k}$ where $a, b, c$ and $\delta$ are constants. Find $t$ such that the velocity and position of the particle are orthogonal.

Sheet1.Question: Is the sun a blackbody? Why or why not?
Sheet1.Answer: It is not; it is not in thermal equilibrium
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Why is it essential that blood pressure in the capillary vessels be much lower than that in the artery?
Sheet1.Answer: Low blood pressure in the capillaries slows blood down the flow of blood, so it gives enough time for diffusion of substances between the blood and cells. The walls of capillaries are also much thinner than those of arteries (squamous epithelium only), so they could rupture / break if the blood pressure is too high in them.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Why should a person who is feeling dizzy be fed with glucose or a fruit juice instead of a bread and margarine that might give more energy?
Sheet1.Answer: Glucose gives instant energy as it is absorbed and reaches the blood. Bread and margarine, however, requires time to digest and be absorbed. As sick people need immediate energy supply, they are fed with glucose or given fruit juice.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Why should mowing lawn grass facilitate better maintenance?
Sheet1.Answer: Apical dominance of terminal bud is due to the secretion of auxin (IA.A) by apical bud. Hence the removal of apical bud causes sprouting of lateral buds with stimulation of intercalary meristem thereby facilitating better maintenance of grass.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Calculate the mass of aluminium that can be obtained from electrolysis of molten aluminium oxide after passing a charge of 82.0 Faraday. $\mathrm{Al}=27.0$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}+6$ Faraday $\rightarrow 2 \mathrm{Al}+\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}$
Mass of $\mathrm{Al}$ produced by $6.00 \mathrm{~F}=54.0 \mathrm{~g}$ Mass of Al to be produced by $82.0 \mathrm{~F}=\frac{82.0}{6} * 54.0=738 \mathrm{~g}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What is the catalyst used in the Haber Process?
Sheet1.Answer:
A mixture of metallic iron and aluminium oxide.
(Accept a mixture of metallic iron and various oxides)

Sheet1.Question: Find the equation for the function $\mathrm{g}(\mathrm{x})$ which is obtained after the graph of the function $\mathrm{y}=2 \mathrm{x}$ is reflected in the line $\mathrm{y}=\mathrm{x}$ and translated 2 units to the right.
Sheet1.Answer:
$g(x)=1 / 2(x-2)$ or $g(x)=1 / 2 x-1$
[reflect in $\mathrm{y}=\mathrm{x}$ gives $\mathrm{x}=2 \mathrm{y}$ or $\mathrm{y}=(1 / 2) \mathrm{x}, 2$ units right gives $\mathrm{y}=(1 / 2)(\mathrm{x}-2)$ ]
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Find the equilibrium temperature attained when $0.20 \mathrm{~kg}$ of water at $60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is added to $0.40 \mathrm{~kg}$ of methanol at $10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ without heat exchange with the surroundings. The specific heat capacity of water is $4200 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$ and that of methanol is $2500 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$33^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
$T_{f}=\left(m_{1} c_{1} T_{1}+m_{2} c_{2} T_{2}\right) /\left(m_{1} c_{1}+m_{2} c_{2}\right)=\left(0.20 \mathrm{~kg} \times 4200 \mathrm{Jkg}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \times 60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}+0.40 \mathrm{~kg} \times 2500 \mathrm{Jkg}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \times 10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right.$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The gravitational potential on the surface of a spherical object of radius $600 \mathrm{~km}$ is $-560 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1}$. Find the gravitational potential $100 \mathrm{~km}$ above the surface of the object.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: A three-input logic gate has inputs $A, B$, and $C: A$ and $B$ are the inputs of a NAND gate whose output is connected to the input of a NOR gate; $C$ is the other input of the NOR gate. Give the output sequence when $A=110, B=101$, and $C=001$.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question:
Rockets are missiles propelled by the ejection of gases from an orifice.
Hydrogen gas and kerosene are substances that have been used as rocket fuels. The $\Delta \mathrm{H}$ of combustion per mole of hydrogen is $-242 \mathrm{~kJ}$. Kerosene is approximately $\mathrm{C}_{12} \mathrm{H}_{26}$ and the $\Delta \mathrm{H}$ of combustion is $-7520 \mathrm{~kJ}$. Which of the two fuels is more efficient and why? Your reasoning must be quantitative. $C=$
$12.0 ; \mathrm{H}=1.00$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\Delta \mathrm{H}$ perg of $\mathrm{H}_{2} \quad=\frac{-242}{2}=-121 \mathrm{~kJ}$
Molar mass of Kerosene $\quad=\quad 144+26.0=170 \mathrm{~g}$
$\Delta \mathrm{H}$ per $\mathrm{g}$ of kerosene $=\frac{-7520}{170}=\quad-44.2 \mathrm{~kJ}$
Since $\Delta \mathrm{H}$ per $\mathrm{g}$ of $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ is $-121 \mathrm{~kJ}$ and that of kerosene is $-44.2, \mathrm{H}_{2}$ is more efficient.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
The largest single use of trioxonitrate $(V)$ acid is the production of ammonium trioxonitrate $(V)$.
What is this substance used for?

Sheet1.Question: Why is the symbol for the metallic element lead, $\mathrm{Pb}$ ?
Sheet1.Answer: It is derived from its Latin name Plumbium. .
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: State what will be observed when a few drops of trichloromethane are added to sodium bromide solution followed by addition of chlorine water and the mixture shaken vigorously. Also explain the chemistry of any changes.
Sheet1.Answer:
The trichloromethane layer will turn orange or red.
Reason: Chlorine will oxidise the bromide ion to bromine which then imparts the orange/red/bromine colour to the $\mathrm{CHCl}_{3}$ layer
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What is the name of the study of chemistry of living organisms?
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Find the area of the finite region bounded by the curves $f(x)=2 x$ and $g(x)=x^{2}$

Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Which of Mendel's laws is also known as the law of purity of gametes.
Sheet1.Answer: Law of segregation (gametes are always remained pure by separating the genes or factors at the time of gamete formation
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Name the term which defines the study of the characteristics and parameters of the population.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question:
Which of the following is not the function of the Golgi apparatus?
a) Processing and shorting of glycoprotein
b) Lipid metabolism
c) Carbohydrate metabolism
d) Amino acid metabolism

Sheet1.Question: A $2.0 \mathrm{~kg}$ sphere and a $3.0 \mathrm{~kg}$ sphere of the same radius are in contact on a smooth horizontal surface. A 4.5 $N$ horizontal force pushes the $2.0 \mathrm{~kg}$ sphere along the line of centers which in turn pushes the other sphere. Find the magnitude of the normal force on the $3.0 \mathrm{~kg}$ sphere.

Sheet1.Question:
Which of the following contains the smallest number of carbon atoms?
a) 0.052 mole of glucose
b) 0.110 mole of propane
c) 0.320 mole of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$
Sheet1.Answer: $\quad 0.052$ mole of glucose $\left(\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{12} \mathrm{O}_{6}\right)$ contains 0.312 mole of $\mathrm{C}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: The polarity of a molecule or a bond is measured or described in terms of Dipole Moment. What is Dipole Moment?
Sheet1.Answer: It is the product of the charge on the dipole multiplied by the distance between them.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Chemically what is the difference between baking soda and baking powder?
Sheet1.Answer:
Baking soda $\quad=\quad$ sodium hydrogentrioxocarbonate(IV) $\quad\left[\mathrm{NaHCO}_{3}\right]$
Baking powder $\quad=\quad \mathrm{NaHCO}_{3}+\quad$ citric acid or tartaric acid
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Solve the equation $1 / f=1 / u+1 / v$ for $v$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Simplify $3 \sqrt{8}-\sqrt{ } 32+3 \sqrt{ } 72+\sqrt{ } 75$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Find the domain of the function $f(x)=\sqrt[3]{(x-2)}$
Sheet1.Answer: $\{x: x$ is a real number $\}$ or $\{$ real numbers $\}$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: What is the function of a nonsense codon?
Sheet1.Answer: The function of nonsense codons is to terminate the message of a gene controlled protein synthesis.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Casparian strip is present in which part of the root of plants?
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question:
Which of the following is not one of the functions of the mammalian kidney?
a) Regulates blood volume and composition
b) Synthesizes glucose
c) Regulates blood pressure
d) Defends the body against disease
Sheet1.Answer: d) Defends the body against disease
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: The coefficient of static friction between a $2.0 \mathrm{~kg}$ object and a plane inclined at $30^{\circ}$ to the horizontal is 0.30. Find the magnitude of the force applied to the object in a direction perpendicular to the plane that is needed to just prevent sliding of the object.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Determine the wavelength diffracted at $60^{\circ}$ in first order by a diffraction grating ruled with 1000 lines per mm when it is illuminated with white light at normal incidence.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Find the rms speed for ideal gas molecules of molar mass $70 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at a temperature of $560 \mathrm{~K}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Chemically how would you classify stainless steel?
Sheet1.Answer: It is an alloy of steel (not iron) chromium and nickel
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What physical process aids dogs to sniff and finally locate the bodies of missing people?
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Explain why gases dissolve more in cold water than in warm better.
Sheet1.Answer: In hot water, the heat of the water molecules warm up the gas molecules, which results in higher kinetic energy for the gas molecules. These molecules are therefore more able to escape from the attractive forces of the hot water molecules.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Differentiate the function $y=(2 x-2) / v x$. Simplify your answer.
Sheet1.Answer:
$d y / d x=v x / x+v x / x^{2}$
$\left[y=2 v x-2 / v x, d y / d x=1 / v x+1 / x v x=v x / x+v x / x^{2}\right]$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Find an equation for the function $g(x)$ which has the graph of $f(x)=x^{2}$, but moved 3 units to the right and 4 units vertically up.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Rationalize the denominator $(3 \sqrt{ } 5-5 \sqrt{3}) /(3\sqrt{5} + 5\sqrt{3})$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Which carbohydrate molecule is a principal component of the cell wall of angiosperms?
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What is meant by power of accommodation of the eye?
Sheet1.Answer: It refers to the ability of an eye to change the focal length of the eye lens
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question:
Which of the following is the first step in urine production?
a) Tubular secretion
b) Glomerular reabsorption
c) Tubular reabsorption
d) Glomerular filtration
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Determine the power developed when the point of application of the force given by $F=(5 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}) N$ moves with velocity $v=(4 \hat{i}-6 \hat{j}) \mathrm{ms}^{-1}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$2 W$
$$
P=F \cdot v=(5 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}) N \cdot(4 \hat{i}-6 \hat{j}) m s^{-1}=2 W
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: What is the moment of inertia of a solid sphere of radius $0.100 \mathrm{~m}$ and mass $32.0 \mathrm{~kg}$ about an axis passing through the center of the sphere?
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Two strings, $A$ and $B$, each of which is fixed at one end suspend a stationary $32.0 \mathrm{~kg}$ object so that each string makes an angle of $30.0^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Find the tension in $A$ assuming standard gravity is $9.81 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Exactly $250 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of 0.100 moldm $^{-3}$ dilute ammonia are mixed with $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $0.125 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$ of the dilute $\mathrm{HCl}$.
Sheet1.Question: Give the composition in mmoles of the mixed solution.
Sheet1.Answer:
mmole of $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ provided $=25.0$
mmole of $\mathrm{HCl}$ provided $=12.5$
Hence the mixture contains 12.5 mmol of $NH_{3}$ and 12.5 mmol of $NH_{4}^{+}$ and 12.5mmol Cl
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Exactly $250 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of 0.100 moldm $^{-3}$ dilute ammonia are mixed with $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $0.125 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$ of the dilute $\mathrm{HCl}$.
Sheet1.Question: State the type of solution that has been prepared.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Exactly $250 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of 0.100 moldm $^{-3}$ dilute ammonia are mixed with $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $0.125 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$ of the dilute $\mathrm{HCl}$.
Sheet1.Question: If the $\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{b}}$ of ammonia is 4.76 , calculate the $\mathrm{pH}$ of the solution.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Name the muscles of the eye responsible for accommodation of the eye Ciliary muscles
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Name the cross by which the law of independent assortment inferred.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question:
Which of the following is NOT an endocrine gland?
a) Hypothalamus
b) Pituitary
c) Parathyroid
d) Pancreas
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Simplify $\left(x^{2}-x-6\right) /\left(x^{2}-2 x-8\right)$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Find the area of the finite region bounded by the curves $y=9-x^{2}$ and $y=9-3 x \quad$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Identify the polygon whose exterior angle in its regular form is $\pi / 5$ radians
Sheet1.Answer:
DECAGON
$[2 \pi / n=\pi / 5, n=2(5)=10$, hence a decagon]
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Why is a small amount of fluoride added to toothpaste?
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Biology

Sheet1.Question: What role do chlorofluoromethanes play in the decomposition of ozone in the stratosphere?
Sheet1.Answer:
chlorofluoromethanes decompose to give chlorine free radical $(\mathrm{Cl})$, which catalyses the decomposition of ozone to oxygen.
$\mathrm{O}+\mathrm{O}_{3} \stackrel{\mathrm{Cl}}{\longrightarrow} 2 \mathrm{O}_{2}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What happens when a coil of wire is moved through a magnetic field at constant velocity?
Sheet1.Answer: An e.m.f will be induced across the ends.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: A sealed glass jar contains an ideal gas. Describe what happens to the molecules when the temperature of the gas is increased
Sheet1.Answer: The kinetic energy (or the velocity) of the molecules will increase.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Which part of the eye is specialized for the perception of colour and how is it specialized for such a function?
Sheet1.Answer: The fovea of the retina is specialized for colour vision. This is because most of the cones which are responsible for colour vision are concentrated here
Sheet1.Subject: Biology, Physics

Sheet1.Question: Mammalian red blood cells have a biconcave shape and flexible cell membrane, what are the benefits of this structure?
Sheet1.Answer: The biconcave shape gives it a large surface area for the exchange of gases while the flexible cell membrane enables it to squeeze through the capillaries without ruptures.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Find the equation of the straight line through the point $(2,1)$ and perpendicular to the line through the points $\mathrm{A}(1,2)$ and $\mathrm{B}(3,-2)$
Sheet1.Answer:
$Y=\underline{1 / 2} \mathrm{x}$, or $2 \mathrm{y}=\mathrm{x}$
Slope of line through $\mathrm{A}(1,2)$ and $\mathrm{B}(3,-2) /(3-1)$ is $(-2-2) /(3-1)=-2$ Slope of line perpendicular to this line is $1 / 2$
Equation of the perpendicular line through $(2,1)$ is $y-1=1 / 2(x-2)$, or $y=1 / 2 x$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Find the equation of a line through the point $\mathrm{A}(3,-3)$ and parallel to the line with equation $2 \mathrm{x}+\mathrm{y}=4$
Sheet1.Answer:
$Y=-2 x+3$, or $2 x+y=3$
Slope of the given line is -2
Equation of line through $\mathrm{A}(3,-3)$ with slope -2 is given
by $y+3=-2(x-3)$ or $Y=-2 x+3$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: What accounts for the hardness of diamond?
Sheet1.Answer: The 3-dimensional network of very strong carbon - carbon covalent bonds.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Why is graphite, another allotrope of carbon soft?
Sheet1.Answer: Graphite consists of hexagonal rings of carbon, which slide over one another on application of force.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What is the thermometric property used in a pyrometer? Explain your Answer.
Sheet1.Answer: Colour: The pyrometer measures the temperature of an object by relating the wavelength (or colour) of the light emitted by a hot object to the temperature of the object (according to Wein's displacement law).
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: What is the thermometric property used in a constant-volume gas thermometer? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: Pressure. When the temperature of a gas in a rigid, sealed container changes the pressure exerted by the gas will also change (according to the gas laws).
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: If a seed imbibes water, its weight increases. Would you regard this as growth? Explain.
Sheet1.Answer: No, this is not growth. This is because growth is an incresase in the DRY weight of an organism through cell division and cell enlargement.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Is Guttation likely to occur in forest trees or savanna trees? Explain your answer
Sheet1.Answer: It is likely to occur in forest trees. Guttation is the exudation from plants of water in the liquid form. It is therefore likely to occur in warm HUMID areas where forest trees are found. The savanna areas are dry and gultation is not likely to occur here.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Under a translation vector $\underline{\mathrm{U}}$, the point $\mathrm{A}(2,-4)$ is mapped onto the point $B(-3,-7)$. Find the translation vector $\underline{U}$. Give your answer in unit vector notation.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Under the translation vector, $\mathrm{u}=2 \mathrm{i}-5 \mathrm{j}$, the point $\mathrm{A}$ is mapped onto the point $\mathrm{B}(-3,3)$. Find the coordinates of the point
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Which ion in solution would give red-brown precipitate with aqueos ammonia or sodium hydroxide.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Which ion in solution would give dark blue precipitate with potassium hexacyanoferrate II solution
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: The stem, leaves and rhizoids of a moss plant constitute the gametophyte generation. Why is the moss plant referred to as the gametophyte?
Sheet1.Answer: This is because the moss plant produces cells that have the haploid number of chromosomes and thus capable of functioning as gametes. The gametophyte generation is that stage of the life cycle of the plant that bears the sex organs and thus gametes.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What evidence is there to show that mosses have aquatic ancestors?
Sheet1.Answer: Mosses require water for fertilization. Their antherozoids (male gametes or sperms) can only reach the archegonium (egg) by swimming in the film of water that covers the surface of the plant. Mosses can therefore grow only in moist places.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: The average speed of a tractor is $18 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}$. Find the time in seconds taken to travel a distance of 300 metres.
Sheet1.Answer:
60 seconds
$18 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}=(18,000 / 3600) \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$
300 metres is covered in $300 / 5=60$ seconds
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: A car is traveling at a uniform speed of $72 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}$. Find the distance (in metres) travel in 10 seconds.
Sheet1.Answer:
200 metres
$72 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}=(72,000 / 3600) \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$
In 10 seconds, travel in a distance of $20 \times 10=200 \mathrm{~m}$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: There are no spark plugs in a diesel engine. Explain how the fuel is ignited within the cylinders of the engine?
Sheet1.Answer: The fuel is ignited by compression, i.e., during the compression stroke, the pressure on the fuel-air mixture is increased and the temperature is increased enough to ignite the fuel and generate combustion.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: A heat pump is a device that extracts heat energy from a low temperature reservoir and exhausts heat energy to a high temperature reservoir during one thermal cycle. (This requires that an external agent does work, of course). An example of a heat pump is a refrigerator. Explain how a heat pump can be used to warm a room in a cold climate.
Sheet1.Answer: By arranging so that the cold reservoir is the "outside" and the warm reservoir is the inside of the room. When the heat engine is running, it will extract energy from the outside and dump heat energy inside the room, thereby keeping the room warm .
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Which vitamin may be obtained from carrots?
Sheet1.Subject: Biology, Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Vitamin A is the same as retinol. What functional group(s) is/are present in retinol.
Sheet1.Answer:
Akanol / alcohol
Alkene / carbon - carbon double bonds
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Biology

Sheet1.Question: There is a large group of anaerobic bacteria whose major end product of fermentation is lactic acid. Of what economic importance are these lactic acid producing bacteria?
Sheet1.Answer: They are used in the food industry for making dairy products like cheese, butter and yoghurt from milk.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What is major importance of fungi in the pharmaceutical industry?
Sheet1.Answer: They are used for the production of antibiotics.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Two events $A$ and $B$ are independent. If $P(A)=3 / 4$, and $P(A \cap B)=1 / 2$, find $P(B)$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$\quad 2 / 3$ or 0.67
$\quad$ Since $\mathrm{A}$ and $\mathrm{B}$ are independent, $\mathrm{P}\left(A\cap \mathrm{B}\right)=\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{A}) \mathrm{P}(\mathrm{B})$
$$
\text { Hence } \mathrm{P}(\mathrm{B})=\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{A} \cap \mathrm{B}) / \mathrm{P}(\mathrm{A})=1 / 2 \times 4 / 3=2 / 3
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Two events $A$ and $B$ are mutually exclusive. If $P(A)=1 / 2$ and $P(B)=1 / 4$, find $\quad P(A \cup B)$.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: A small opaque object is placed in front of a large white screen in a dark room. A beam of green light is shone on the object. What will be the colour of the shadow formed? What will be the colour of the rest of the screen? Explain your answers.
Sheet1.Answer:
The shadow formed will be black, since the opaque object will prevent light from reaching the screen.
The rest of the screen will appear green. Since it is in fact a white screen, it will reflect all light that is incident on it. Thus, it will reflect the green light and therefore appear green.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: A camera is equipped with a shutter that opens and closes in order to capture an image. Suppose that you wanted to take a photograph of a stationary object in poor lighting conditions. Would it be more advantageous to increase or to decrease the length of time that the shutter stays open? Explain your answers.
Sheet1.Answer: It will be more advantageous to decrease the shutter speed. Keeping the shutter open for longer will admit more photons into the camera.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Under what condition is the centre of gravity of an object equal to the center of mass?
Sheet1.Answer: The centre of gravity is equal to the centre of mass when the gravitational field is uniform and the acceleration due to gravity is the same for all parts of the object.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The star, Alpha Centauri is 4.4 light years, $4.4 \times 10^{13}$ kilometers from the earth. Is there any gravitational attraction between the planet earth and this galaxy? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: Yes. From Newton's theory of gravity, any object with mass will experience a Force due to the mass of all other objects. Even though the distance is so large, The force of gravity will still act though the force between the earth and Alpha Centauri will be very small on account of the great distance.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Mr. Mensah sold an article to Madam Araba at a gain of $25 \%$, and since she in turn sold it to Mrs. Tetteh at a loss of $10 \%$. If Mrs. Tetteh paid GHS18 for it, how much did Mr. Mensah pay for the article?
Sheet1.Answer:
GHS 16
Let original cost be $\mathrm{GH} \phi \mathrm{y}$
$$
\frac{125}{100} y \frac{90}{100} \frac{125}{100} y \frac{90}{100}=18 \text { hence } y=\frac{100}{125} x \frac{100}{90} x 18=16
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: A trader bought an article for GHS 100 and sold it to woman at profit of $20 \%$. The woman also sold the article to another man at a loss of $20 \%$. What did the last man pay for the article?
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: People who live at very high altitudes have a higher red blood cell number than those who live at low altitudes. What accounts for this increase in red blood cell number?
Sheet1.Answer: At high altitudes, the oxygen content of the air is low and the body responds to this by increasing red blood cell production.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics, Biology

Sheet1.Question: In a network of blood capillaries, fluid tends to leak out at the arterial end while at the venous end fluid tends to enter the capillaries why do you think this is so?
Sheet1.Answer: The arterial end of capillaries is under high pressure from the pumping action of the heart and this causes fluid to leak out . At the venous end, blood pressure is low and the presence of plasma proteins tends to draw water into the capillaries by osmosis.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Name one cation whose sulphide is white.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Name one cation whose hydroxide is white but the sulphide black.
Sheet1.Answer: $\mathrm{Pb}^{2+}$ (Though $\mathrm{Cu}^{2+}$ and $\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}$ have black sulphide, their hydroxides are also coloured).
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Apart from the fact that we are required to maintain silence in library, explain why well-stocked libraries are usually quiet.
Sheet1.Answer: This is because the books absorb sound waves quite well, preventing reflection and travel over long distances.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: An electric bell is placed in a glass jar which is connected to a vacuum pump. Air is pumped out of the jar while the bell is ringing. Describe what happens to the sound of the ringing bell.
Sheet1.Answer: The sound will diminish as the air is pumped out of the jar. This is because sound waves require a medium in order to propagate. When the air is removed from the jar a vacuum is left and this will prevent the sound from reaching the walls of the jar.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: At a cinema theatre, an adult ticket costs GHS 5, and a child's ticket costs GHS 3. If 200 tickets are sold and the gross receipt is GHS 760, find how many of each type of ticket are sold?
Sheet1.Answer:
Adult ticket: 80 , child ticket: 120
Let $\mathrm{x}$ be number of adult tickets, and $\mathrm{y}$ the number of child's ticket
$$
\begin{aligned}
& x+y=200,5 x+3 y=760, y=200-x \\
& 5 x+3(200-x)=760,2 x+600=760,2 x=160, \text { hence } x=80, y=120
\end{aligned}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: At a football match, tickets for the popular stand cost $\mathrm{GHS}  5$ and tickets for VIP stand cost GHS 10 each respectively. Altogether 1000 tickets are sold at a total cost of GHS 6,500. Find the number of each type of ticket sold.
Sheet1.Answer:
Popular stand: 700,VIP stand: 300
Let $x$ be number of VIP tickets sold and $y$ the number of popular stand tickets sold.
$X+y=1,000,10 x+5 y=6,500, y=1,000-x$
$10 x+5(1000-x)=6,500,5 x+5000=6500$
$5 x=6500-5000=1500$, hence $x=300$ and $y=700$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: One of the vaccines given to babies is DPT. Why is the vaccine called DPT?
Sheet1.Answer: The initials DPT stands for the three diseases that the vaccine protects babies against. These are Diphtheria, Pertussis (whooping cough) and Tetanus.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: One important vaccine given to children is BCG. What do the initials BCG stand for and what disease does it protect children against.
Sheet1.Answer: The initials BCG stand for Bacillus (Bacille) Calmette-Guerin (after the names of the two French scientists who first prepared the vaccine). It protects children against Tuberculosis.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Name one non-metallic solid.
Sheet1.Answer: Boron (B) or Phosphorus (P) or Sulphur (S) or Iodine (I)
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Camphor balls are placed in drawers to keep pests away. What physical processes does camphor undergo for it to perform that function?
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: When the leaves of the water lily or Nymphaea are pushed below the surface of water and released, they quickly float again and the water rolls off the surface of the leaves. What accounts for the rolling of water off the leaf surface and what is its significance?
Sheet1.Answer: Water rolls off the leaf surface because the leaf surface is covered with a waxy cuticle. This prevents water from blocking the stomata and reducing the diffusion of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ into the leaf for photosynthesis
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: One of the major problems faced by submerged aquatic plants is the low rate of diffusion of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$. Give me two features of the ceratophylum that enhance the diffusion of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
a. It has finely divided leaves and this provides a large surface area for the diffusion of gases.
b. The leaves are thin and this makes the diffusion of gases easy.
c. Since it has no roots to anchor it to the bottom, it the leaves float near the surface of water where diffusion of gases can occur at a faster rate.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Is steel a solution or a mixture? If it is a solution indicate what the solvent is and what the solute is. If it is a mixture name the components.
Sheet1.Answer: Steel is a solution, solvent $=$ iron solution $=$ carbon + small amount of $\mathrm{Cr}|\mathrm{Ni}| \mathrm{Mn}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Is the cement powder a mixture or a solution? If it is a mixture name the components. If it is a solution what is the solvent and what is the solution?
Sheet1.Answer: Powdered cement is a mixture. A mixture of; (a) Calcium trioxosilicate IV (b) Calcium dioxoaluminate and $(c)$ Calcium tetraoxpsulphate VI.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: How much water must be evaporated from 10 litres of a 3\% salt solution in order to obtain a $5 \%$ salt solution?
Sheet1.Answer:
4 Litres
Let $x$ liters of water be evaporated from the $3 \%$ salt solution
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (0.03) 10=(0.05)(10-x) \\
& 30=50-5 x \\
& 5 x=20, \text { hence } x=4
\end{aligned}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: How much pure water must be added to 10 liters of $4 \%$ salt solution in order to produce a $3 \%$ salt solution?
Sheet1.Answer:
10/3 LITRES $3.33 l, 31 / 3 l$
Let $x$ liters of water be added to the $4 \%$ salt solution?
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (0.04) 10=(x+10)(0.03) \\
& 40=(x+10) 3 \\
& 3 \mathrm{x}=10 \text {, hence } \mathrm{x}=10 / 3
\end{aligned}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: In one common type of particle accelerator, charged particles are made to move in circular paths whose radius might reach several hundred meters, or even kilometers. Why is the radius usually so large?
Sheet1.Answer: This is to minimize the loss of energy by radiation emitted as a result of the centripetal acceleration suffered by the charged particles. Since $a_{c}=v \mid r$, large $r$ means a smaller centripetal acceleration and therefore smaller amounts of energy radiated away.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: In the explosion of an atomic bomb, what are the dangers apart from the thermal destruction caused by the fireball of the explosion?
Sheet1.Answer: There is a release of large amounts of radiation and radioactive particles which can be carried by wind over large distances. These can cause damage to living resulting in illness and death.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Sulphur dioxide $\mathrm{SO}_{2}$ is a poisonous gas produced when sulphur - containing fuels are burned. Give me three harmful effects of sulpur dioxide $\left(\mathrm{SO}_{2}\right)$ pollution.
Sheet1.Answer:
a. It kills plant cells and thus reduces the rate of photosynthesis
b. It dissolves in water vapor to produce acid rain which speeds up corrosion of metals and damages walls of buildings.
c. It increases the acidity of water bodies and soils and this results in the death of organisms like fish
d. In humans, it causes lung disease e.g. bronchitis.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry
