Sheet1.Question: Lead pollution comes mainly from motor vehicle exhaust gases. Give me, three harmful effects of lead poisoning in children.
Sheet1.Answer:
a. It can cause mental radiation.
b. It can cause anaemia.
c. It can cause kidney failure.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Chemically what is the difference between soapy detergents and soapless detergents?
Sheet1.Answer: Soapy detergents (soap) are sodium or potassium salts of fatty acids or long chain alkanoic acids, whereas soap less detergents are salts of benzene/alkyl teteraoxosulphate IV $\operatorname{ROSO}_{3}-\mathrm{Na} \mid \mathrm{K}+$ or benzene /alkyl trioxosulphate IV R$\mathrm{SO} 3 \mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{K}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What advantage if any does soap less detergent have over soapy detergent?
Sheet1.Answer: The soapless detergents are not affected by hard water i.e. their $\mathrm{Mg}$ and Ca salts are also soluble.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: The area of a square is $200 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$. Find the length of a diagonal of the square.
Sheet1.Answer:
$20 \mathrm{~cm}$
Let length of a side be $\mathrm{x}$. Hence $\mathrm{x}^{2}=200$ and $\mathrm{x}=10 \sqrt{2 \mathrm{~cm}}$ Let length of a diagonal be $\mathrm{d}$
$$
\mathrm{d}^{2}=(10 \sqrt{2})^{2}+(10 \sqrt{2})^{2}=400 \text { hence } \mathrm{d}=20 \mathrm{~cm}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: The length of a diagonal of a square is $30 \mathrm{~cm}$. Find the area of the square.
Sheet1.Answer:
$450 \mathrm{~cm}$
Let length of a diagonal be $\mathrm{d}$
Area of square is $1 / 2 \mathrm{~d}^{2}=1 / 2\left(30^{2}\right)=1 / 2(900)=450 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Heat energy is supplied to a low-density gas in a sealed jar. What will be the effect of the heat on the internal energy of the gas? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The internal energy of the gas will increase. This is because the volume of the jar remains constant, and therefore the energy supplied cannot cause the volume of the gas to change. By the first law of thermodynamics, the effect of the supplied energy will be to change the internal energy of the gas.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question: Explain why the bulb of a clinical thermometer is always small.
Sheet1.Answer: This is to minimize the amount of heat energy taken by the thermometer itself during the measurement.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: In the measurement of blood pressure, two numbers are recorded, e.g. 120/80. Explain what these numbers stand for.
Sheet1.Answer: 120 represents the systolic pressure i.e. the pressure in the arteries when the heart contracts while the 80 represents the diastolic pressure i.e. the pressure in the arteries when the heart relaxes..
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Which of the chambers of the heart has the thickest muscular wall and why?
Sheet1.Answer: The left ventricle has the thickest muscular wall because it pumps blood to all parts of the body. The right ventricle only pumps blood to the lungs while the atria only pump blood to the ventricles.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Explain why although the formula of ethanoic acid is $\mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{H}_{4} \mathrm{O}_{2}$, and that of carbonic is $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{CO}_{3}$, the former is a monobasic acid while the later is a dibasic acid.
Sheet1.Answer: Ethanoic acid can donate only one proton to a base whilst carbonic acid can donate 2.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Why is $\mathrm{AlCl}_{3}$ used as an acid sometimes?
Sheet1.Answer: $\mathrm{AlCl}_{3}$ is a Lewis Acid it is an electron pair acceptor. OR in water it hydrolyses to $\mathrm{Al}(\mathrm{OH})_{3}$ which is a proton donor.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Simplify the expression as far as possible
Sheet1.Question: $\sqrt[3]{16 x^{4} y}-3 x(\sqrt[3]{2 x y})+5\left(\sqrt[3]{-16 x y^{4}}\right)$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Simplify the expression as far as possible
Sheet1.Question: $8 x y-\sqrt{25 x^{2} y^{2}}+\sqrt[3]{8 x^{3} y^{3}}$
Sheet1.Answer:
$5 x y$
$8 x y-5 x y+2 x y=5 x y$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Ultrasound imaging is a popular way of getting an image of the foetus in a mother's womb by using high frequency sound waves. Why is ultrasound used? It is possible to use other methods for imaging the baby? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: Ultrasound waves do not possess enough energy to cause damage (by ionization), therefore it is safe for the mother and foetus. It is possible to use other methods such as computer tomography, but these use high energy radiation which is likely to cause damage to the foetus. (Magnetic Resonance Imaging MRI may also be used without serious safety issues.)
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: It is possible to determine the distance of the moon from the earth by reflecting a beam of radio waves from the moon's surface and measuring the time it takes for the reflected signal to be received. Why it is not possible to determine the earth-sun distance in this manner?
Sheet1.Answer: It is not possible because the sun behaves as a black-body, i.e. it is a perfect emitter as well as absorber of radiation. Therefore, the sun will absorb the radio waves and no reflection will be observed.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: When plants are exposed to conditions in which they lose water to the atmosphere faster than can be obtained from the soil, they wilt i.e. the stem droops and the leaves become limp and folded.
Sheet1.Question: What do you think is the advantage of wilting, if it occurs for a short period?
Sheet1.Answer: The folding of the leaves reduces the surface area exposed to direct sunlight and this reduces transpiration and loss of water to the atmosphere.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Preamble Text: When plants are exposed to conditions in which they lose water to the atmosphere faster than can be obtained from the soil, they wilt i.e. the stem droops and the leaves become limp and folded.
Sheet1.Question: What do you think is the main disadvantage of wilting?
Sheet1.Answer: The folding of leaves reduces the surface area of the leaves exposed to direct sunlight and this reduces photosynthesis.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: In Chemistry what are standard solutions?
Sheet1.Answer: They are solutions whose exact concentration are known.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Name one primary standard for acids.
Sheet1.Answer:
a. $\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{CO}_{3} /$ anhydrous sodium trioxocarbonate IV
b. $\operatorname{Borax}\left(\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{~B}_{4} \mathrm{O}_{10} .10 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\right)$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Find a vector of unit length perpendicular to the vector
Sheet1.Question: $a=2 \mathrm{i}+3 \mathrm{j}$
Sheet1.Answer:
$(3 i-2 j) / \sqrt{13}$
$\mathrm{b}=3 \mathrm{i}-2 \mathrm{j}$ is perpendicular to $\mathrm{a}=2 \mathrm{i}+3 \mathrm{j}$
The corresponding unit vector is $\frac{3 i-2 j}{\sqrt{13}} \frac{3 i-2 j}{\sqrt{13}}$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Find a vector of unit length perpendicular to the vector
Sheet1.Question: $a=3 i-4 j$
Sheet1.Answer:
$(4 \mathrm{i}+3 \mathrm{j}) / 5$ or $0.8 \mathrm{i}+0.6 \mathrm{j}$
$\mathrm{b}=4 \mathrm{i}+3 \mathrm{j}$ is perpendicular to $\mathrm{a}=3 \mathrm{i}-4 \mathrm{j}$
The corresponding unit vector is $(4 i+3 j) / \sqrt{\left(4^{2}+3^{2}\right)}=(4 i+3 j) / 5$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: State one feature of the $x$-ray spectrum from an $x$-ray tube and explain how it is produced.
Sheet1.Answer:
a. Maximum energy (frequency) or minimum wavelength - this is produced when the electrons incident on the metal target give off all their energy, which is emitted as photons with energy that cannot exceed the energy of the incident electrons.
b. White Background - this is produced when the incident electrons slow down within the metal target.
Characteristic Spectrum - this is produced when the atoms in the target are excited and return to ground state by emitting photons.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Lack of which vitamin causes night blindness, why?
Sheet1.Answer: Lack of vitamin A causes night blindness. This is because it is required for synthesis of visual purple or rhodopsin, the light sensitive pigment produced by the rods which is responsible for vision in dim light.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Lack of which vitamin causes prolonged bleeding from ruptured blood vessels and why?
Sheet1.Answer: Lack of vitamin K causes prolonged bleeding from ruptured vessels. This is because it is required for the synthesis of the protein prothrombin which plays a role in blood clotting.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: The escape velocity of the Earth is about $11 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}$. Explain what is meant by the term escape velocity.
Sheet1.Answer: The escape velocity is the minimum velocity or speed that an object must have in order to escape from the gravitational pull of the Earth.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: People on Earth see only one side of the moon all the time. The other side, also known as the "far side", is not visible from the Earth. Explain why this is so.
Sheet1.Answer: The moon rotates as it orbits the Earth, and the orbital period is equal to its period of rotation. (This is synchronized with the Earth's own rotation such that it is always the same side of the moon that is visible at any time from the earth).
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Which functional group could be present in an organic molecule if it gives effervescence with aqueous sodium hydrogen trioxocarbonate IV (i.e aq. $\mathrm{NaHCO}_{3}$ ).
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Which group could be present in an organic molecule if it gives iodoform with a mixture of $\mathrm{NaOH}$ and $\mathrm{I}_{2}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
Methyl alkanones/ketones or
Alkanols that can be oxidized to methyl alkanone
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Find the area of the rhombus whose diagonals have lengths $15 \mathrm{~cm}$ and $16 \mathrm{~cm}$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Find the area of a kite whose diagonals are of lengths $20 \mathrm{~cm}$ and $14 \mathrm{~cm}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Diatoms have vacuoles that contain oil. What is the importance of this?
Sheet1.Answer: It enables them to float on the surface of water bodies where they can get enough sunshine for photosynthesis
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Most trees in the savanna region have thick barks. What is the importance of this?
Sheet1.Answer: It enables them to resist the effects of bush fires which are frequent in the savanna region.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What are the major differences between a torch light battery and car-battery as sources of direct current?
Sheet1.Answer:
Torch-light battery: single cell
Primary cell i.e. cannot be recharged
Car battery: 6 cells joined in series
Secondary cell i.e. can be recharged
Sheet1.Subject: Physics, Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Identify the anode, the cathode and the electrolyte in a torch light battery
Sheet1.Answer:
Anode - $\quad$ Zinc in the form of a sheet, rolled to form the container
Cathode - Carbon rod
Electrolyte - (Powdered carbon) manganese IV oxide.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question: A man bought a Mathematics book and a science book and he paid GHS 15. Another man bought two of the same Mathematics and three of the science books and he paid GHS 40 . Find the cost of each book.
Sheet1.Answer:
Mathematics book costs GHS 5, and Science book costs GHS 10
Let Mathematics book cost GHS x and Science book cost GHS y.
$x+y=15$ and $2 x+3 y=40$
$$
2 x+2 y=30 \text {, hence } y=10 \text { and } x=5
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: A girl buys three loaves of bread and three cakes at a cost of GHS 21. The last time she spend GHS 9 when she bought two loaves of bread and a cake. Find unit cost of the bread and the cake.
Sheet1.Answer:
Bread: GHS 2, Cake: GHS 5, Bread: x, Cake: $y$
$$
3 x+3 y=21, \text { and } 2 x+y=9
$$
Solving simultaneously, $x=2$, and $y=5$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Explain why light emitted from a fluorescent lamp is unpolarised, even though each phosphor molecule within the lamp is most likely to emit linearly polarized light.
Sheet1.Answer: Though each individual molecule may emit linearly polarized light, the direction of polarization is likely to be different from the other molecules. Taken together, the light from a great number of molecules will appear to be unpolarised, since it will contain all directions of polarization.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Many street lamps are sodium discharge lamps. Explain why these emit amber (or yellowish) light.
Sheet1.Answer: In a discharge lamp, an electric current is made to flow through a gas or vapour containing atoms or ions. A sodium discharge lamp contains sodium vapour, and as the electric current flows, the sodium atoms absorb energy and become excited. As the atom de-excites, electrons move to lower energy levels, thereby emitting radiation. Yellow light is one of the wavelengths emitted when sodium atoms de-excite.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Human beings have binocular vision. What does this mean and what is its advantage?
Sheet1.Answer: Binocular vision means that the image of the same object can be focused on the retinas of both eyes. The advantage of this is that it permits three dimensional vision. It also makes the judgment of distance accurate (i.e. it permits perception of depth and distance)
Sheet1.Subject: Biology, Physics

Sheet1.Question: The terms spawning and swarming are used in relation to fishes and insects respectively. What do these terms mean?
Sheet1.Answer: Spawning is the seasonal movements of some fishes upstream to lay large numbers of eggs while swarming is the movement of large numbers of insects in a specific direction.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What do you expect to observe if a few drops of conc. $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$ are added to some crystals of $\mathrm{Fe}_{2}\left(\mathrm{SO}_{4}\right)_{3}$ in a test tube?
Sheet1.Answer: Clear solution, no gas, no precipitate is formed.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: A few crystals of $\mathrm{Fe}_{2}\left(\mathrm{SO}_{4}\right)_{3}$ are dissolved in test tube and a solution of $\mathrm{Pb}\left(\mathrm{NO}_{3}\right)_{2}$ are added dropwise and in excess. What do you expect to see?
Sheet1.Answer: White precipitate of $\mathrm{PbSO}_{4}$, insoluble in excess.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: A piece of bone is discovered in an archaeological excavation, and the researchers wish to identify how old the bone is. There is a popular technique using radioactivity that can be used to determine the age of the bone. What is this technique and how is it applied?
Sheet1.Answer: The technique is Carbon dating (or carbon-14 dating). It is applied by measuring the activity (or radioactive emissions) from the sample and comparing the measured values to the activity of Carbon-14 in the atmosphere.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics, Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Explain why carbon-14 dating methods cannot be used to determine the age of a living organism. We assume here that living organisms can only be found on earth.
Sheet1.Answer: C-14 dating works by comparing the present activity of $\mathrm{C}-14$ in the test sample to the activity of $\mathrm{C}-14$ in the atmosphere. If the sample comes from a living organism, the activity of C-14 in the sample will be the same as the activity of C-14 atmosphere since the organism will always be taking in C-14 from the atmosphere once it is alive. Therefore C-14 dating will not work in this case since the method depends on the difference between the C-14 activity of the sample and the atmosphere.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question: The length of a rectangle is increased by $20 \%$ and the breadth is decreased by $10 \%$. Find the $\%$ increase or decrease in the area of the rectangle.
Sheet1.Answer:
$8 \%$ increase
$L B \frac{120}{100} \times \frac{90}{100}=L B \frac{108}{100}$, Hence $\%$ increase is $8 \%$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: The area of a square is decreased by $36 \%$. Find the $\%$ decrease in the length of a side.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: There is an order of mammals that feed mainly on insects and are referred to as insectivora. What is the most distinguishing feature that enables them to feed efficiently on insects?
Sheet1.Answer: They have an elongated snout (large nose and area around the mouth) that helps them to fish out hidden insects.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: The five toes of a chameleon are fused into a group of two and a group of three. What do you think is the advantage of this? [1 attempt]
Sheet1.Answer: It gives the foot a tong-like appearance and this allows the chameleon to grip tightly to narrow branches.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: In which chemical form does aluminium exist in bauxite
Sheet1.Answer: Hydrated aluminium oxide $\mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3} .2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ or aluminium hydroside $\mathrm{Al}(\mathrm{OH})_{3}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Why is bauxite treated with hot $\mathrm{NaOH}$ solution in the Bayer Process?
Sheet1.Answer: Bauxite would normally have impurities such as sand $\mathrm{SiO}_{2}$ and iron oxides. The conc. $\mathrm{NaOH}$ dissolves the aluminium hydroxide, leaving the sand and iron oxides, which can be filtered off.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Explain how the operation of an incandescent lamp differs from the operation of a neon lamp.
Sheet1.Answer:
The incandescent lamp generates light from a heated filament that glows because it is hot: when electric current flows through the filament, it heats up and emits light.
The neon lamp generates light from the de-excitation of excited atoms. When electric current is made to flow through neon gas, the atoms become excited and electrons move to higher energy levels. As the electrons de-excite, the atoms emit energy.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: State the difference between an internal combustion engine and an external combustion engine and give an example of each, as applied to vehicular transportation.
Sheet1.Answer:
In an internal combustion engine, the working fluid is in direct contact with the combustible material; i.e. the combustible material is burnt inside the engine. In an external combustion engine, the working fluid is not in direct contact although it is in thermal contact; i.e. the combustible material is burnt outside the engine.
Examples: Internal combustion engine: car engines; petrol, diesel engines, dieselelectric trains, motorbikes, etc; (corn mill engine).
External combustion engine: steam locomotives, steam ships
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Find an equation of variation in which $y$ varies as $x$ and inversely as $\mathrm{z}^{2}, \mathrm{y}=2$, when $\mathrm{x}=10$ and $\mathrm{z}$ $=5$.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Find an equation of variation in which $\mathrm{y}$ varies inversely as $\mathrm{x}$ and directly as $\mathrm{Z}^{2}$, given that $\mathrm{y}=4$, when $\mathrm{x}=3$ and $\mathrm{z}=2$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: The arc of a circle has length $15 \mathrm{~cm}$ and the radius of the circle is $10 \mathrm{~cm}$. find the angle in radians subtended by the arc at the centre of the circle.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: An arc of a circle subtends an angle of 1 radian at the centre of the circle. If the radius is $10 \mathrm{~cm}$, calculate the area of the sector.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Explain why the spectrum of hydrogen has many lines, even though the hydrogen atom has only one electron
Sheet1.Answer: Even though hydrogen has only one electron, there are many energy levels (or states) available and the electrons can be in any one of these states, leading to many lines in the absorption and emission spectra.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question: A quantity of pure silicon is melted in a furnace. While molten, a small amount of pure Gallium is added to the silicon. What sort of semiconductor material will be formed when the silicon solidifies? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: P-type silicon will be formed. This is because, each Gallium atom has one less electron than a silicon atom, leading to less electrons i.e. more holes, which are positively charged, in the semiconductor.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: If $\mathrm{A}$ is an acute angle and $\cos \mathrm{A}=\frac{1}{3}$ calculate $\cos 2 \mathrm{~A}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: If $\mathrm{A}$ is acute and $\tan \mathrm{A}=\frac{3}{4}$, calculate $\sin 2 \mathrm{~A}$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: You are given a single converging lens. When you observe the image formed by this lens, you find that the edges of the image are coloured. What is the name given to this phenomenon? Explain why the image appears the way it does.
Sheet1.Answer: The name of the phenomenon is 'chromatic aberration'. It is caused by the lens dispersing light from the object according to the components of the light; i.e., the different components of the light are focused at slightly different points. For example, blue light will be focused closer to the lens than red light.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics, Biology

Sheet1.Question: Objects that are closer to your eyes appear larger than objects that are far away. For example, a pencil held at arms length appears larger than a storey building hundreds of meters away. Explain why this is so.
Sheet1.Answer: The length (or size) of an image that is formed by the eye is proportional to the 'visual angle' at the eye - i.e. the angle subtended at the eye by the object. The larger the visual angle, the greater the apparent size of the object. Since the visual angle is largest when the object is close to the eye, such objects appear larger.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics, Biology

Sheet1.Question: Are denitrifying bacteria beneficial or undesirable? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: They are undesirable because they convert nitrates in the soil into atmospheric nitrogen, thereby decreasing the amount of nitrates in the soil available to plants.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Can a haploid cell undergo meiosis? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: No, a haploid cell cannot undergo meiosis. This is because it has not got homologous chromosomes to pair up.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question:
Name the polymer and the monomer used in making these household items
Coating for electric and telephone wires
Black plastic bag
Plastic chairs
Ropes
Sheet1.Answer:
Polyethene(ethane)(monomer)
Polythene (ethene)
Polypropene (propene)
Nylon (1,6 - diaminohexane
Or ( 1,6-hexa dioic acid)
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: A colour blind woman married a man with normal vision. They had ten children-six boys and four girls. How many will be normal?
Sheet1.Answer: All the females will be normal but carriers while all the boys will be colour blind i.e. 4 will be normal.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: A normal woman but not a carrier married a colour blind man and they had ten children, seven boys and 3 girls. How many of them will be normal?
Sheet1.Answer: All the 10 children will be normal but the girls will be carriers.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: The separation of each pair of alleles on homologous chromosomes during meiosis in the formation of gametes and their subsequent recombination during fertilization brings about variation in the offspring. What are the other two factors that enhance this variation caused by independent assortment?
Sheet1.Answer:
1. Crossing over
2. The fact that fertilization is a random process.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: How much variation as a result of independent assortment can occur in a cell with 6 pairs of Chromosomes?
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What factor determines whether a triglyceride would be a solid (or fat) or a liquid (oil).
Sheet1.Answer: Depends on the degree of unsaturation in the fatty - acid residues.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Biology

Sheet1.Question: When fats and oils become rancid, what chemical processes would have taken place?
Sheet1.Answer:
1. Hydrolysis of the ester into fatty acid and glycerol
2. Oxidation of the double bonds in the fatty acid residue
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Biology

Sheet1.Preamble Text: The number 13.5 is given to 3 significant figures and the number 9.7 is given to 2 significant figures. If the two numbers are added, find:
Sheet1.Question: The maximum possible value of the sum.
Sheet1.Answer:
23.3
13.5 to 3 sig.fig is $13.5 \pm \mid 0.05$
9.7 to 2 sig.fig is $9.7 \pm\left.\right|_{0.05}$
Max value is $13.55+9.75=23.3$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: The number 13.5 is given to 3 significant figures and the number 9.7 is given to 2 significant figures. If the two numbers are added, find:
Sheet1.Question: The minimum possible value of the sum
Sheet1.Answer:
23.1
13.5 to 3 sig.fig is $13.5 \pm\left.\right|_{0.05}$
9.7 to 2 sig.fig is $9.7 \pm \mid 0.05$
Min value is $13.45+9.65=23.1$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Space-based telescope such as the Hubble space telescope are placed in orbit around the earth. Explain the main advantage that a space based telescope has over a ground-based telescope.
Sheet1.Answer: Electromagnetic radiation reaching a ground based telescope is much reduced by the effect of the Earth's atmosphere, which absorbs, scatters, or reflects a lot of the radiation incident from outer space. A space based telescope does not have this problem.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Often, one hears that looking at the stars and galaxies is like traveling backwards in time or looking into the past. Explain what is meant by this statement.
Sheet1.Answer: Some of the stars and galaxies are several millions of light years away from the earth. This means that the light that is incident on an observer's eye from some stars was emitted several millions years ago, and is only at this time reaching the earth. Therefore, the night sky that one sees is not what currently pertains but pertained in the past.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The function of sweating is to promote evaporative cooling when the body temperature rises. Sweating therefore occurs only when the body temperature rises". Do you agree with this? Explain.
Sheet1.Answer: NO. Even though the major function of sweating is to promote evaporative cooling, it can also occur during periods of emotions such as fear and nervousness. In these conditions adrenalin is secreted and this causes sweating.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What is respiratory quotient and why is it high in animals preparing to hibernate?
Sheet1.Answer: Respiratory quotient is the ratio of the amount of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ produced to the amount of oxygen used in a period of time by an organism. In animals preparing to hibernate, there is conversion of carbohydrate to fat and this results in the release of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ and thus a high respiratory quotient.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Two metal cations $\mathrm{A}^{+}$and $\mathrm{B}^{+}$both form insoluble sulphides with $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}$ gas but in the presence of a mineral acid $\mathrm{A}^{+}$does not give a precipate with $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}$ but $\mathrm{B}^{+}$does. How do you explain the different behavior of $\mathrm{A}^{+}$and $\mathrm{B}^{+}$?
Sheet1.Answer: The presence of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$suppresses ionization of the $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}$._There will be fewer $\mathrm{S}^{2-}$ ions. The sulphide that can be formed from small concentration of $\mathrm{S}^{2-}$ will precipate. ie: Sulphide of A has lower solubility product.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Why are gas densities proportional to molar masses?
Sheet1.Answer: This is because for the gases molar volume is constant. Therefore irrespective of the molar mass, high or low, the gas will occupy the same volume hence $\mathrm{d} \alpha_{\mathrm{m}}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question:
The measures of the angles of a triangle are $2 x+30^{\circ}, x+50^{\circ}, 3 x-50^{\circ}$.
Find the value of $x$.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question:
The angles of a quadrilateral have measures of $2 x, 4 x, 5 x$ and $7 x$.
Find the value of $x$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$x=20$
$2 x+4 x+5 x+7 x=18 x=360^{\circ}$ 
$$
\therefore \mid x=20^{\circ}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: In a small village, two identical houses stand side by side. One of the houses is roofed with shiny new aluminum roofing sheets and the other has old, rusting sheets. Which of these houses is likely to have warmer rooms during the day? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The house with old, rusting roofing sheets will be warmer, since these roofing sheets have a darker colour and rougher surface. Therefore, they are poor reflectors of thermal (infra-red) radiation from the sun. The shiny roofing sheets will reflect the sunlight better and therefore the rooms will be cooler.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: If we disregard the effect of reflection, which of these two houses is likely to have cooler rooms: A house that has a roof of red clay tiles, or a house that a roof of shiny aluminum sheets? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The house that has a roof of clay tiles is likely to be cooler, because clay is a poor conductor of heat whereas aluminum, being a metal, is a good conductor. This is regardless of the fact that the aluminum will reflect more of the incident radiation than the clay tiles.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Use the first law of thermodynamics to explain why the shaft of a bicycle pump heats up when the pump is used to inflate a tire. What other effect could lead to the heating?
Sheet1.Answer:
According to the first law of thermodynamics, when work is done on a gas, the internal energy increases and heat energy is generated. Work is done on the pump when the piston compresses the air and forces it into the tire. (On the 'upstroke', fresh air is drawn into the shaft before also being compressed- this leads to a continued warming of the shaft).
Another effect that leads to heating is friction between the parts of the pump.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Explain why the surface of a car tire has grooves on it.
Sheet1.Answer:
1) This is to allow water to be efficiently squeezed out from under the tire when the tire passes over a wet or flooded surface. If there were no grooves, the tire would make poor contact with the road surface due to the water. With the grooves, the water will be squeezed out and the tire will still make good contact with the road surface.
2) It allows for a better grip on the road surface due to friction and suction effects.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: In human beings, the allele for albinism is recessive to the allele for normal skin pigmentation.
Sheet1.Question: If a father and mother are both heterozygous for the condition, what is the probability that their normal child will be a carrier of the recessive albino allele.
Sheet1.Answer:
Parents Aa
Children $\quad \underline{\text { AA }} \frac{\text { Aa Aa }}{3 \text { normal }} \quad 1$ albino
2 out of the 3 normal children will be carriers i.e. $67 \%(66.6)$
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Preamble Text: In human beings, the allele for albinism is recessive to the allele for normal skin pigmentation.
Sheet1.Question: If a normal homozygous man marries a normal heterozygous woman, what is the probability their normal child will be a carrier of the recessive albino allele
Sheet1.Answer:
AA Aa
AA AA Aa Aa
All the children will be normal but 2 will be carriers i.e. 2 out of $4=50 \%$
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Solve the equation with rational expressions
Sheet1.Question: $\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{x+2}=\frac{3}{4}$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Solve the equation with rational expressions
Sheet1.Question: $6 \mathrm{x}^{2}+5 \mathrm{x}^{-1}+1=0$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: In mineral processing, ores are sometimes roasted during the process of extraction/purification. What is roasting?
Sheet1.Answer: Roasting is the process of heating a mineral/ore in air to obtain an oxide of the metal.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: There are usually 2 different reasons why ores are roasted what are these?
Sheet1.Answer:
(a) To covert the mineral to a compound suitable for reduction ( $\mathrm{FeS}_{2}$ to oxide of iron, $\mathrm{ZnS}$ to oxide of zinc).
(b) To get rid of certain substances that can interfere with extraction of the principal metal. (e.g. in gold extraction arsenic sulphate is heated to get rid of As and S)
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Explain why even small pieces of space debris are considered a danger to spacecraft and satellites.
Sheet1.Answer: This is because the velocity of the objects in space is usually very large. This means that the change in kinetic energy can be large during a collision even if the mass of a piece of debris is small, and this may cause significant damage to a space vehicle such as a spacecraft or satellite. Also, the space vehicles are quite delicate and impacts that can punch holes or create deep scratches may cause serious damage.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Sometimes, when a satellite is de-commissioned, its trajectory is altered so that it re-enters the earth's atmosphere. Explain why this is done, and what happens to the satellite.
Sheet1.Answer: This is a means of disposing of the satellite. The satellite will burn up when it enters the atmosphere, due to friction generated by its speed within the atmosphere.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Methane burners are often used in greenhouses where crops like tomatoes are grown. What do you think is the importance of this?
Sheet1.Answer: The methane burners produce $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$, giving a $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ enriched environment. The increased $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ increases the rate of photosynthesis.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology, Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: During rapid photosynthesis, glucose is produced at a rate faster than can be removed by the sieve tubes. The glucose is immediately converted to starch. What do you think is the importance of this?
Sheet1.Answer: A high level of glucose in the cells of the leaf can result in the osmotic pressure of the cells being lowered to a harmful level (i.e. the cells can absorb too much water). Starch, being insoluble can accumulate without causing osmotic disturbances.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology, Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: A ship is moving in the direction $070^{\circ}$. It is instructed to move in a new direction $185^{\circ}$. Find the smallest angle it must turn through in order to move in the new direction.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: If the bearing of $A$ and $B$ is $330^{\circ}$, find the bearing of $B$ from $A$.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Give the expected products when ethyl butanoate is reduced with $\mathrm{LiAlH}_{4}$. [1 attempt]
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Some ethyl butanoate is put in a test- tube and drops of dilute $\mathrm{NaOH}$ are added and heated. How can you tell if a reaction has taken place?
Sheet1.Answer: The sweet smell of the ester will disappear.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What is the pulse of a person and why is it normally taken from the wrist?
Sheet1.Answer: The pulse is a series of dilations that spread along the arteries as a result of the pumping action of the heart. It is normally taken from the wrist because here, the artery passes closely to the skin.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: A baby born to a rhesus positive father and a rhesus negative mother is likely to be born anaemic but will live. Subsequent babies born to the same parent, however have lesser chance of living. Why?
Sheet1.Answer: The first baby is unlikely to die because the mother's rhesus antibodies may not be sufficient to cause excessive destruction of the baby's red blood cells. With each subsequent pregnancy the mother produces more antibodies and this increases the chances of the babies dying from severe anaemia.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Find the equation of the straight line parallel to the line with equation $3 \mathrm{x}-2 \mathrm{y}=10$, and passing through the point $\mathrm{A}(1,-2)$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$y=\frac{3 x}{2}-\frac{7}{2}$ or $(y+2)=\frac{3}{2}(x-1)$ or $2 y=3 x-7$
Slope of line $\mathrm{m}=\frac{3}{2}\left(y=\frac{3 x}{2}-5\right)$
$\therefore$ Equation of the line is $(y+2)=\frac{3}{2}(x-1) \quad$ or $\quad y=\frac{3 x}{2}-\frac{7}{2}$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Find the equation of the straight line perpendicular to the line with equation $x+2 y=1$, and passing through the point $\mathrm{B}(2,1)$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{y}=2 \mathrm{x}-3$ or $(\mathrm{y}-1)=2(\mathrm{x}-2)$
[Slope of line $x+2 y=1$ is $m=-\frac{1}{2}$
$\therefore$ Slope of perpendicular line is 2
Equation of line is $(\mathrm{y}-1)=2(\mathrm{x}-2)$ or $\mathrm{y}=2 \mathrm{x}-3$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: A "satellite dish" is used in many homes to receive television signals beamed from orbiting satellites. Explain why satellite dishes have curved surfaces, and indicate how far the signal receiver must be placed from the surface of the disk.
Sheet1.Answer: The satellite dishes have curved surfaces (spherical or elliptical) so that signals (electromagnetic waves) received can be focused. The receiver must be placed at the focus of the curved surface, so the distance must be the focal length of the surface.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Explain why an $\mathrm{x}$-ray tube is evacuated and kept under vacuum.
Sheet1.Answer: Since there are high electric fields and fast moving electrons inside the tube when in operation, any atom within the tube will be ionized by collision with the electrons. When this happens, the positive ions created will be accelerated towards the cathode, which they strike at high velocity. Continuous bombardment of the cathode by the relatively heavy ions will result in damage to the cathode and a shorter lifetime of the tube.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: If someone is bitten by a snake, would you inject the person with whole blood containing the anti-venom or serum containing the anti-venom? Explain the reason for your choice.
Sheet1.Answer:
It would be preferable to inject the person with serum containing the anti-venom.
This is because if whole blood is injected, it would include the red blood cells and if the victim of the snake bite is in a different blood group, his or her red blood cells will clump together (agglutinate) and cause the person's death. With serum, the blood group of the recipient does not matter.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: If someone is bitten by a snake, how can you determine whether the snake is poisonous or not by an examination of the bite marks?
Sheet1.Answer: If the snake is not poisonous, it will leave marks of 2 rows of teeth but no fang marks, but if the snake is poisonous, it will leave two deep marks of the 2 fangs.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Express as partial fractions
Sheet1.Question: $\frac{X-2}{X+1}$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Express as partial fractions
Sheet1.Question: $\frac{x-2}{x+1} \frac{2 X+1}{X-1}$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Explain why a semiconductor with a large forbidden gap and an empty conduction band can be a good dielectric material.
Sheet1.Answer: A dielectric material is an insulator. With a large forbidden gap, a lot of energy is needed to move an electron from the valence band to the conduction band. If the valence band is empty, then such a semiconductor will be an insulator until sufficient energy is applied to cause electrons to move into the conduction band.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: When an intrinsic semiconductor is exposed to elevated temperatures, it becomes more capable of sustaining the flow of electric current .This is especially so for semiconductors with a small band gap. Explain how this happens.
Sheet1.Answer: For a small band gap, it does not require much energy to make an electron move from the valence to the conduction band. So, the electron can absorb the thermal energy and thereby cross the forbidden gap. Once the electrons are in the conduction band they are able to conduct electricity.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Describe the colour and toxicity of the given gases. In the case of toxicity indicate if it is very toxic, toxic or non toxic.
Sheet1.Question: $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Describe the colour and toxicity of the given gases. In the case of toxicity indicate if it is very toxic, toxic or non toxic.
Sheet1.Question: $\mathrm{CO}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Describe the colour and toxicity of the given gases. In the case of toxicity indicate if it is very toxic, toxic or non toxic.
Sheet1.Question: $\mathrm{SO}_{2}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Describe the colour and toxicity of the given gases. In the case of toxicity indicate if it is very toxic, toxic or non toxic.
Sheet1.Question: $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: The price of a car is reduced by $20 \%$ and sold for GHc20, 000. Find the original selling price of the car.
Sheet1.Answer:
GHc 25,000
let the original price of car be $\mathrm{GHc} \quad \mathrm{x}$
$80 \% x=20,000$, hence $\mathrm{x}=(100 / 80) 20,000$
$=(5 / 4) 20,000$
$=25,000$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: A book in a bookshop is sold for GHc55, at a profit of $25 \%$. Find the cost of the book to the bookshop.
Sheet1.Answer:
GHc44
let cost of book be GHc C
$C(5 / 4)=55$, hence $C=55 \times 4 / 5=11 \times 4=44$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question:
Consider a car moving in a circle of radius $\boldsymbol{R}$ at a constant velocity $\boldsymbol{V}$. Say which one of the following is true and explain your answer.
a. It is more likely for the car to skid when the radius $\boldsymbol{R}$ is small.
b. It is more likely for the car to skid when the radius $\boldsymbol{R}$ is large.
c. A larger or smaller $\boldsymbol{R}$ has no effect on whether the car will skid or not.
Sheet1.Answer: A. it is more likely for the car to skid when the radius is smaller. This is because the centripetal force required to keep the car moving in a circle is greater for smaller $R$.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question:
Consider two cars moving in a circle of radius $\boldsymbol{R}$ at a constant a velocity $\boldsymbol{V}$. one of the cars weighs two times as much as the other. Say which one of the following is true and explain your answer.
a. It is more likely for the heavier car to skid than for the lighter car to skid.
b. It is more likely for the lighter car to skid than for the heavier car to skid.
c. The weight of the cars has no effect on whether skidding will occur or not.
Sheet1.Answer: B. It is more likely for the lighter car to skid than for a heavier car to skid. This is because whether the car skids or not depends on the force of friction between the tires and the road surface. The force of friction in this case also depends on the mass or weight through the normal reaction force.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The inner membrane of a mitochondrion is highly folded to form cristae. What is the importance of this?
Sheet1.Answer: It provides a large surface area to accommodate the enzymes that are involved in the release of energy from ATP.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Hair, feathers and hooves are regarded as protective structures. What property makes them protective?
Sheet1.Answer: The cytoplasm of the cells in these structures has been replaced by a fibrous protein called keratin. This makes the cells hard and dead and therefore insensitive to pain.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ is one of the products of fermentation of carbohydrates. Give one commercial use of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
a. Preparation of dry ice, i.e. solid $\mathrm{CO} 2$ for cooling
b. Use in fire extinguishers.
c. Dissolved in beverages to give fizzy taste.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Biology

Sheet1.Question: Another product of fermentation of carbohydrates in ethanol. Give one commercial use.
Sheet1.Answer:
a. As solvent in industrial preparation.
b. In alcoholic beverages.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Biology

Sheet1.Question: How many litres of pure water should be added to 30 litres of a $40 \%$ acid solution to produce a $30 \%$ acid solution
Sheet1.Answer:
10 litres
let $x$ litres of pure water be added
$(x+30) 30 \%=(30) 40 \%$, hence $3(x+30)=4(30)$, and $3 x=30$ or $x=10$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: How many litres of pure acid should be added to 20 litres of a $30 \%$ acid solution to produce a $50 \%$ acid solution?
Sheet1.Answer:
8 litres
let $\mathrm{x}$ litres of pure acid be added
$(x+20(0.3))=(0.5)(x+20), x+6=1 / 2 x+10,1 / 2 x=4, x=8$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Two brass disks, having mass $10 \mathrm{~g}$ and $2 \mathrm{~g}$ respectively, are put in an insulated glass container. The $2 \mathrm{~g}$ disk is initially at a temperature of $200^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ while the $10 \mathrm{~g}$ disk is at a temperature of $32^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. After a sufficiently long period of time, would you expect (a) the $10 \mathrm{~g}$ disk to be at a greater temperature than the $2 \mathrm{~g}$ disk (b) the $2 \mathrm{~g}$ disk to be at greater temperature than the $10 \mathrm{~g}$ disk (c) both disks to be at the same temperature? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: Both disks will be at the same temperature. This is because after a sufficiently long time, thermal equilibrium will be reached.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question:
A brass block of mass $200 \mathrm{~g}$ is initially at a temperature of $150^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. It is split into parts of $25 \mathrm{~g}$ and $175 \mathrm{~g}$, which are then moved to opposite ends of the laboratory bench. After a few minutes, the temperature of both objects is measured. Would you expect that (a) the 25-g pieces will have a lower temperature (b) the $175 \mathrm{~g}$ piece will have a lower temperature (c) Both pieces will be at the same temperature.
Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The $25 \mathrm{~g}$ piece will be at a lower temperature. Since it has a smaller mass, it had a smaller amount of heat energy to begin with, and since the rate of heat loss will be the same for both pieces, the smaller piece will end up being at a lower temperature.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: A quadrat can only be used successfully to sample vegetation and not animals. Why?
Sheet1.Answer: This is because animals are mobile and can therefore easily escape beyond the boundaries of the quadrat.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What is the major flaw in Lamark's theory of evolution?
Sheet1.Answer: His theory proposes that acquired characteristics are inheritable but this has been found to be untrue.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Give the chemical formula for haematite an ore of iron. (1 attempt)
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Give the chemical formula for magnetite an ore of iron. (1 attempt)
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: How would you call an instrument such as the one based on J.J Thomson's cathode rays that separate ions by mass to charge ratios?
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question: J.J Thompson's experiment showed that the cathode rays behaved the same way regardless of the gas filling the tubes. What conclusion was drawn from this observation?
Sheet1.Answer: Cathode rays consisted of negatively charged particles (named electrons) which were present in all matter.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question: A bicycle wheel has 20 spokes evenly spaced around the wheel. Find the angle between two adjacent spokes.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: The angle between adjacent spokes of a bicycle wheel measures 30 . find the number of spokes
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: What is endemic goitre and what causes it?
Sheet1.Answer: Endemic goiter is a situation where a lot of people in an area have enlarged thyroid glands. It is caused by deficiency of iodine in the soil of the area and hence lack of it in the foodstuffs grown in that area.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: The major function of thyroxine is to increase metabolic rate and influence mental and physical development. What do you think will be symptoms of low thyroxine production in an adult? Give me at least 3 symptoms.
Sheet1.Answer:
Sluggishness, long periods of sleep, weight gain Constipation
Slow heart, ratemental sluggishness, Lethargy
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Preamble Text: In the following questions, $c$ is the speed of light in a vacuum.
Sheet1.Question: A spaceship, moving in outer space at speed of $0.3 \mathrm{c}$, fires a beam of ions that leave the ship with a velocity of $0.8 \mathrm{c}$ relative to the ship. To an observer in a stationary spaceship close by, the ion beam will appear to move with a speed a) Greater than the speed of light b) Less than the speed of light. c) Equal to the speed of light  (Explain your answer)
Sheet1.Answer: (b) the ion beam will be observed to be moving at a speed less than the speed of light. By eliminating the other possibilities: (a) nothing can travel faster than the speed of light (c) the ion beam cannot move at the speed of light, since the ions have mass.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Determine what is wrong with the following question and explain your answer
Sheet1.Question: A space ship, moving in outer space at a speed of $0.1 \mathrm{c}$, is spotted by a stationary enemy cruiser, which fires at the ship, using a beam of photons that emerges with a speed of $0.5 \mathrm{c}$. The initial distance of separation was 5 light minutes. Calculate the time taken for the beam to strike the spaceship.
Sheet1.Answer: The cruiser fires a beam of photons that emerges with a speed of $0.5 \mathrm{c}$ '. Since photons are electromagnetic radiation, they will have a velocity of $1 \mathrm{c}$ in the vacuum of outer space.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Determine what is wrong with the following question and explain your answer
Sheet1.Question: A column chromatograph is set up to separate $\beta-$ naphthol from naphthalene. The column is packed with neutral alumina and it is eluted with petroleum ether. Which of the two substances will come out first and why?
Sheet1.Answer: The petroleum ether being a non polar solvent will dissolve/ wash the non-polar compound better. Naphthalene is non-polar or less polar, hence naphthalene will come out first.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Ethylene glycol and glycerol are examples of alkanols that contain more than one hydroxyl group per molecule. Give their systematic names
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: If $\mathrm{A}(3,1), \mathrm{B}(3,5), \mathrm{C}(-3,5)$ and $\mathrm{D}(-3,1)$ are four vertices of a rectangle, find the point of intersection of the diagonals.
Sheet1.Answer:
$(0,3)$
Point of intersection is midpoint of $\overline{A C}$ or $\overline{B D}$
$$
\left(\frac{-3+3}{2}, \frac{5+1}{2}\right) \equiv(0,3)
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: If $\mathrm{A}(3,2), \mathrm{B}(-3,5)$ and $\mathrm{C}(5,7)$ are 3 vertices of the parallelogram $\mathrm{ABCD}$, find coordinates of $\mathrm{D}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Patients who are bedridden for a long time often develop blood clots, especially in the legs. What do you think accounts for this?
Sheet1.Answer: Because of their horizontal position (plus the practice of propping their legs up with pillows) blood flow through the body is very slow and it is this slow blood flow that promotes blood clot formation.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What is fainting and why should people who have fainted not be held in an upright position
Sheet1.Answer: Fainting is a brief loss of consciousness caused by a temporary reduction in blood flow to the brain. When a person faints that person falls to a horizontal position and this improves the blood flow to the brain. Holding such a person in an upright position decreases blood flow to the head since blood has to be pumped against gravity. This could lead to death.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Preamble Text: A balloon is filled with helium gas and attached to a string. The free end of the string is attached to the floor of a large glass container, so that the balloon floats in the air restrained by the taut string. Now, the container is sealed and the air is slowly pumped out of the container.
Sheet1.Question: Will the balloon burst? Explain
Sheet1.Answer: The balloon will burst. As the pressure inside the container reduces, the pressure difference between the inside and outside walls of the balloon will increase, leading to a large force on the balloon. This will cause the balloon to burst
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: A balloon is filled with helium gas and attached to a string. The free end of the string is attached to the floor of a large glass container, so that the balloon floats in the air restrained by the taut string. Now, the container is sealed and the air is slowly pumped out of the container.
Sheet1.Question: Suppose that the balloon is made of very strong material, and that it cannot burst. In that case, will the balloon remain at the same height, or will it fall to the ground as the air inside the glass container is pumped out? Explain
Sheet1.Answer: The balloon will fall to the ground. Initially, the forces acting on the balloon are its weight and the upthrust. As the air is pumped out of the container, the density of the air decreases, and the upthrust reduces. Therefore, the weight of the balloon makes it fall to the ground.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Why is filter paper fluted for filtration?
Sheet1.Answer: It exposes the greatest surface area and therefore hastens the process of filtration.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Why is spring water clean especially at the source, compared to the water in a flowing river?
Sheet1.Answer: In the spring water, as water comes from the water table to the source, it encounters stones pebbles and sand which purify the water by filtration and chromatography. Water in the river does not go through such processes.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: An arc of a circle subtends an angle of 1.5 radians at the centre. If the radius of the circle is $10 \mathrm{~cm}$, find the length of the arc.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: An arc of a circle subtends an angle of 1 radian at the centre. If the radius of the circle is $8 \mathrm{~cm}$, find the area of the sector bounded by the arc.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: A pyramid of numbers is a diagrammatic representation of the number of organisms at the different trophic levels. An inverted pyramid of numbers is possible but an inverted pyramid of energy is not possible. Explain why.
Sheet1.Answer: An inverted pyramid of numbers is possible because it is not always a fact that as one progresses through a food chain, the animals become fewer but larger eg. ticks on a dog. With regard to energy it is not possible for the consumer to possess more energy than the producer, no matter the number of consumers i.e energy is always lost as once progresses through a food chain.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Are coal and oil renewable or non-renewable resources/ Explain.
Sheet1.Answer: Coal and oil are non renewable resources, even though they are formed by natural processes. This is because it takes millions of years to form them; hence they cannot be replenished at a rate comparable to their consumption.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What accounts for the malleability of metals?
Sheet1.Answer: The metallic bonds - that is metal ions surrounded by mobile valence electrons.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What accounts for the ductility of metals?
Sheet1.Answer: The metallic bonds - i.e metal ions surrounded by mobile valence electrons.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: When you switch on an electric appliance at home, electric current starts to flow. Does this mean that the electrical appliance "uses up" the electrons? If yes, explain your answer. If no, what then do you pay for on your electricity bill? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The electrons are not "used up", as they flow through a circuit and any electrons that leave the appliance are replaced by others. What is paid for is electrical energy carried by the electrons. It is the electrical energy that does work in an electrical device.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Explain why the ice caps in the Arctic and Antarctic regions at the North and South pole of the Earth help to keep the planet cool.
Sheet1.Answer: The polar ice caps help to keep the planet cool by reflecting a lot of the radiation form the sun back into space.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The binary operation $*$ is defined on the set of rational numbers by $a * b=5$. Find the identity under the operation $*$
Sheet1.Answer:
$e=5$
Let $e$ be identity $e^{*} a=a$ and $e^{*} a=\frac{e a}{5}$
$$
\therefore \frac{e a}{5}=a \Rightarrow \frac{e}{5}=1 \Rightarrow e=5
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: The binary operation * on the set of rational numbers is defined by $\mathrm{a} * \mathrm{~b}=4 \mathrm{ab}$. Find the identity under the operation*
Sheet1.Answer:
$e=1 / 4$
Let $e$ be the identity 
$$
e * a=a, \quad e * a=4 a e \Rightarrow 4 a e=a \Rightarrow e=\frac{1}{4}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: A large truck traveling at $30 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$ collides with a small car traveling in the opposite direction at $40 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$. During the time of contact, does one of the vehicles exert a greater force on the other? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The force exerted on the small car by the truck is the same as the force exerted on the truck by the small car. This is explained by Newton's third law, which says that action and reaction are equal and opposite.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: A small lead ball is placed on a horizontal surface in a train that is moving at constant velocity along a straight and level stretch of track. Assuming that vibrations in the train are at a minimum, state whether the ball will roll forwards, backwards, or remain in the same position. Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The ball will remain in the same position since the train is moving at constant velocity in a straight line on a level track and there is no net force in the forward or backward direction acting on the ball.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Explain why people with sickle cell often suffer from anaemia.
Sheet1.Answer: People with sickle cell have abnormal haemoglobin which on exposure to low oxygen precipitates into long crystals. These crystals damage the red blood cell membrane leading to serious anaemia.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Explain how blood pressure affects urine formation.
Sheet1.Answer: In the process of urine formation blood is filtered in the glomeruli of the kidneys. This process requires high pressure. Thus when the blood pressure falls below a certain level, filtration cannot occur and urine formation is impaired.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Even though they don't do so in nature, donkeys and horses can be mated. The offspring produced, called a mule is sterile. What conclusions, in terms of the definition of species can you make of the donkey, horse and mule and why?
Sheet1.Answer: Because their offspring is sterile, the horse and donkey are different species, since members of species can interbreed to produce fertile offspring. The mule is not a species because it cannot mate with another mule to produce an offspring.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: A pharmaceutical company introduced a new drug that was guaranteed to prevent the occurrence of pain in and on the body of anyone who takes the drug regularly. A young man who cannot withstand pain decided that he would take the drug daily for the rest of his life so that he would never experience pain. Do you think this is a good idea? Explain.
Sheet1.Answer: No! This is not a good idea. This is because pain is a protective mechanism of the body. It occurs whenever any tissue is being damaged and causes the individual to react to remove the pain stimulus. e.g. if you touch a hot plate of a stove and you do not experience pain, your fingers will be burnt before you realize that the plate is hot.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: "Over-reproduction is necessary for evolution" Do you agree with this statement? Explain.
Sheet1.Answer: Yes the statement is true. It is over production of offspring that brings about the struggle for existence leading to natural selection of those that can survive. These then pass on their desirable traits to their offspring leading to evolution.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Sexual reproduction is more important that mutation in bringing about natural selection. Do you agree with this statement? Explain.
Sheet1.Answer: The statement is true because even though both mutation and sexual reproduction bring about genetic variety, the rate of naturally occurring mutation is slow and also usually results in an allele that may not be valuable. Sexual reproduction on the other hand, generates genetic variety faster and produces a more extensive recombination of genes and thus producing a wider variety of organisms.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Give the systematic name of alkanoic acid associated with ants.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Give the systematic name of any alkanoic acid obtained from the fat of goat.
Sheet1.Answer:
Hexanoic Acid
(Caproic Acid)
Octanoic Acid
Decanoic Acid
(Capyric Acid)
(Capric Acid)
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text: An urn (container) contains 10 identical balls of which 6 are black and 4 white.
Sheet1.Question: Two balls are drawn from the urn without replacement. Find the probability that both balls are of the same colour.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: An urn (container) contains 10 identical balls of which 6 are black and 4 white.
Sheet1.Question: Two balls are drawn with replacement. Calculate the probability that both are of the different colour.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: A bus is moving along a straight, horizontal stretch of highway at a constant velocity of $50 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$. The windows of the bus are closed. A small boy sitting in one of the front seats throws an orange upwards. There is a man sitting in the seat behind the boy.
Sheet1.Question: Will the orange hit the man sitting behind the boy, or will the orange return to the boy? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The orange will return to the boy. Since the bus is moving at constant velocity, there will be no horizontal force acting on the orange and therefore the orange only moves in a vertical direction.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: A bus is moving along a straight, horizontal stretch of highway at a constant velocity of $50 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$. The windows of the bus are closed. A small boy sitting in one of the front seats throws an orange upwards. There is a man sitting in the seat behind the boy.
Sheet1.Question: To a stationary observer on the ground who is watching the bus pass by, what is the trajectory of the orange? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: To the observer, the orange will follow a parabolic path curved downward. This is because to the observer on the ground, the orange has a constant horizontal velocity in addition to the vertical component imparted by the boy; i.e. to the observer on the ground the velocity of the orange has both horizontal and vertical components.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The output of a large audio amplifier is often connected to three sets of loudspeakers: the highfrequency tweeters, the low-frequency woofers, and the mid-range speakers. The frequencies are selected using a cross-over circuit. Describe how the cross-over circuit can be implemented for the tweeter and woofers, using a.c. circuit elements.
Sheet1.Answer: The high frequencies can be selected by using a capacitor to block the low frequencies and allow only the high frequencies to pass through; the output of this goes to the tweeters. The low frequencies can be selected by using an inductor to block the high frequencies and allow the low frequencies to pass through; the output of this goes to the woofers. The "mid range" will consist of signals that are rejected by both inductors and capacitors.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: In older radio sets, the tuning circuit was dependent on a variable capacitor. Explain how this variable capacitor can be used with alternating current circuit elements to tune a radio set to a particular transmission frequency.
Sheet1.Answer: The total impedance of a tuning circuit consisting of a.c. circuit elements depends on the reactance of the capacitors and inductors in the circuit, which depends on the frequency of the a.c. flowing through the circuit. At a certain frequency (the resonance frequency), the impedance is a minimum and a maximum current flows through the circuit. By adjusting the capacitance, the resonance frequency can be chosen to co-incide with a given transmission frequency. Thus, a maximum current of this frequency will flow through the circuit into the amplifier, thereby "tuning" the radio to that particular frequency.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: $\mathrm{PQRS}$ is a rectangle with vertices $\mathrm{P}(1,0), \mathrm{Q}(2,0)$ and $\mathrm{R}(2,3)$. Find coordinates of $\mathrm{S}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: $\mathrm{ABCD}$ is a rectangle with vertices $\mathrm{A}(-3,-3), \mathrm{B}(5,-3)$ and $\mathrm{C}(5,5)$. Find the coordinates of the vertex D.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: In the Mass Spectrometer, all atoms are capable of forming doubly charged ions except one atom. Which atom is this and why?
Sheet1.Answer: Hydrogen atom. It has only one electron.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: In a Column Chromatography in which the glass tube is packed with cellulose, and eluted with butanol, which is the stationary phase and which is the moving phase?
Sheet1.Answer:
Stationary Phase $\rightarrow$ Water in the cellulose
Moving Phase $\rightarrow$ Butanol
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Distinguish between temperature and heat.
Sheet1.Answer: Temperature is a measure of the degree of hotness or coldness of a body, whereas heat is the energy that is transferred between two objects/ reservoirs that are at different temperatures.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Explain what is meant by the statement that two objects are in thermal equilibrium.
Sheet1.Answer: The two objects are at the same temperature and any heat energy transferred between them will not change the temperature of either of them.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: It is generally better to feed many people with primary producers rather than with consumers. Why do you think this is so?
Sheet1.Answer: This is because energy is lost at each trophic level of a food chain.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Even though it is generally better to feed many people with primary producers rather than with consumers, there is a limitation in the feeding of people with only primary producers. What is this limitation?
Sheet1.Answer: Primary producers i.e. plants do not have all the essential amino acids that humans need (also plants have cellulose which is not digested).
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: By what method in Ghana is salt obtained from sea water? [1 attempt]
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: By what method is liquid nitrogen obtained from liquid air.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
Find the $\mathrm{n}^{\mathrm{hi}}$ term of the sequence
$2,5,8,11, \ldots$
Sheet1.Answer:
$(3 n-1)$
Sequence is an AP with first term $\mathrm{a}=2$, and difference $\mathrm{d}=3$.
$$
n^{\mathrm{n}} \text { term }=a+(n-1) d=2+(n-1) 3=3 n-1
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question:
Find the $n^{\text {hi }}$ term of the sequence
$1,9,25,49, \ldots$
Sheet1.Answer:
$(2 n-1)^{2}=4 n^{2}-4 n+1$
Sequence is $1^{2}, 3^{2}, 5^{2}, 7^{2}, \ldots$ squares of terms of AP, $\mathrm{a}=1, \mathrm{~d}=2$
$$
n^{\text {th }} \text { term }=(2 n-1)^{2} \quad(1+(n-1) 2)^{2}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question:
The emissions from a radioactive substance are monitored in a laboratory with a GeigerMuller counter. The radioactive substance has a half-life of several years. What would you expect from the measurements? The number of counts will
a. decrease
b. increase
c. remain the same
explain your answer
Sheet1.Answer: The number of counts will decrease. This is because the GM tube measures the activity of the sample, which is a function of time and decays exponentially.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics, Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: The activity of two samples of a radioactive material is monitored in a laboratory. One of the samples has a mass of $5 \mathrm{~g}$ and the other has a mass of $15 \mathrm{~g}$. Is the decay constant the same for both samples? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The decay constant is the same for both samples, because it is independent of the mass of the sample.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics, Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: In animals, the term incompatibility is used to describe the interaction between the tissues of two organisms that results in the rejection of a graft. What does the term mean when applied to higher plants?
Sheet1.Answer: The term when applied to higher plants refers to the mechanism that ensures that pollen from a plant does not grow on the stigma of the same plant. (This prevents self fertilization).
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Fertilization in flowering plants is often described as double. Why?
Sheet1.Answer: This is because in flowering plants, there is fertilization (i.e. fusion of male nucleus) with both the egg cell and the polar nuclei.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: State what you would see if dilute $\mathrm{NaOH}$ is added drop wise until it is in excess, to a solution containing lead ions.
Sheet1.Answer: A white precipitate is formed initially which dissolves in excess $\mathrm{NaOH}$ solution to give a clear solution
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Of the ions listed in the current school syllabus, which of them may be present in a solution if on adding ammonia to the solution a precipitate is formed. The precipitate does not dissolve in excess of ammonia.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: A total of GHc 10,000 is to be divided up between Esi and Kwadwo with Kwadwo receiving GHc 1,750 less than Esi. How much does each receive?
Sheet1.Answer:
Esi receives GHc 5,875 and Kwadwo receives GHc 4,125
10,000-1,750 $=8250$
Kwadwo receives $8250 / 2=4125$ Ghana cedis
Esi receives $4125+1750=5875$ Ghana cedis
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: A man wants to invest a total of GHc 20,000 in two banks with Ahomka Rural Bank receiving GHc5000 more than Susu Rural Bank. Find how much is invested at each of the two rural banks.
Sheet1.Answer:
Ahomka Rural Bank GHc 12,500, Susu Rural Bank GHc 7500 SOLUTION: 20,000-5000 $=15,000$
Susu Rural Bank receives GHc5000/2= GHc 7500
Ahomka Rural Bank receives 5000+ 7500=12,500
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Chemically what are vegetable oils
Sheet1.Answer: Triglycerides or triacyls of glycerol or Esters or 1,2,3-propan-triol
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Give one of the commnest ions formed when vegetable oils are saponified
Sheet1.Answer:
a. Stereate ion or (octodecanoate)
b. Palmitate ion or (hexadecanoate)
c. Myristate ion or (tetradecanoate)
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Which has a higher percentage of water vapour, inhaled or exhaled air and why?
Sheet1.Answer: Exhaled air has a higher percentage of water vapour because the respiratory organs have moist surfaces and add water to inhaled air.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Which has a higher percentage of nitrogen inhaled or exhaled air and why?
Sheet1.Answer: There is no difference in the percentage of nitrogen in inhaled and exhaled air. This is because nitrogen in inhaled air is not used for gaseous exchange and therefore its percentage remains the same.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Explain how Bohr's model of the atom explained the absorption and emission of radiation.
Sheet1.Answer: According to Bohr's atomic model, the electrons are in orbits around the nucleus of the atom, and these orbits define the energy levels of the atom. Absorption of radiation occurs when an electron receives just enough energy from incident photons to jump from a lower energy level to a higher energy level. Emission occurs when the electron jumps from a higher energy level to a lower energy level.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question: In Rutherford's scattering experiment, what would have been observed if a low- density beam of neutrons were used instead of alpha particles?
Sheet1.Answer: Since neutrons are uncharged, they are most likely to pass right through the metallic foil. Any deviations caused will be due to mechanical collisions and not electrostatic repulsion, so the likelihood of a deflection through a wide angle is small
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question: Find the total surface area of a solid hemisphere of radius $r$
Sheet1.Answer:
$3 \pi r^{2}$
Area of curved surface of the hemisphere $=2 \pi r^{2}$
Area of the flat circular surface
$$
=\pi r^{2}
$$$$
\text { Total surface area of a hemisphere } \quad=2 \pi r^{2}+\pi r^{2}=3 \pi r^{2}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Find the total surface area of a solid right circular cone of base radius $\mathrm{r}$ and height $\mathrm{h}$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\pi r^{2}+\pi r \sqrt{r^{2}+h^{2}}$ or $\pi r \quad\left(\mathrm{r}+\sqrt{r^{2}+h^{2}}\right)$
Slant height $l=\sqrt{r^{2}+h^{2}}$
Curved surface area $=\pi r l=\pi r \sqrt{r^{2}+h^{2}}$
Circular base area $=\pi r^{2}$
Total surface area of cone $=\pi r^{2}+\pi r \sqrt{r^{2}+h^{2}}$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Give one important use of the radioisotope of carbon-14 (C-14).
Sheet1.Answer: Carbon dating or synthesis of organic molecules containing $\mathrm{C}^{14}$ for tracer studies.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question: How are carbon-14 atoms produced.
Sheet1.Answer:
By bombardment of nitrogen nuclei by neutrons
${ }_{7}^{14} N+n \longrightarrow{ }_{6}^{14} C+{ }_{1}^{0} P$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question: Which of these 2 plants, venus flytrap or Canna lily would you expect to do well in a nitrogen deficient soil and why?
Sheet1.Answer: Venus fly trap is an insectivorous plant and can therefore obtain its supply of nitrates by digesting small animals. It will therefore do better in a nitrogen deficient soil than canna lily which is just a rhizome.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Which of these 2 plants, groundnuts or cocoyam, would you expect to do well in a nitrogen-deficient soil and why?
Sheet1.Answer: Groundnut is a leguminous plant and has nodules on its roots which contain bacteria that can fix atmospheric nitrogen and make it available to the plant. Cocoyam is a corm and cannot obtain nitrates from any other source.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Distinguish between cold-cathode emission and thermionic emission from a metallic surface
Sheet1.Answer: Cold-cathode emission occurs when electrons are ejected from the surface of a metal by the action of an electric field alone; whereas thermionic emission occurs when electrons are emitted from the surface due to the high temperature of the metal.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Mention the three ways in which a bipolar junction transistor is connected in a circuit.
Sheet1.Answer: Common base; Common emitter; and Common collector.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: A bag contains four black balls and five white balls. Two balls are drawn at random, one after the other without replacement.
Sheet1.Question: Find the probability that a black ball and a white ball are drawn
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: A bag contains four black balls and five white balls. Two balls are drawn at random, one after the other without replacement.
Sheet1.Question: Both are of same colour

Sheet1.Question: Find the probability that a black ball and a white ball are drawn
