Sheet1.Preamble Text: A bag contains four black balls and five white balls. Two balls are drawn at random, one after the other without replacement.
Sheet1.Question: Both are of same colour
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: In using a pitfall trap to sample the population of small animals, a glass jar is often sunk into the pit. Explain why.
Sheet1.Answer: The sides of a glass jar are smooth and slippery and so animals trapped cannot escape.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Explain why the capture - mark- release recapture method of determining the population of a species of animals in an area work best with animals whose movements are limited by geographic barriers, e.g. animals in a pond.
Sheet1.Answer: This is because animals that have been captured, marked and released should have the same chance as animals unmarked animals. If the movements of animals are not limited, the random mixing of marked and unmarked animals will not be possible.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Name one functional group in paracetamol.
Sheet1.Answer:
Amide
Phenol
Benzene ring / aromatic
(Amino group? Not exactly but accept)
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Name one functional group in aspirin.
Sheet1.Answer:
a. Carboxylic acid / Alkanoic acid
b. Estar / Alkanoate.
c. Benzene ring / aromatic nucleus
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Describe the process of the transfer of heat energy in a metal by conduction.
Sheet1.Answer: Conduction in a metal is due to the vibrations of atoms about their mean positions. Heat energy is also distributed through the metal by motion of electrons.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Describe the process of the transfer of heat energy by convection.
Sheet1.Answer: Convection occurs in fluids and involves the transfer of heat energy by the movement of particles from one region to the other.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: A painter can paint a room in ten hours. With the help of an assistant, the two can paint the room in six hours. If the assistant works alone, how long will it take him to paint the same room?
Sheet1.Answer:
15 hours
time (hrs) rate
$\begin{array}{lcll}\text { Painter } & 10 & 1 / 10 & \\ \text { Painter +assistant } & 6 & 1 / 6 & 1 / 10+1 / \mathrm{T}=1 / 6 \\ \text { Assistant } & \mathrm{T} & 1 / \mathrm{T} & 1 / \mathrm{T}=1 / 6-1 / 10=(10-6) / 60, \mathrm{~T}=15\end{array}$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Edem takes 20 minutes to complete a task and his friend Mawutor takes 30 minutes to complete the same task. If the two work together, how long will it take them to complete the task?
Sheet1.Answer:
12 minutes
time (mins) rate
$\begin{array}{lcll}\text { Edem } & 20 & 1 / 20 & \\ \text {Mawutor } & 30 & 1 /30 & 1 / 20+1 / \mathrm{30}=1 / T \\ \text {Edem+ Mawutor} & \mathrm{T} & 1 / \mathrm{T} \\
hence \\ T =12\end{array}$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Give three economic benefits of bees.
Sheet1.Answer:
a. Bees produce Honey which is used as food and sweetener
b. Bee wax is used for making candles, floor waxes and polishes
c. Bees are agents of pollination.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: One economic importance of lichens is that they are used as indicator species. What does this mean?
Sheet1.Answer: This means that they are used to estimate the extent of pollution in an area. This is because they will grow only where the pollution is below a certain level.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Name three metals that react with water at room temperature.
Sheet1.Answer:
Obvious ones: Sodium, Lithium, Calcium, Potassium
Not very obvious Rubidium,Caesium,strontium,Barium
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: In what way is beryllium different from the rest of the elements in Group II
Sheet1.Answer: It forms salts with more covalent character (due to its small atomic /ionic size)
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: You are in a car that is moving at a constant speed of $75 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$. A car behind you sounds its horn. This other car is also moving at $75 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$ in the same direction as your car. How will the frequency which you hear compare with the actual frequency of the horn? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The frequency heard will be the same as the frequency of the horn. This is because both cars are moving in the same direction with the same velocity, and therefore the relative velocity of one car to the other is zero.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: You are in are in a car that is moving at constant speed of $75 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$. A car in front of you sounds its horn. This other car is moving at $100 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$ in the same direction as your car. How will the frequency which you hear compare with the actual frequency of the horn? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The frequency heard will be lower than the frequency of the horn, because the velocity of the second car is higher than your car and therefore the sound waves have to travel through an increasing distance to reach you which causes the observed frequency to be lower than the emitted frequency.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Two events $\mathrm{A}$ and $\mathrm{B}$ are such that $\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{A})=0.7, \mathrm{P}(\mathrm{B})=0.6$ and $\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{A} \cap \cap \mathrm{B})=0.5$ Find
Sheet1.Question: $\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{AUB})$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Two events $\mathrm{A}$ and $\mathrm{B}$ are such that $\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{A})=0.7, \mathrm{P}(\mathrm{B})=0.6$ and $\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{A} \cap \cap \mathrm{B})=0.5$ Find
Sheet1.Question: $\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{A} \mid \mathrm{B})$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: The gastric juice of young mammals contains an enzyme called rennin which curdles or coagulates milk. What is the importance of this?
Sheet1.Answer: The curdling of milk slows down its passage through the stomach and this allows time for pepsin to act on milk protein.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Explain how the secretion of pancreatic juice is regulated.
Sheet1.Answer: The presence of food in the duodenum causes the duodenal lining to secrete a hormone called secretin (on pancreozymin) this hormone is carried by the blood to the pancreas and causes it to secrete pancreatic juice.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What is the relationship between oxygen gas and ozone?
Sheet1.Answer: They are both allotropes of the element oxygen.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Name the three natural isotopes of oxygen.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Factorise completely
Sheet1.Question: $\mathrm{X}^{4}-1$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Factorise completely
Sheet1.Question: $3 x-3 x^{3} y^{2}$
Sheet1.Answer:
$3 x(1-x y)(1+x y)$
$3 x-3 x^{3} y^{2}=3 x\left(x^{2} y^{2}-1\right)=3 x(x y-1)(x y+1)$
(Differences of two squares)
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: In most solar-electric or photo-voltaic applications, a battery bank is an integral part of the installation. Explain why batteries are needed in a solar installation.
Sheet1.Answer: To store the electrical energy generated by the photo-voltaic cells.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: In a typical application of utilizing the thermal energy from the sun in generating electricity, arrays of parabolic mirrors are often used. Explain the purpose of these mirrors.
Sheet1.Answer:
The mirrors are used to concentrate the rays of the sun, so that higher
temperatures can be achieved. This may then be used for generating steam for running a turbine.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Animals that live in streams and rivers are similar to those in ponds and lakes. Animals that live in streams and rivers however face the danger of being swept away by the water current. How do the following survive water currents?
Sheet1.Question: Ancylus
Sheet1.Answer: It has a smooth flat shell over which water flows easily without sweeping it away.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Preamble Text: Animals that live in streams and rivers are similar to those in ponds and lakes. Animals that live in streams and rivers however face the danger of being swept away by the water current. How do the following survive water currents?
Sheet1.Question: The larva of the black fly
Sheet1.Answer: It has a ring of hooks at its posterior end with which it attaches itself firmly to rocky surfaces.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Name any device which transforms chemical energy into mechanical energy.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Name any device in which chemical energy is transformed into electrical energy.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: An object appears black when viewed in white light. What will be the colour of the object when viewed in yellow light? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The object will still appear black in yellow light. It appears black in white light because it absorbs all the light incident on it. Since white light contains all the wavelengths of light (including yellow), it means that yellow light incident on the object will be absorbed and the object will appear black in yellow light.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: An object appears red when viewed in red light. What will be the colour of the object when viewed in white light? Will the object still appear red, or is the information supplied insufficient? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The information supplied is insufficient. Since the object is viewed in red light and appears red, all that can be inferred is that the object is not absorbing red light. No conclusion can be made as to which other wavelengths the object may or may not absorb. Therefore; the information supplied is insufficient to determine the colour of the object in white light.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The perimeter of a rectangular field is 600 meters and the length is 80 meters more than the width. Find the dimensions of the field.
Sheet1.Answer:
Length $=190 \mathrm{~m}$, and Width $=110 \mathrm{~m}$
2(L $+\mathrm{W})=600$ and $\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{W}=80$ (Solve for $\mathrm{L}$ and $\mathrm{W}$ )
$$
\mathrm{L}+\mathrm{W}=300
$$
$2 \mathrm{~L}=380$ and $\mathrm{L}=190, \mathrm{~W}=190-80=110$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: The perimeter of a rectangular field is 420 meters and the length is twice the width. Find the dimensions of the rectangular field.
Sheet1.Answer:
Length $=140 \mathrm{~m}$, and Width $=70 \mathrm{~m}$
$2(\mathrm{~L}+\mathrm{W})=420$ and $\mathrm{L}=2 \mathrm{~W}$
Hence $2(3 \mathrm{~W})=420 \quad($ Substitute $\mathrm{L}=2 \mathrm{~W})$
$$
\mathrm{W}=70 \text { and } \mathrm{L}=140
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Under what circumstance does absorption of mineral salt form the soil by the roots of plants occur through active transport?
Sheet1.Answer: Active transport occurs when the concentration of minerals in the root sap is higher that that in the soil
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Even though plasmolysis can be induced experimentally in living cells, it rarely coccurs in nature. Why.
Sheet1.Answer: This is because, for plasmolysis to occur the solution outside the plant's cells must be more concentrated than the cell's content and this does not occur. The cell contents are usually more concentrated than that of the soil and this allows water to be drawn into the plant by osmosis.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Suppose you set up an apparatus to prepare dry ammonia and collect it in gas jars, will you collect the gas with the open end of the jar up or turned up-side down and why?
Sheet1.Answer: Turned upside down since $\mathrm{NH}^{3}$ is lighter than air, it has to be collected by the downward displacement of air.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: How would you obtain dry ammonia gas?
Sheet1.Answer: By passing it through a tube packed with calcium oxide.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
A sailing ship or a boat equipped with sails uses the kinetic energy of the wind to move over the sea, i.e., the wind exerts a force on the sails and this moves the ship forward. Does this mean that the ship will always move in the same direction in which the wind is blowing?
Explain you answer.
Sheet1.Answer: No. By adjusting the position of the sail and the rudder, the resultant force on the ship can be made to act in a desired direction, even if the wind is not blowing in that particular direction.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question:
You are in a bus that is traveling at $70 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$ on a highway when a truck traveling at $90 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$ overtakes your bus on the left hand side. A force will be exerted on your bus due to the pressure difference that is created. In what direction will this force act?
a. Forward
b. to the left
c. to the right
d. backward? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: (b).The force will act towards the left; i.e., from right to left. This is because the wind speed between the truck and the bus will be increased as the truck passes by, and therefore the pressure will be lower on the left side and higher on the right side of the bus. This difference in pressure will result in a force acting towards the left.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The pituitary gland is often referred to as the master gland. Why?
Sheet1.Answer: This is because it secretes a number of hormones that control other endocrine glands.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: The abdominal glands are often referred to as suprarenal glands. Why?
Sheet1.Answer: This is because they are located on top of the kidneys.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: A charged particle is moving at constant velocity when it enters a magnetic field at right angles to the field. Describe the subsequent motion of the particles and state whether the kinetic energy of the particle will change.
Sheet1.Answer: The particle will move in a circular path, and it's kinetic energy will not change because the magnitude of the velocity remains the same even though the direction changes.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: In cold climates, rooms are often warmed by radiators or electric heaters. Where is it more efficient to mount a heater in the room: closer to the floor or closer to the ceiling? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: It is more efficient to mount the heater closer to the floor. This is because warm air will rise by convection, causing the heat to be distributed throughout the room.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ has a dipole moment of zero but $\mathrm{S}_{2}$ has a dipole moment of 1.64 Debye. What accounts for this difference?
Sheet1.Answer: $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ is a linear molecule but $\mathrm{SO}_{2}$ is molecule bent.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Tetrachloromethane $\mathrm{CCl}_{4}$ has a dipole moment of zero but trichloromethane has a dipole moment of 1.02 . Why?
Sheet1.Answer: In $\mathrm{CCl}_{4}$, all the $\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{Cl}$ dipoles cancel out but in $\mathrm{CHCl}_{3}$ there is a net dipole.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Find the area of a square with the points $\mathrm{A}(2,5)$ and $\mathrm{B}(-2,2)$ as adjacent vertices.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Find the area of a square with the points $\mathrm{A}(-1,4)$ and $\mathrm{B}(3,8)$ as endpoints of diagonal.
Sheet1.Answer:
16 square units
$|A B|^{2}=(3+1)^{2}+(8-4)^{4}=16+16=32$
Area of square is $1 / 2$ square of square of diagonal $=1 / 2(32)=16$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: $x(9 x-5)<(3 x-1)^{2}$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Two cars leave town $\mathrm{A}$ at the same time with one car traveling $15 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}$ faster than the other car. The faster car arrives at town B 3hrs later, $1 / 2$ hour before the other car. Find the average speed of each car.
Sheet1.Answer:
$90 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}$ and $105 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}$
SOLUTION
Let speed of slower car be $\mathrm{v} \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{hr}$
Distance $=$ Speed $\times$ Time
$(\mathrm{V}+15) 3=\mathrm{V}\left(3 \frac{1}{2}\right)$, hence $45=1 / 2 \mathrm{v}$ and $\mathrm{v}=90$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Two towns A and B are $320 \mathrm{~km}$ apart. A car leaves A for B and at the same time a second car leaves B for A. One car's speed is $20 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}$ more than the other. The two cars meet after two hours. Find the average speeds of the two cars.
Sheet1.Answer:
$70 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}$ and $90 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}$
SOLUTION
Let speed of slower car be $\mathrm{v} \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{hr}$
Distance $=$ Speed $\times$ Time
$2 \mathrm{v}+(\mathrm{v}+20) 2=320$, hence $4 \mathrm{v}+40=320$, and $\mathrm{v}=70$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Will guttation in a humid area occur more in plants with plenty of stomata or in plants with few stomata? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: It will occur more in plants with few stomata because if stomata are few, less water will be lost by transpiration and the rest will have to be lost by guttation.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Which generally decays faster, plants or animal tissue and why?
Sheet1.Answer: Animal tissue in general decays faster because of lack of hard substances like cellulose and lignin which are found in plants and decay more slowly ( please note: not all animals are vertebrates i.e. have bones - which decay slowly).
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Why do benzene or other unsaturated hydrocarbons burn with sooty flame?
Sheet1.Answer:
The carbon content per molecule is relatively high.
Eg. Benzene
$\mathrm{C}: \mathrm{H}=6: 6$ or $1: 1$
Hexane
$\mathrm{C}: \mathrm{H}=6: 14$ or $3: 7$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Benzene nucleus usually reacts with nucleophiles with difficulty but when it contains a type of substituent substitution becomes easier. What type of substitution would make nucleophilic substitution easier?
Sheet1.Answer: Electron withdrawing groups. They reduce the charge density in the ring/on the carbons.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Explain why a nail is made with a sharp tip.
Sheet1.Answer: A sharp tip means that less force is required from the hammer to drive the nail into a piece of wood, since the force per unit area at the tip will be greater for a sharper tip. The shape makes it easier to penetrate the wood.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Explain why it is easier to keep a wooden crate in motion over a rough floor, than it is to start moving it.
Sheet1.Answer:
This is because the co-efficient of static friction is higher than the co-efficient of kinetic friction, which means that the force of friction is greater for the stationary crate and therefore a larger force is required to get it to start moving it than is required to keep it
in motion.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: A fair coin is tossed three times. Find the probability that exactly two heads appear.
Sheet1.Answer:
$3 / 8$
$\mathrm{A}=\{\mathrm{HHT}, \mathrm{HTH}, \mathrm{THH}\}$
Exactly two heads has three equally likely outcomes
The samples space has $2^{3} 2^{3}=8$ equally outcomes
Hence $\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{A})=3 / 8$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: A biased coin has a probability of a head being $1 / 3$. It is tossed three times. Find the probability of having two heads.
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: It is difficult to make out colours in dim light why?
Sheet1.Answer: This is because the cones which are responsible for colour vision function best in bright light.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology, Physics

Sheet1.Question: Prolonged strenuous exercise results in a lowering of blood $\mathrm{pH}$. Why?
Sheet1.Answer: Prolonged strenuous exercise results in the production of lactic acid and a lot of carbon dioxide. The latter dissolves in the water of plasma to form carbonic acid. This together with lactic acid, which is produced anaerobically, causes the lowering of the $\mathrm{pH}$ of blood.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology, Physics

Sheet1.Question: $\mathrm{SO}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ are substances that are used as refrigerants. What do the substances have in common?
Sheet1.Answer: They are both gaseous at room temperature and can easily be compressed to give liquids.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: If the refrigerant of your refrigerator is $\mathrm{SO}_{2}$ and there is a leakage, how could you tell that there is a leakage?
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: The sum emits a great number of charged particles which stream out into space. Why are most of these particles unable to reach the surface of the Earth?
Sheet1.Answer: The charged particles are trapped by the earth's magnetic field.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Is the colour of the sun related to its surface temperature? (Explain your Answer)
Sheet1.Answer: Yes, the colour of the sun is related to the surface temperature by the Stefan - Boltzmann law. The most intense wavelength of electromagnetic radiation emitted from every incandescent body depends on its temperature.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

The chemical equation for the reversible reaction of compounds $A$ and $B$ to give compounds $C$ and $D$ is as follows
$$
\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B} \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{C} \quad+\mathrm{D}
$$
moles of $A$ and 3 moles of $B$ are mixed in a sealed container and the mixture heated until equilibrium is attained at $150^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
Sheet1.Question: If on analysis, only $10 \%$ of $A$ had reacted at equilibrium at $150{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, calculate the mole fraction of $A$ in the mixture and give your answer to two places of decimal.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text:
The chemical equation for the reversible reaction of compounds $A$ and $B$ to give compounds $C$ and $D$ is as follows
$$
\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B} \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{C} \quad+\mathrm{D}
$$
moles of $A$ and 3 moles of $B$ are mixed in a sealed container and the mixture heated until equilibrium is attained at $150^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
Sheet1.Question: Calculate the mole fraction of $B$ in the equilibrium mixture at $200{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ when $25 \%$ of $A$ had reacted and give your answer to two places of decimal
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{A} \quad+\mathrm{B} \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{C} \quad+\quad \mathrm{D}$
$\begin{array}{rlll}\text { Initial } 2.0 & 3.0 & 0 & 0 \\ \text { At Eq. } 1.5 & 2.5 & 0.5 & 0.5 \\ \text { Mole fraction of } B= & (2.5) / 5 & = & 0.50\end{array}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text:
The chemical equation for the reversible reaction of compounds $A$ and $B$ to give compounds $C$ and $D$ is as follows
$$
\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B} \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{C} \quad+\mathrm{D}
$$
moles of $A$ and 3 moles of $B$ are mixed in a sealed container and the mixture heated until equilibrium is attained at $150^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$

Endothermic

(Note at $150^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, \quad \mathrm{Kc}=7.93 * 10^{-3} ; \quad$ at $200^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \mathrm{Kc}=6.67^{*} 10^{-2}$ )

Sheet1.Question: If a $100 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ drum of a pesticide solution of $85 \mathrm{ppm}$ is accidentally left open and the solution dries up to $60 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$, what would be the new pesticide concentration in ppm? Give your answer to one place of decimal?
Sheet1.Answer:
Volume decreases from $100 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ to $60 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$
The concentration will increase by a factor of $100 / 60$ or $5 / 3$
Therefore, the new concentration of the pesticide $=85 * 5 / 3=141.7 \mathrm{ppm}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
$75 \%$ of the reactant concentration of a first order reaction is consumed in 10 minutes.
Determine the half-life of the reaction and give your answer in seconds.
Sheet1.Answer:
It takes 2 half-lives to consume $75 \%(100 \rightarrow 50 \% ; 50 \% \rightarrow 25 \%$ i.e 75 consumed)
Therefore, $\mathrm{t}_{1 / 2}=5$ minutes $=10 / 2$ minutes $=300 \mathrm{~s}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: y varies directly as the cube of $x$. If $y=54$ when $x=3$, find $y$ when $x=4$

Sheet1.Preamble Text:
Propanone reacts with iodine in acidic solution according to the following equation $\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{COCH}_{3 \text { (aq) }}+\mathrm{I}_{2 \text { (aq) }}+\mathrm{H}_{(\mathrm{aq})}^{+} \rightarrow \mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{COCH}_{2} \mathrm{I}+\mathrm{HI}$
Consider the following kinetic results
|Experiment No.| Conc. of $C_{3}H_{6}O$| Conc. of $I_{2}$|Conc. of $H^{+}$ |Rate $moldm^{-3}s^{-1}$|
|--------------|-----------------------|-----------------|----------------|-----------------------|
|Exp't 1       | 0.001                 | 0.01            | 0.01           |$3.1 * 10^{-3}$        |
|Exp't 2       | 0.002                 | 0.01            | 0.01           |$6.3 * 10^{-3}$        |
|Exp't 3       | 0.002                 | 0.02            | 0.01           |$6.3 * 10^{-3}$        |
|Exp't 4       | 0.001                 | 0.01            | 0.02           |$6.3 * 10^{-3}$        |
Sheet1.Question: Use the results to determine the rate law for the reaction
Sheet1.Answer:
$\quad \operatorname{Exp}^{\prime} \mathrm{t}(1)$ and (2): Concentration of propanone is doubled while all other concentrations remain constant. Rate doubles: the reaction is first order with respect to propanone Exp't (1) and (4): (same reasoning) Rate is first order with respect to $\mathrm{H}^{+}$ Exp't (2) and (3): Concentration of $I_{2}$ doubled while all other concentrations remain constant. Rate remains unchanged. Reaction is zero order with respect to $\mathrm{I}_{2}$
Hence Rate Law: $\quad$ Rate $\quad k[\text { Propanone }]^{1}\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]^{1}\left[\mathrm{I}_{2}\right]^{0}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Answer:

Sheet1.Question: The enthalpy of formation of $CO_{2}$ gas is $393 kJmol^{-1}$. If the enthalpy change per mole for the oxidation of CO to $CO_{2}$ by oxygen is $283 kJmol^{-1}$, use Hesss law to calculate the enthalpy of formation per mole of CO gas from graphite.
Sheet1.Answer:
CO + 1/2O2  CO2 (1) - 283 kJ
2CO + O2  2CO2 (2) - 566 kJ
C (s) + O2  CO2 (3) - 393 kJ
2C + 2O2  2CO2 (4) - 786 kJ
Reverse (2) and add to (4)
2C (s) + O2 (g)  2CO(g)
Hf for 2CO = (- 786 + 566) = - 220 kJ
Hf per mole of CO = - 110 kJ
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
Consider the following equilibrium process
$$
3 \mathrm{~A}+\mathrm{B} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{C}+4 \mathrm{D}
$$
7 moles of $\mathrm{A}$ and 2 moles of B were mixed in a flask, at $350 \mathrm{~K}$ and the mixture allowed to come to equilibrium. If at equilibrium 0.64 moles of $\mathrm{C}$ were formed, how many moles of $\mathrm{A}$ had reacted?
Sheet1.Answer:
From the equation: $\mathrm{A} / \mathrm{C}=3 / 2 ; \mathrm{A}=(3 / 2) \mathrm{C}$
$$
\text { Hence moles of } \mathrm{A}=3 / 2 * 0.64=0.96 \text { moles }
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
If the equilibrium reaction:
$3 \mathrm{~A}+\mathrm{B} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{C}+\mathrm{D}, \quad$ all the compounds are gases, how would an increase in the external pressure affect the equilibrium constant $K_{C}$ ?
Sheet1.Answer: The equilibrium will momentarily shift in the backward direction to favour formation of more reactants. Finally equilibrium will be re-established with the same $\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{C}}$. Only a temperature change can change $K_{C}$.

& \text { Total moles of gases } \quad=\quad 2

$$

$\mathrm{Fe}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3} \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{Fe}+3 / 2 \mathrm{O}_{2}$
$112+48$
Loss in mass $\quad=\quad 48$

Sheet1.Question: FeO can also be reduced to metallic iron. In which reduction is the percentage loss greater and by how much? $\quad \mathrm{Fe}=56.0 ; \mathrm{O}=16.0$

$\mathrm{FeO} \rightarrow \mathrm{Fe}+1 / 2 \mathrm{O}_{2}$
$56+16 \quad 56$
Loss in mass $\quad=\quad 16$
$\%$ Lossin mass $\quad=(6 / 72)^{*} 100=22.2$
The percentage loss is greater for $\mathrm{Fe}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$ by $\quad(30-22.2) \quad$ or $\quad 7.8 \%$

Sheet1.Question: The thermal conductivity of steel is $50.2 \mathrm{~W} \mathrm{~m}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$. Find the rate of transfer of thermal energy through an insulated steel rod of length $20.0 \mathrm{~cm}$ and cross-sectional area $4.00 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$ whose ends are in thermal contact with heat baths at $80.0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $30.0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$5.02 W$
$$
\frac{d Q}{d t}=k A \frac{d T}{d l}=50.2 \mathrm{~W} \mathrm{~m}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \times 4.00 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}^{2} \times 50.0 \mathrm{~K} /\left(20.0 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~m}\right)=5.02 \mathrm{~W}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: A vehicle travels $25.0 \mathrm{~km}$ at $60.0 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}$, another $25.0 \mathrm{~km}$ at $40.0 \mathrm{kmh}^{-1}$ and yet another $25.0 \mathrm{~km}$ at $36.0 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}$ without stopping. What is the average speed of the vehicle?
Sheet1.Answer:
$43.2 \mathrm{kmh}^{-1}$
$$
v_{a v g}=\frac{3 v_{1} v_{2} v_{3}}{v_{2} v_{3}+v_{1} v_{3}+v_{1} v_{2}}=\frac{3 \times\left(60.0 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}\right)\left(40.0 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}\right)\left(36.0 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}\right)}{\left(60.0 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}\right)\left(40.0 k m \mathrm{~h}^{-1}\right)+\left(60.0 \mathrm{kmh}^{-1}\right)\left(36.0 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}\right)+\left(36.0 \mathrm{kmh}^{-1}\right)\left(40.0 \mathrm{kmh}^{-1}\right)}= 43.2 \mathrm{kmh}^{-1}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The electron Compton wavelength is $2.43 \mathrm{pm}$. Find the wavelength of radiation scattered at a scattering angle of $90^{\circ}$ in a Compton scattering experiment conducted with photons of wavelength $93.57 \mathrm{pm}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$96.0 \mathrm{pm}$
$$
\lambda=\lambda_{0}+\lambda_{C}(1-\cos \theta)=93.57 p m+2.43 p m \times\left(1-\cos 90^{\circ}\right)=96.0 p m
$$

Sheet1.Question: A $2.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ flask is filled with nitrogen gas at $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ until the pressure is $40.0 \mathrm{kPa}$. Calculate the total pressure after $0.640 \mathrm{~g}$ of oxygen has been added to the flask, and give your answer to two places of decimal. Assume the gas constant, $\mathrm{R}=\quad 8.31 \mathrm{kPadm}^{3} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\left(\right.$ or $\left.\mathrm{JK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\right) ; \quad \mathrm{O} \quad=\quad 16.0$
Sheet1.Answer:
Moles of oxygen $=0.64 / 32=0.02$
Use Ideal gas equation to calculate the partial pressure of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$
$P_{oxygen}$ = (nRT)/V
= $(0.02*8.31*300)/2$
Partial pressure of oxygen = 24.93 kPa
Total pressure = 64.93 kPa
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
A metal $\mathrm{X}$, reacts with excess acid to give hydrogen gas according to the following equation:
$$
\mathrm{X}_{(\mathrm{s})}+2 \mathrm{H}^{+} \rightarrow \mathrm{X}^{2+}+\mathrm{H}_{2(\mathrm{~g})} \text {. }
$$
Calculate the atomic weight of the metal if $1.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of it reacts with excess acid to give $400 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ gas at $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $100 \mathrm{kPa}$. Give your answer to one place of decimal.
$$
\mathrm{R}=8.31 \mathrm{kPadm}^{3} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}
$$
Sheet1.Answer:
Use the Ideal Gas equation; $\mathrm{PV}=\mathrm{nRT} ; \quad \mathrm{n}=(\mathrm{PV}) / \mathrm{RT}$
But $\mathrm{n}=\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{M} ;$ where $\mathrm{M}=$ atomic weight of $\mathrm{X} ; \quad$ Therefore $\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{M} \quad(\mathrm{PV}) /(\mathrm{RT})$; $\mathrm{m}=1.0 \mathrm{~g} ; \quad \mathrm{P}=100 \mathrm{kPa} ; \quad \mathrm{V}=0.400 \mathrm{dm}^{3} ; \quad \mathrm{T}=300 \mathrm{~K}$
$1.0 / \mathrm{M}=(100 * 0.4) /(8.31 * 300)$
$\mathrm{M}=(8.31 * 300) /(100 * 0.4)=62.3$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Give one condition under which the Ideal Gas Equation is no longer obeyed and state the reasons?
Sheet1.Answer:
i) At high pressures. The volume of the gaseous molecules is no longer negligible
ii) At high pressures or low volume there are intermolecular attractive forces which tend to reduce the actual pressure.
iii) At low temperatures. The gases have either condensed to liquids or their volumes are small and the gaseous particles experience the inter-molecular forces.

Sheet1.Question: A series $R L$ circuit with $R=4.0 \Omega$ and $L=0.10 H$ is driven by the alternating voltage $V=V_{0} \sin \omega t$ where $V_{0}=2.0 \mathrm{~V}$ and $\omega=30 \mathrm{rad} \mathrm{s}^{-1}$. Find the potential difference across the inductor.
Sheet1.Answer:
$(1.2 V) \cos \cos \left(30 \mathrm{rad} \mathrm{s}^{-1} t\right)$
$$
V_{L}=\frac{L}{Z} \frac{d V}{d t}=\frac{L V_{0} \omega \cos \omega t}{\sqrt{R^{2}+\omega^{2} L^{2}}}=\frac{\left(0.1 H \times 2 V \times 30 \mathrm{rads}^{-1} \times \cos \omega t\right)}{\sqrt{(4 \Omega)^{2}+\left(30 \mathrm{rads}^{-1} \times 0.1 H\right)^{2}}}=1.2 V \cos (\omega t)
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: $\mathrm{MnO}_{2}$ in a sample may be determined as follows. A mole of the oxide is heated with concentrated $\mathrm{HCl}$ to give a mole of the complex ion $\left[\mathrm{MnCl}_{6}\right]^{2-}$. A mole of the complex ion $\left[\mathrm{MnCl}_{6}\right]^{2-}$ decomposes to give a mole of $\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}, 4 \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$and a mole of chlorine gas. The chlorine gas is bubbled through a KI solution to liberate iodine and the iodine liberated is titrated against a thiosulphate solution. Give the relationship between the $\mathrm{MnO}_{2}$ and thiosulphate as a mole ratio.
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{MnO}_{2} \equiv\left[\mathrm{MnCl}_{6}\right]^{2-} \equiv \mathrm{Cl}_{2} \equiv \mathrm{I}_{2} \equiv \mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}$
Hence, $\left(\mathrm{MnO}_{2}\right) / \mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}=\quad 1 / 2$;
Or $\mathrm{MnO}_{2}: \mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-} \quad=\quad 1: 2$
Note: One mole of $\mathrm{Cl}_{2}$ will liberate 1 mole of $\mathrm{I}_{2} . \mathrm{I}_{2}$ reacts with $\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)^{2-}$ in $1: 2$ ratio.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
A steel vessel contains oxygen and argon at a total pressure of $120 \mathrm{kPa}$ at $30{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. If the partial pressure of oxygen is $40.0 \mathrm{kPa}$, what is the mass ratio of argon to oxygen in the vessel?
$\mathrm{Ar}=40.0 ; \mathrm{O}=16$
Sheet1.Answer:
Partial pressure of argon $=80 \mathrm{kPa}$
For gas 1 in a mixture with gas 2 ;
Partial pressure of gas $1, \quad \mathrm{P}_{1}=\left[\mathrm{n}_{1} /\left(\mathrm{n}_{1}+\mathrm{n}_{2}\right)\right]^{*} \mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{T}}$
Partial pressure of gas $2, \quad \mathrm{P}_{2}=\left[\mathrm{n}_{2} /\left(\mathrm{n}_{1}+\mathrm{n}_{2}\right)\right] * \mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{T}}$
Therefore for argon and oxygen $\frac{P_{A r}}{P_{O 2}}=\frac{80}{40}=\frac{n_{A r}}{n_{O 2}}$
Argon: oxygen mole ratio $=\quad 80: 40$
Argon: oxygen mass ratio $=(80 * 40):(40 * 32)=5: 2$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

mmoles of $\mathrm{Ba}^{2+}$ provided $=0.2 * 100=20.0$ mmoles of $\mathrm{BaSO}_{4}$ to be formed $\quad=\quad 18.0$

Sheet1.Question: Give a suitable reason why reptiles and birds lay shelled eggs and mammals produce eggs without shell?
Sheet1.Answer: In case of reptiles and birds, the eggs need protection from environment and care, whereas, in mammals, the eggs are produced inside the animal body; hence, they need no protection from environment
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Some plants reproduce by releasing pollen into the air which reaches the female plant, and fertilizes and egg. The zygote formed as a result of fertilization grows and eventually becomes another plant. Explain whether plants fit into cell theory or not All parts of the plant lifecycle fit within cell theory.
Sheet1.Answer: The pollen are actually gamete cells, or reproductive cells. Two gamete cells can fuse together during fertilization to create a single cell. The new cell divides to create an entire organism.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Why are Haploid plants preferred over diploids for mutation study?
Sheet1.Answer: Haploids are preferred over diploids for mutation study because mutation is easier in haploid recessive. Most of the induced mutations are recessive and these have to be in double to be expressed phenotypically. Mutations are not seen in heterozygous conditions. So, in haploid plants, recessive mutation express immediately.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Preamble Text: An iron ore which is supposed to contain $\mathrm{Fe}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$ is only $1.2 \%$ rich in the oxide.
Sheet1.Question: Calculate the mass of the oxide in kilograms that can be obtained from 90.0 tonnes of the ore. $$ 1 \text { tonne } \quad=1000 \mathrm{~kg} $$
Sheet1.Answer:
$100 \mathrm{~kg}$ of ore
$1000 \mathrm{~kg}$ of ore
Therefore, 90 tonnes of ore $=$ $\equiv \quad 0.0120 \mathrm{~kg}$ of $\mathrm{Fe}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$
$\equiv \quad 0.120 \mathrm{~kg}$ of $\mathrm{Fe}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$
$10.8 \mathrm{~kg}$ of $\mathrm{Fe}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text: An iron ore which is supposed to contain $\mathrm{Fe}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$ is only $1.2 \%$ rich in the oxide.
Sheet1.Question: Calculate the mass in tonnes of the ore that must be processed to yield $60 \mathrm{~kg}$ of pure $\mathrm{Fe}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\quad 0.012 \mathrm{~kg}$ of pure $\mathrm{Fe}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3} \quad \equiv \quad 100 \mathrm{~kg}$ of ore
$0.12 \mathrm{~kg}$ of pure $\mathrm{Fe}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3} \quad \equiv \quad 1000 \mathrm{~kg}$ or 1 tonne of ore
$60 \mathrm{~kg}$ of pure $\mathrm{Fe}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3} \quad \equiv \quad(60 / 0.12)^{*} 1=500$ tonnes of ore
Mass of the ore to be processed $=500$ tonnes
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Name any three elements in asbestos
Sheet1.Answer:
Any three of $\mathrm{Ca}, \quad \mathrm{Mg}, \quad \mathrm{Si}, \quad \mathrm{O}, \quad \mathrm{H}$
Formula of asbestos: $\quad \mathrm{Ca}_{2} \mathrm{Mg}_{5}(\mathrm{OH})_{4}\left(\mathrm{Si}_{4} \mathrm{O}_{11}\right)_{2}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: A photon beam of wavelength $550 \mathrm{~nm}$ illuminates a black surface at normal incidence. If the photons strike the surface at a rate of $2.0 \times 10^{14} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$ and each photon is absorbed by the surface, find the force the beam exerts on the surface.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: The thermal efficiency of a thermal power plant which generates $200 M W$ of electricity is $30 \%$. How much thermal energy does the plant reject into the atmosphere in a $10 \mathrm{~h}$ period?
Sheet1.Answer:
$16.8 T J$
$$
Q_{R}=0.7 \times 200 M W \times 10 h \times 3600 \mathrm{sh}^{-1} / 0.3=16.8 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{MJ}=16.8 \mathrm{TJ}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Why does it hurt less to break a fall slowly than to break a fall suddenly?
Sheet1.Answer: The prolonged collision requires a lower force for the same change in linear momentum, implying less damage to the body
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Given that $d y / d x=3 x^{2}-2 x$, and $y=6$ when $x=-1$, find an expression for $y$ in terms of $x$.

Sheet1.Question: Why should mono-cropping lead to Soil infertility.
Sheet1.Answer: When one type of crop is planted in the same location year after year, that crop gradually exhausts soil of the particular nutrients that it requires for growth, which results in soil infertility.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Two common mosquito genera, (Anopheles and Culex) can be easily identified by their sitting positions. State the difference in the sitting positions of the two.
Sheet1.Answer: When sitting, the abdomen of Anopheles is always held at an angle to the surface while that of Culex is held parallel to the surface.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Name the two conditions under which a heterozygous individual has a different phenotype from the homozygous individual
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Why is it that, when a vehicle jerks forward suddenly from rest, a passenger feels being pushed back into his seat? What force pushes the passenger back into his seat?
Sheet1.Answer: The passenger tends to remain in his state of rest or uniform motion; As the vehicle accelerates, it exerts a forward force on the passenger, who reacts on the vehicle with an equal and opposite force-there is no force pushing the passenger backward
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Find the least value of the expression $x^{2}-x+1$, and also the corresponding value of $x$.
Sheet1.Answer: LEAST VALUE $=3 / 4$, for $x=1 / 2$. $\left[x^{2}-x+1=(x-1 / 2)^{2}+3 / 4\right.$, hence least value is $3 / 4$ for $\left.x=1 / 2.\right]$
Sheet1.Subject: Mathematics

Sheet1.Question: Walking fern may refer to two species of ferns. Why are they called walking ferns?
Sheet1.Answer: The name "walking fern" is derived from the fact that new plantlets grow wherever the bending leaves of the parent touch the ground, creating a walking effect. This helps in the spread of fern over a large soil surface and thus the name 'walking fern'.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What is the function of the tail plate and tail fibers of bacteriophage?
Sheet1.Answer: The tail plate and the caudal fibres of bacteriophage anchor the phage virion to host cell wall at a specific site
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: A Senior High school student looking at stained nuclei of cells under a microscope, noticed that some nuclei appear uniformly colored, while others appear almost empty, with most of the coloured nuclei clumped together in the middle of the cells. What is happening to the cells?

Sheet1.Question: Why is a d'Arsonval galvanometer critically damped?
Sheet1.Answer: To achieve a steady deflection in the shortest time

Sheet1.Question: Determine the internal energy of an ideal gas containing $5.0 \times 10^{25}$ monatomic molecules in a vessel of volume $2.0 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$ at a pressure of $1.0 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~Pa}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$3.0 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~J}$
$$
U=\frac{3}{2} N k T=\frac{3}{2} p V=\frac{3}{2} \times 1.0 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~Pa} \times 2.0 \mathrm{~m}^{3}=3.0 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~J}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

$\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{CO}_{3} \quad=\quad 106.0$

Sheet1.Question: What is the difference between corrosion and rusting?
Sheet1.Answer:
Corrosion is an oxidation - reduction (Redox) reaction that involves deterioration of metals in general. Rusting refers to corrosion of iron.
(Iron in the presence of both water and oxygen is oxidised to $\mathrm{Fe}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3} \cdot 3 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Why are pioneer species so important in areas of primary succession?
Sheet1.Answer: They are usually a hardy plant, algae or moss that can withstand a hostile environment hence their presence increases the diversity in a region.

Sheet1.Question: What is DNA Sequencing?
Sheet1.Answer: The process of determining the order in which the four nucleotide bases (adenine, guanine, cytosine and thymine) occur within that nucleic acid molecule (It is the process of determining the exact sequence of nucleotides within a DNA molecule).
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: When inhaled Carbon monoxide gets into your blood stream, it can move into your cells and bond tightly with iron, a cofactor of an important enzyme in the production of ATP. Without this enzyme function ATP cannot be formed. Why can't the enzyme function?
Sheet1.Answer: The carbon monoxide binds to the iron cofactor, slightly changing the shape of the enzyme and causing it to no longer accept its substrate, partly because the carbon monoxide molecule is in the way. Hence the enzyme substrate complex cannot be formed. Without the enzyme substrate complex fully forming with the proper substrate, the substrate cannot be transformed
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What is the period of oscillation of a simple pendulum of length $1.5648 \mathrm{~m}$ at a location where surface gravity is $9.78 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}$ when the pendulum oscillates with an angular displacement amplitude of $60^{\circ} ?$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\frac{17 \pi}{20} s=2.67 s$
$$
T=2 \pi \sqrt{1 / g}\left(1+\frac{1}{2^{2}} \frac{\theta}{2}+\cdots\right) \approx 2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{1.5648 m}{9.78 m^{-2}}} \times\left(1+\frac{1}{2^{2}} \times 30^{\circ}\right)=\frac{17 \pi}{20} s=2.67 \mathrm{~s}
$$
The small-amplitude period is only about $0.8 \pi \mathrm{s}$.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Calculate the number of molecules expected to be found in $64.0 \mathrm{~g}$ of a sample of oxygen gas. Give your answer in the scientific form to three places of decimal. Use Avogadro's number of three significant figures
Sheet1.Answer:
Moles of oxygen in $64 \mathrm{~g}$ of the gas $\quad=\quad 64 / 32=2.0$
Assume Avogadro's number
$=6.02 * 10^{23}$
Number of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ molecules in 2.0 moles $\quad=\quad 1.204 * 10^{24}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
Calculate the charge in coulombs required for the electrolysis of $1.70 \mathrm{~g}$ of alumina or aluminum oxide.
Use a Faraday constant corrected to three significant figures. You may give your answer in the scientific form to two places of decimal. $\mathrm{Al}=27.0 ; \mathrm{O}=16.0$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}=54+48=102$
$\mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}+6 \mathrm{~F} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{Al}+3 / 2 \mathrm{O}_{2}$
Therefore, $102.0 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3} \equiv 6$ Faraday of charge
$1.70 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3} \quad=\quad(1.7 / 102)^{*} 6$ Faraday of charge $\quad=\quad 0.10$ Faraday
But 1 Faraday $=\quad 96500$ coulombs (three significant numbers)
Therefore, charge needed for electrolysis of $1.70 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3} \quad=\quad 9.65^{*} 10^{3}$ coulombs
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: The enthalpy of formation of a compound is given as $-23.0 \mathrm{kcalmol}^{-1}$. What is this value in $\mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$ ? Use a conversion rate that involves only two significant figures and give your answer to one place of decimal.

Sheet1.Question: Why was the rediscovery of Mendel's experiments important for the development of molecular biology?
Sheet1.Answer:
Until Mendel experimented with pea plants, it was never clear how heredity was achieved.
Though the gross mechanisms involved were always known, the details were never clear.
It was Mendel's laws of inheritance that suggested that there were distinct biochemical particles involved in heredity.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Why are pyramids of energy always upright?
Sheet1.Answer: Pyramids of energy are always upright since energy decreases at each trophic level.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Why are Plant cells able to thrive in hypotonic solutions?
Sheet1.Answer: Because their cell walls keep them from bursting due to excessive water intake.

Sheet1.Question:
Sodium metal reacts with chlorine according to the equation;
$2 \mathrm{Na}+\mathrm{Cl}_{2} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{NaCl}$
Calculate the mass of $\mathrm{NaCl}$ to be formed from a reaction of $23.0 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{Na}$ and $5.6 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{Cl}_{2}$ at STP.
$$
\mathrm{Na}=23.0 ; \mathrm{Cl}=\text { 35.5; Molar volume of gas at STP }=\quad 22.4 \mathrm{dm}^{3} \text {. }
$$
Give your answer to two places of decimal
Sheet1.Answer:
$2 \mathrm{Na}+\mathrm{Cl}_{2} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{NaCl}$
$2 * 23 \quad 22.4 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$
$5.6 \mathrm{dm}^{3} \mathrm{Cl}_{2}$ at STP $=1 / 4$ mole of $\mathrm{Cl}_{2}$
Hence, $1 / 4 \mathrm{~mol}$ of $\mathrm{Cl}_{2}$ will react with $1 / 2 \mathrm{~mol}$ of $\mathrm{Na}$ to give $1 / 2 \mathrm{molNaCl}$
$$
\text { Mass of } \mathrm{NaCl}=\quad 1 / 2(23.0+35.5) \quad=\quad 58.5 / 2=\quad 29.25 \mathrm{~g}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: A $5 n C$ particle has instantaneous velocity $v=2 \hat{i} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$ at a point where a constant electric field $E=3 \hat{j} V m^{-1}$ and a constant magnetic field $B=2 \hat{j} T$ exist. Find the electromagnetic force on the particle.
Sheet1.Answer:
$(15 \hat{j}+20 \hat{k}) n N$
$$
F=q(E+v \times B)=5 n C \times\left(3 \hat{j} V m^{-1}+2 \hat{i} m s^{-1} \times 2 \hat{j} T\right)=(15 \hat{j}+20 \hat{k}) n N
$$

$$

Sheet1.Question: Carbon - oxygen double bond is stronger than carbon - carbon double bond, why?
Sheet1.Answer: The shorter a covalent bond, the stronger it is. Oxygen atom has a smaller covalent radius than carbon. Hence carbon - oxygen double bond is shorter than carbon - carbon double bond.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Explain how bond energies can be used to estimate the enthalpy of a reaction.
Sheet1.Answer: The enthalpy of a reaction is equal to the sum of bond energies of bonds broken minus the sum of bond energies of bonds formed. Energy is required to break bonds and energy is given off when a bond is formed.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text:
Consider the following half-cells including their respective electrode potentials:
$\mathrm{MnO4-}, \mathrm{Mn} 2+, \mathrm{H}+/ \mathrm{Pt} \quad 1.49 \mathrm{~V} ; \quad \mathrm{Hg} 2+, \mathrm{Hg} / \mathrm{Pt} \quad 0.850 \mathrm{~V}$.
Sheet1.Question: Give the balanced equation for the oxidation of $\mathrm{Hg}$ by $\mathrm{MnO}$ - ions in acidified solution.
Sheet1.Answer:
Oxidation: $\mathrm{Hg} \quad-\quad 2 \mathrm{e} \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{Hg} 2+\ldots .$. (1)
Reduction: $\mathrm{MnO4-}+5 \mathrm{e}+8 \mathrm{H}+\quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{Mn} 2++4 \mathrm{H} 2 \mathrm{O} \ldots$ (2)
Multiply (1) by 5 and (2) by 2 and add.
Balanced equation:
$5 \mathrm{Hg}+2 \mathrm{MnO} 4-+16 \mathrm{H}+\rightarrow 2 \mathrm{Hg} 2++2 \mathrm{Mn} 2++\mathrm{H} 2 \mathrm{O}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text:
Consider the following half-cells including their respective electrode potentials:
$\mathrm{MnO4-}, \mathrm{Mn} 2+, \mathrm{H}+/ \mathrm{Pt} \quad 1.49 \mathrm{~V} ; \quad \mathrm{Hg} 2+, \mathrm{Hg} / \mathrm{Pt} \quad 0.850 \mathrm{~V}$.
Sheet1.Question: Will the reaction in principle be thermodynamically spontaneous? Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer:
Yes, the reaction will be thermodynamically favourable.
The emf of a cell whose reaction represents the redox reaction will be positive.
$\mathrm{Emf}=(1.49-0.850) \mathrm{V}=\quad 0.640 \mathrm{~V}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text:
Consider the following half-cells including their respective electrode potentials:
$\mathrm{MnO4-}, \mathrm{Mn} 2+, \mathrm{H}+/ \mathrm{Pt} \quad 1.49 \mathrm{~V} ; \quad \mathrm{Hg} 2+, \mathrm{Hg} / \mathrm{Pt} \quad 0.850 \mathrm{~V}$.
Sheet1.Question: How many types of electrochemical cells are available? Name them and explain the difference.
Sheet1.Answer: Two types; Voltaic cells and Electrolytic cells. Voltaic cells convert chemical energy into electrical energy whereas electrolytic cells convert electrical energy into chemical energy.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question: In principle, ethanal and ethene can be hydrogenated separately to give ethanol and ethane respectively. Use the following enthalpies of formation all in kJmol-1 to determine which reaction is more thermodynamically favourable. $\mathrm{C}_{2}\mathrm{H}_{4}(\mathrm{~g}) \quad 53.0 ; \quad \mathrm{CH}_{3}\mathrm{OH}(\mathrm{I}) \quad-239 ; \quad \mathrm{HCHO}(\mathrm{g}) \quad-116 ; \quad \mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{H}_{6}$ $-85.0$
Sheet1.Answer:
(1) $\mathrm{C}_{2}\mathrm{H}_{4}(\mathrm{~g})+\mathrm{H}_{2}(\mathrm{~g}) \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{C}_{2}\mathrm{H}_{6}(\mathrm{~g})$
$\Delta \mathrm{H}($ reaction $)=-85.0-(53.0)=-138 \mathrm{~kJ}$
(2) $\mathrm{HCHO}(\mathrm{g})+\mathrm{H}_{2}(\mathrm{~g}) \rightarrow \mathrm{CH}_{3}\mathrm{OH}(\mathrm{l})$
$\Delta \mathrm{H}($ reaction $)=-239-(-116)=-123 \mathrm{~kJ}$
From the $\Delta \mathrm{H}^{\prime} \mathrm{s}$, reduction of $\mathrm{C}_{2}\mathrm{H}_{4}$ is more thermodynamically favourable.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
Calculate the mass of silver bromide in grams that can be obtained by adding $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of 0.0800 mol$dm^{-3}$ of $AgNO_{3}$ solution to $50.0 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of 0.120 mol$dm^{-3}$ $\mathrm{NaBr}$ solution.
$\mathrm{Ag}=107 ; \mathrm{Br}=80.0$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{AgNO}_{3}+\mathrm{NaBr} \rightarrow \mathrm{AgBr}+\quad \mathrm{NaNO} 3$
$\mathrm{mmol}$ of Ag+ available $=50.0 * 0.120=6.00$
$\mathrm{mmol}$ of $\mathrm{Br}$ - available $=100 * 0.0800=8.00$
$\mathrm{mmol}$ of $\mathrm{AgBr}$ expected $=\quad 6.00$
Mass of $\mathrm{AgBr}=187 * 6.00 * 10-3 \mathrm{~g}=1.12 \mathrm{~g}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
An ore of iron, haematite is $4.80 \%$ rich in $Fe_{2}O_{3}$. Calculate the mass of metallic iron in kg that can be obtained by extraction of 10.0 tonnes of the ore.
$\mathrm{Fe}=56.0 ; \quad 0 \quad=16.0$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{Fe}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{Fe}$
160 2(56)
Mass of Fe2O3 in 10.0 tonnes of the ore that is $4.80 \%$ rich $=480 \mathrm{~kg}$
Mass of Fe to be obtained $=\quad 112 / 160 * 480 \mathrm{~kg}=336 \mathrm{~kg}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
Two ores of iron are siderite, $FeCO_{3}$ and iron pyrites, $FeS_{2}$. All things being equal, which ore will yield more iron per unit mass of the ore.
$\mathrm{Fe}=56.0 ; \mathrm{S}=32.0 ; \mathrm{O}=16.0 ; \mathrm{C}=12.0$
Sheet1.Answer:
Iron pyrites $(FeS_{2})$ $=56.0+64.0=120$
Siderite $(\mathrm{FeCO}_{3})=56.0+60.0=116$
56/116 > 56/120
Therefore, siderite contains more iron per unit mass of the ore than iron pyrites.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
The displacement reaction involving molecules $\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{Br}{\text {and }} \mathrm{OH}^{-}$to give $\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{OH}$ and $\mathrm{Br}^{-}$goes through the following steps:
(i) $\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{Br} \quad \rightarrow \mathrm{A}^{+}+\mathrm{Br}^{-} \ldots$... slow
(ii) $\mathrm{A}^{+}+\mathrm{OH}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{A}-\mathrm{OH} \ldots \ldots \ldots$ fast

Sheet1.Answer:
Rate $=\mathrm{k}[\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{Br}]^{1}\left[\mathrm{OH}^{-}\right]^{0}$; The rate determining step does not involve the $\mathrm{OH}^{-}$
OR Rate $=\mathrm{k}[\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{Br}]$ i.e. the slow step does not depend on the concentration of $\mathrm{OH}^{-}$

Sheet1.Question: How will the pressure of a gas vary with its amount in moles at constant temperature and volume? Use the Kinetic Molecular Theory to explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: The pressure of the gas will increase as the amount in moles increases. As the amount increases the number of molecules increases and the number of collisions with the surface of the container increases. The collisions create the pressure.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Answer:
Bonds to be broken: $\quad 12 \mathrm{~N}-\mathrm{H}+5 \mathrm{O}_{2}=4632+5 * 494=7102$ $\Delta \mathrm{H}$ reaction $=-7936+7102=-834 \mathrm{~kJ}$ or -

Sheet1.Question: Explain why $C \equiv N$ has a higher bond energy than $C \equiv C$.
Sheet1.Answer:
Either: Generally, the shorter a covalent bond the stronger the bond. Covalent or atomic radius of $\mathrm{N}$ is shorter than that of $\mathrm{C}$.
OR: Since the nitrogen atom is smaller than the carbon atom, the orbitals used by nitrogen for bonding are more compact, leading to more effective overlap with the orbitals of carbon.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text:
A steel cylinder contains $8.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of argon gas, $16.0 \mathrm{~g}$ of oxygen gas and $22.0 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ at a
total pressure of $150 \mathrm{kPa} . \quad \mathrm{Ar}=40.0 ; \mathrm{O}_{2}=32.0 ; \mathrm{CO}_{2}=44.0$
Sheet1.Question: Calculate the volume of the gas at $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Gas constant $\mathrm{R}=8.31 \mathrm{JK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$
Sheet1.Answer:
Moles of argon $=(8.00 / 40.0)=0.200$
Moles of oxygen $=(16.0 / 32.0)=0.500$
Moles of $\mathrm{CO}_{2} \quad=\quad(22.0 / 44)=0.500$
Using the Ideal gas equation: $\quad \mathrm{V}=(\mathrm{nRT} / \mathrm{P})$
$\mathrm{V}=(1.20 * 8.31 * 300) / 150 \quad=19.9 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text:

Sheet1.Question: Calculate the combined partial pressure of oxygen and $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
Total mole fraction of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{CO}_{2} \quad=\quad 1.00 / 1.20$

Sheet1.Question: Calculate the $\mathrm{pH}$ of 0.100 moldm are $2.15,7.20$ and 12.4 respectively. State any assumption(s) made.
Sheet1.Answer:

$$
\mathrm{pH}=1 / 2 \mathrm{pKa}-1 / 2 \log \mathrm{Ca}=7.20 / 2+0.500=4.10
$$

Sheet1.Question: Calculate the $\mathrm{pH}$ of a solution obtained by mixing $400 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $0.125 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$ ammonia solution and $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of 0.500 moldm$^{-3} \mathrm{HCl}$ solution. $\quad \mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{b}}$ of $\mathrm{NH}_{3}=4.76$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{mmol}$ of $\mathrm{NH}_{3}=400 * 0.125=50.0$
$\mathrm{mmol}$ of $\mathrm{HCl}=100 * 0.500=50.0$
Hence $500 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{Cl}$ solution is produced
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Concentration of } \mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{Cl}=\quad 50.0 / 500=0.100 \text { moldm }^{-3} \\
& \mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a}} \text { of } \mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}=\quad 14.0-\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{b}} \text { of } \mathrm{NH}_{3}=\quad 9.24 \\
& \mathrm{pH}=1 / 2 \mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a}}-1 / 2 \log \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{a}}=\quad 9.24 / 2+0.500=5.12
\end{aligned}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Predict if the 0.100 moldm ${ }^{-3}$ solution of $\mathrm{HPO}_{4}{ }_{4}{ }^{2-}$ will be acidic or basic. The $3 \mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a}}$ values of $\mathrm{H}_{3} \mathrm{PO}_{4}$ are $2.15,7.20$ and 12.3. Explain how arrived at your answer.
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a}}$ of $\mathrm{HPO}_{4}{ }^{2-}=12.3$
As a base, its conjugate acid $=\quad \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{PO}_{4}{ }^{-}$
$\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a}}$ of $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{PO}_{4}^{-} \quad=\quad 7.30$
$\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{b}}$ of conjugate base of $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{PO}_{4}{ }^{-}$being $\mathrm{HPO}_{4}{ }^{2-}=14.0-7.30=6.70$
Since $\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{b}}(6.70)$ is larger than $\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a}}(12.3)$, the $\mathrm{HPO}_{4}{ }^{2-}$ is a stronger base than it is an acid. OR Its solution is likely to be basic.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text:
In the Haber Process for the manufacture of ammonia gas, nitrogen gas is made to react with hydrogen. The balanced equation is as follows:
$$
\mathrm{N}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}+3 \mathrm{H}_{2(\mathrm{~g})} \rightarrow \quad 2 \mathrm{NH}_{3(\mathrm{~g})}
$$
Sheet1.Question: Use the following bond energies, all in $\mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$ to estimate enthalpy of the given reaction. $$ \mathrm{H}-\mathrm{H} \quad 432 ; \quad \mathrm{N} \equiv \mathrm{N} \quad 942 ; \quad \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{H} \quad 386 . $$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{N}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}+3 \mathrm{H}_{2(\mathrm{~g})} \rightarrow \quad 2 \mathrm{NH}_{3(\mathrm{~g})}$
Bonds broken $=\quad \mathrm{N} \equiv \mathrm{N}+3 * \mathrm{H}-\mathrm{H} ; \quad$ Energy required $=942+$
$3 * 432=+2238$
Bonds formed $=6^{*} \mathrm{~N}-\mathrm{H} ; \quad$ Energy given out $=-6 * 386=$
$-2316$
$\Delta \mathrm{H}($ reaction $)=2238-2316=-78.0 \mathrm{~kJ}$
$\left(\mathrm{OR} \quad=\quad-39 \mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}\right.$ of $\left.\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text:
In the Haber Process for the manufacture of ammonia gas, nitrogen gas is made to react with hydrogen. The balanced equation is as follows:
$$
\mathrm{N}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}+3 \mathrm{H}_{2(\mathrm{~g})} \rightarrow \quad 2 \mathrm{NH}_{3(\mathrm{~g})}
$$
Sheet1.Question: The standard enthalpy of formation of ammonia gas by calorimetry is $-46.0 \mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$. The enthalpy of formation per mole using bond energies is $-39.0 \mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$. Why are the values different and which one is more acceptable?
Sheet1.Answer: The bond energy (concept) is only an approximation. The $\Delta \mathrm{H}$ of formation which is experimentally determined is more accurate.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Explain in terms of bond energies why the polymerisation of ethene to give polyethene is expected to be exothermic.
Sheet1.Answer: For each double bond that is broken, two new $\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{C}$ single bonds are formed. Two single bonds are more stable than one $\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{C}$ double bond.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Find the magnetization of a sphere of radius $0.200 \mathrm{~m}$ uniformly magnetized in the $z$-direction with total magnetic dipole moment of magnitude $3.50 \mathrm{~A} \mathrm{~m}^{2}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$104 \mathrm{Am}^{-1}$ in the z-direction
$$
M=\mu / V=3.50 \hat{k} A m^{2} \times 3 /\left[4 \pi \times\left(0.200 m^{3}\right]=104 \hat{k} A m^{-1}\right.
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Find the net charge on a conducting sphere of radius $0.40 \mathrm{~m}$ whose electric potential is $-18 \mathrm{~V}$.

$$

v=\frac{u f}{u-f}=\frac{(0.25 m)(-0.40 m)}{0.25 m-(-0.40 m)}=-0.15 m

Sheet1.Question:
Determine from the following half-cells and their corresponding electrode potentials whether acidified $\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}$solution can oxidise metallic mercury, $\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}, \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}, \mathrm{H}^{+} / \mathrm{Pt} \quad 1.49 \mathrm{~V}$;
$\mathrm{Hg}^{2+} / \mathrm{Hg} \quad 0.85 \mathrm{~V}$. Give the balanced equation for the cell and its initial emf.
Sheet1.Answer:
The mercury can be oxidised by acidified $\mathrm{KMnO}_{4}$
Oxidation: $\mathrm{Hg}-2 \mathrm{e} \rightarrow \mathrm{Hg}^{2+}-0.85 \mathrm{~V}$
Reduction: $\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+5 \mathrm{e}+8 \mathrm{H}^{+} \rightarrow \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}+\quad 4 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}+1.49 \mathrm{~V}$
Multiply (1) by 5 and (2) by 2 and add.
$5 \mathrm{Hg}+2 \mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+16 \mathrm{H}^{+} \rightarrow \quad 5 \mathrm{Hg}^{2+}+\quad 2 \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}+\quad 8 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$
$$
\text { Initial emf }=\quad 1.49-0.85=+0.64 \mathrm{~V}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: State if $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}$, hydrogen peroxide, can reduce the $\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}$ion in acidified medium. The half-cell $H_{2}O_{2}, H^{+}/Pt$ has a reduction potential of 1.78 V while $MnO_{4}^{-}, Mn^{2+}, H^{+}/Pt$ has a reduction potential of $1.49 \mathrm{~V}$. Explain your answer.
Sheet1.Answer: It cannot reduce $\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}$to $\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$. From the two electrode potentials, $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}$ will rather oxidise $\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$ to $\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}$because $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}$ has a higher potential to be reduced.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Consider the half-cell $\mathrm{H}^{+} / \mathrm{O}_{3}, \mathrm{O}_{2} / \mathrm{Pt}$ with its electrode potential 2.07 V. Explain if ozone is a better or a poorer oxidising agent than the $\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}$in acid medium. The half-cell $\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}, \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$, $\mathrm{H}^{+} / \mathrm{Pt}$ has the electrode potential $1.49 \mathrm{~V}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
For a species to act as an oxidising agent, it must have great potential to be reduced.
The ozone electrode has a greater reduction electrode potential. Hence ozone is a better oxidising agent.

Isomers:
$$
\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{C}\left(\mathrm{CH}_{3}\right)=\mathrm{CH}_{2} \mathrm{CH}_{2} \mathrm{CH}_{3} \quad \text { = 2-methyl-2-pentene or 2-methylpent-2- }
$$ ene
$$
\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{CH}\left(\mathrm{CH}_{3}\right) \mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CHCH}_{3}=\text { 4-methyl-2-pentene or 4-methylpent- }
$$ 2-ene
$$
\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{CH}\left(\mathrm{CH}_{3}\right) \mathrm{CH}_{2} \mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}_{2}=\text { 4-methyl-1-pentene or 4-methylpent-1- }
$$ ene

$\mathrm{BaCrO}_{4}=137+52.0+64.0=253$

Sheet1.Question: A metal $\mathrm{M}$ forms a hydroxide, $\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{OH})_{2}$ whose solubility product is $1.08^{*} 10^{-10}$. Calculate the concentration of $\mathrm{M}^{2+}$ in ppm of a saturated solution of the hydroxide. $\quad \mathrm{M}=$ 201
Sheet1.Answer:
Solubility of $\left.\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{OH})_{2}=\sqrt[3]{ } 27^{*} 10^{-12}\right]=3.00^{*} 10^{-4} \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$
Solubility of $\mathrm{M}^{2+}$ in $\mathrm{gdm}^{-3}=201 * 3.00 * 10^{-4}=603 * 10^{-4}$
Solubility of $\mathrm{M}^{2+}$ in $\mathrm{mgdm}^{-3}=60.3$
Hence concentration of $\mathrm{M}^{2+}$ in ppm $=60.3$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Answer:
Solubility of $\mathrm{PbSO}_{4}$ in moldm$^{-3}=\sqrt{ }\left(16.0 * 10^{-8}\right)=4.00^{*} 10^{-4}$ Solubility of $\mathrm{SO}_{4}^{2-}$ in $\mathrm{gdm}^{-3}=$
$(32.0+64.0) * 4.00 * 10^{-4}=$
$384 * 10^{-4}$
Concentration of $\mathrm{SO}_{4}{ }^{2-}$ in $\mathrm{mgdm}^{-3}=38.4$
Concentration of $\mathrm{SO}_{4}{ }^{2-}$ in ppm $=38.4$

Sheet1.Question: A buffer is prepared by adding $50.0 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $0.100 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3} \mathrm{KOH}$ solution to $150 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of 0.100 moldm ${ }^{-3}$ ethanoic acid solution. Calculate the $\mathrm{pH}$ of the resulting buffer. $\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a}}$ of ethanoic acid is 4.76. You may give your answer as a logarithm expression.
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{mmol}$ of $\mathrm{KOH}$ provided $=50.0 * 0.100=5.00$
mmol of ethanoic acid initially present $=150 * 0.100=15.0$
$\mathrm{mmol}$ of ethanoate formed $=5.00$
$\mathrm{mmol}$ of ethanoic acid left $=10.0$
Volume of the buffer solution is the same for both species.
Hence $\mathrm{pH}=\mathrm{pKa}+\quad \log i=4.76+\log \frac{50.0}{100}$
$$
=\quad 4.76+\log 0.500 \quad \text { or } \quad 4.76-\log 2.00
$$

Sheet1.Question: The rate constant of a first order reaction is $1.00 * 10^{-3} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$. How long would it take for the concentration of the reactant to decrease to $25 \%$ of its starting value?
Sheet1.Answer:
For a first order reaction; $\mathrm{t}_{1 / 2}=0.693 / \mathrm{k}$
$$
=0.693 /\left(1.00 * 10^{-3}\right)=6.93 * 10^{2} \mathrm{~s}
$$
It takes 2 half-lives for the reactant concentration to decrease to $25 \%$
$$
\text { Hence time }=\quad 2 * 6.93 * 10^{2}=\quad 13.86^{*} 10^{2} \mathrm{~s}=\quad 1386 \mathrm{~s} \text { or } 23 \text { min } 6 \mathrm{~s}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: An experiment was performed to determine the order of a chemical reaction which could be a first order or second order reaction. Concentrations of the only reactant A were determined at various time intervals. Explain how the experimenter determined what order it was.
Sheet1.Answer:
By graphical method.
For $1^{\text {st }}$ order a plot of $\quad \log _{10}[A]$ vs $t \quad$ would give a straight line.
For $2^{\text {nd }}$ order $\quad$ a plot of $\quad 1 /[A]$ vs $t \quad$ would give a straight line.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Suppose the order of the reaction was found graphically to be first order, how could the rate constant $\mathrm{k}$ be determined from the graph?
Sheet1.Answer: When $\log _{10}[A]$ is plotted against $t$, a straight line with negative gradient $-\mathrm{m}$ is obtained. This is equal to $-\mathrm{k} / 2.303$.i.e. $-\mathrm{m}=-\mathrm{k} / 2.303 ; \quad$ Hence $\mathrm{k}=$ $2.303 * \mathrm{~m}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: The solubility product of a metal hydroxide $\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{OH})_{2}$ is $1.6 \times 10^{-10}$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. If a solution of $\mathrm{OH}^{-}$ions is being added to a 0.100 moldm $^{-3}$ solution of $\mathrm{M}^{2+}$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, above what concentration of $\mathrm{OH}^{-}$will $\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{OH})_{2}$ start precipitating?
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{OH})_{2}(\mathrm{~s}) \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{M}^{2+}(\mathrm{aq}) \quad+\quad 2 \mathrm{OH}^{-}$
0.100 moldm $^{-3} \quad$ y moldm ${ }^{-3}$
$\mathrm{Ksp}=\left[\mathrm{M}^{2+}\right]\left[2 \mathrm{OH}^{-}\right]^{2} \quad=\quad\left[1.00^{*} 10^{-1}\right][\mathrm{y}]^{2}$ $1.60 \times 10^{-10}=1.00 * 10^{-1} * \mathrm{y}^{2} ; \quad \mathrm{y}^{2}=1.60 \times 10^{-9}$
Hence the precipitate will start forming when $\mathrm{OH}^{-}$concentration, y is just above $4.00 \mathrm{x}$ $10^{-5} \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$

Sheet1.Question: What is the difference between a colloidal solution and ordinary solution?

Sheet1.Question: How does the structure of alveoli maximize gaseous exchange?
Sheet1.Answer: The sac-like structure of the alveoli increases their surface area. In addition, the alveoli are made of thin-walled cells. These features allow gases to easily diffuse across the cells.

Sheet1.Question:
A buffer is needed for a medium whose $\mathrm{pH}$ has to be maintained at 8.50 . Which of the two buffers will you use and why?
$\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ and $\mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{Cl}$ or Ethanoic acid and sodium ethanoate.
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ and $\mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{Cl}$ will be used.
Reason: The $\mathrm{pH}$ of the medium is in the basic region and we need a buffer whose buffering $\mathrm{pH}$ range $\left(\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a} \text { (acid) }} \pm 1\right)$ is in the basic region. $\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a}}$ of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$is greater than 7.00 while $\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a}}$ of $\mathrm{AcOH}$ is less than 7.00
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Calculate the $\mathrm{pH}$ of a buffer prepared by adding $50.0 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $0.100 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3} \mathrm{HCl}$ solution to $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of 0.100 moldm $^{-3}$ ammonia solution. $\quad \mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{b}}$ of ammonia is 4.75.
Sheet1.Answer:
$50.0 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $0.100 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3} \mathrm{HCl}$ will neutralise exactly half of the ammonia solution to give $\mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{Cl}$.
Therefore, in solution,
$\left[\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right]=$
$\left[\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}\right]$
$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a}} \text { of } \mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+} & =14.0-4.75=9.25 \\
\therefore \mathrm{pH} & =\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a}}+\quad \log _{10}\left[\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right] /\left[\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}\right]=\quad 9.25
\end{array}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Explain how a buffer of $\mathrm{NH}_{3}-\mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{Cl}$ will operate to keep the $\mathrm{pH}$ of a medium approximately constant when a small quantity of sodium hydroxide solution is added to the medium.
Sheet1.Answer: When $\mathrm{NaOH}$ is added, the small amount of $\mathrm{OH}^{-}$reacts with a small quantity of the $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$, and because $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$is present in a large quantity, the $\left[\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right] /\left[\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}\right]$ratio is not significantly altered.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What is Photobiology?
Sheet1.Answer: The study of the effects of Light (ultraviolet, visible and infrared radiation) on living organisms. (It includes topics such as photosynthesis, vision, bioluminescence, circadian rhythms and photodynamic therapy).

Sheet1.Question:
Use the following enthalpies of formation all in $\mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$ to determine if the dissolution of barium trioxonitrate $(\mathrm{V})$ in water is endothermic or exothermic. Determine the heat evolved or absorbed.
$\mathrm{Ba}^{2+}{ }_{(\mathrm{aq})}-538 ; \quad \mathrm{Ba}\left(\mathrm{NO}_{3}\right)_{2(\mathrm{~s})}-952 ; \quad \mathrm{NO}_{3}{ }^{-}(\mathrm{aq}) \quad-205$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{Ba}\left(\mathrm{NO}_{3}\right)_{2(\mathrm{~s})}+\quad$ water $\rightarrow \quad \mathrm{Ba}^{2+}{ }_{(\mathrm{aq})}+\quad 2 \mathrm{NO}_{3^{-}(\mathrm{aq})}$
$$
\Delta \mathrm{H} \text { (solution) }=(-538-2 * 205)-(-952)=(-538-410)+
$$
952
$$
=\quad-948+952=+4.00 \mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}
$$
The process is Endothermic and the heat absorbed is $4.00 \mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
Use the following enthalpies of formation all in $\mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$ to determine if the dissolution of solid $\mathrm{CaCl}_{2}$ in water is an endothermic or exothermic process. Determine the amount of heat involved.
$\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}{ }_{(\mathrm{aq})} \quad-543 ; \quad \mathrm{Cl}_{(\mathrm{aq})}^{-167 ;} \quad \mathrm{CaCl}_{2(\mathrm{~s})} \quad-796$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{CaCl}_{2(\mathrm{~s})}+$ water $\rightarrow \quad \mathrm{Ca}^{2+}{ }_{(\mathrm{aq})}+\mathrm{Cl}_{(\mathrm{aq})}^{-}$
$\Delta \mathrm{H}$ (solution) $=(-543+-2 * 167)-(-796)=-81.0 \mathrm{~kJ}$
The process is Exothermic. Heat evolved $=-81.0 \mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Why should the value for gross productivity of the primary producers be the same as the value for total heat and respiration?
Sheet1.Answer: According to the first law of thermodynamics, energy can neither be created nor destroyed. Eventually, all energy consumed by living systems is lost as heat or used for respiration, and the total energy output of the system must be equal to the energy that went into it
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Which features of red blood cells allow for rapid diffusion of oxygen and carbon dioxide across the plasma membrane?
Sheet1.Answer: The small size and large surface area

Sheet1.Question: A geneticist found genetic marker and a disease gene to be closely linked. What does this mean?
Sheet1.Answer: The genetic marker and the disease gene are in close physical proximity and tend to be inherited together

Sheet1.Question: Hydrogen gas can be prepared in the laboratory by a reaction of metallic zinc with hydrochloric acid. Calculate the volume of the gas that can be collected in a reaction of 6.50 g of zinc with excess $\mathrm{HCl}$ at a pressure of $100 \mathrm{kPa}$ and a temperature of $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Assume hydrogen gas behaves as an ideal gas under the conditions of the reaction; $\mathrm{Zn}=65.0 ; \mathrm{R}=$ $8.31 \mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$; Molar volume of an ideal gas at $\mathrm{STP}=22.4 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\quad \mathrm{Zn}_{(\mathrm{s})}+2 \mathrm{HCl}_{(\mathrm{aq})} \rightarrow \mathrm{ZnCl}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}+\mathrm{H}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}$
At STP $\quad 65.0 \mathrm{~g}$
$1.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ or
$22.4 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$
$6.50 \mathrm{~g}$
$0.100 \mathrm{~mol}$ or $2.24 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$
EITHER: Use Ideal Gas Equation:
Moles of $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ gas $\mathrm{n}$, expected, $\quad=0.100 ; \quad \mathrm{T}=300 \mathrm{~K}$
$\mathrm{V}=\frac{n R T}{P}=\frac{0.100 \times 8.31 \times 300}{100}=\mathbf{2 . 4 9} \mathbf{d m}^{3}$
OR Use Charles law to calculate volume at $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$;
$\mathrm{V}_{1}=2.24 \mathrm{dm}^{3}, \quad \mathrm{~T}_{1}=273 \mathrm{~K} ; \quad \mathrm{T}_{2}=300 \mathrm{~K}$. 
$$
\mathrm{V}_{2}=\left(\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}} \times \mathrm{V}_{1}=\frac{300 \times 2.24}{273}=\mathbf{2 . 4 6} \mathbf{d m}^{3}\right.
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
Glucose, with molecular formula $\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{12} \mathrm{O}_{6}$ in certain living cells reacts with oxygen to give $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ gas, $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ and energy. Calculate the volume of oxygen needed at $100 \mathrm{kPa}$ and $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to react with $90.0 \mathrm{~g}$ of glucose.
$\mathrm{R}=8.31 \mathrm{Jmol}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$; Glucose $=180$. Assume oxygen behaves as an ideal gas under the conditions of the reaction.
Sheet1.Answer:
$\quad \mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{12} \mathrm{O}_{6}+6 \mathrm{O}_{2} \rightarrow 6 \mathrm{CO}_{2}+6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$
Moles of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ required to react with 90.0 of Glucose $\equiv \frac{90.0}{180} \times 6$
$=\quad 3.00 \mathrm{~mol}$
EITHER Use the Ideal Gas equation
$\mathrm{V}=\frac{n R T}{P}=\frac{3.00 \times 8.31 \times 300}{100}=\mathbf{7 4 . 8} \mathbf{~ m m}^{3}$
$\mathrm{V}_{2}=\left(\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}\right) \times \mathrm{V}_{1}=\frac{300 \times 22.4 \times 3}{273}=\mathbf{7 3 . 8} \mathbf{d m}^{3}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Why does non disjunction occur only in anaphase of cell division?
Sheet1.Answer: It is during anaphase that sister chromatids (in mitosis and/or meiosis II) or paired chromosomes (in meiosis I) separate from each other in order to prepare for cell division. When they do not separate correctly then nondisjunction occurs.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: An embryo sac has lost the synergids (One of two small, short-lived nuclei lying near the egg in the mature embryo sac of a flowering plant). What specific impact will that have on fertilization?
Sheet1.Answer: The pollen tube will form but will not be guided toward the egg.

Sheet1.Question: Determine the work done by $5.0 \mathrm{~mol}$ of an ideal gas in an isothermal process at $800 \mathrm{~K}$ in which its volume changes from $3.00 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$ to $6.00 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$23 k J$
$$
W=n R T \ln \ln \left(V_{f} / V_{i}\right)=5.0 \mathrm{~mol} \times 8.31 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \times 800 \mathrm{~K} \times \ln \ln 2=23 \mathrm{~kJ}
$$

Sheet1.Question: Why do smaller endothermic animals require more energy to maintain a constant internal temperature than larger animals do?
Sheet1.Answer: Smaller endothermic animals have a greater surface area for their mass than larger ones and therefore lose heat at a faster rate than larger animals

Sheet1.Question: Calculate the mass in grams of mercury (II) iodide that can be precipitated from $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of 0.120 moldm $^{-3}$ mercury (II) ions using excess sodium iodide solution. $$ \mathrm{Hg}=201 ; \mathrm{I} \quad=127 $$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{I}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{HgI}_{2}$
mmol of $\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}$ available $=100 * 0.120 \quad=12.0$
Molar mass of $\mathrm{HgI}_{2} \quad=201+2 * 127=455 \mathrm{~g}$
Mass of $\mathrm{HgI}_{2}$ to be precipitated $=\quad 455^{*} 12.0^{*} 10^{-3} \mathrm{~g}=5460^{*} 10^{-3} \mathrm{~g}$
$$
=5.46 \mathrm{~g}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Farmers often rotate corn (a cereal crop) and cowpeas, planting a field with each crop in alternate seasons. What advantage might this crop rotation confer?
Sheet1.Answer: Cowpeas are able to fix nitrogen in their roots, which are not harvested at the end of the growing season. The belowground nitrogen can be used in the next season by the corn.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: What might be the effect on an animal of not being able to perceive taste?
Sheet1.Answer: The animal might not be able to recognize the differences in food sources and thus might not be able to discriminate between spoiled food and safe food or between foods that contain necessary nutrients, such as proteins, and foods that do not.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: When aluminium - 27 with atomic number 13 is bombarded with alpha particles a phosphorus nuclide with atomic number 15 is produced, accompanied by a nuclear emission. Give a balanced equation for the nuclear reaction and explain how you arrived at the atomic mass of the phosphorus and the type of emission that took place.
Sheet1.Answer:
$^{27}_{13}\mathrm{Al}+^{4}_{2} \alpha \rightarrow ^{31}_{15} \mathrm{P}+\quad ^{0}_{0} \gamma$
OR $^{27}_{13}\mathrm{Al}+^{4}_{2}\alpha \rightarrow ^{30}_{15} \mathrm{P}+\quad ^{1}_{0} n$
Explanation: If the phosphorus nuclide formed has atomic mass of 31 then gamma emission would have taken place; $\quad$ OR atomic mass of 30 in which case neutron emission could have taken place.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question: Phosphorus - 30, atomic number 15 is radioactive and its decays to give a nuclide of mass number 30 , and atomic number 14 . Identify the nuclide and the type of emission.
Sheet1.Answer:
$\quad^{30}_{15} \mathrm{P} \rightarrow \quad ^{30}_{14} \mathrm{X}+\quad ^{0}_{1} \mathrm{e}$
$\mathrm{X}$ must be a silicon (nuclide) and the emission is positron emission.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics
