Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry, Physics

Sheet1.Question: How is a satellite in geostationary orbit different from one in geosynchronous orbit?
Sheet1.Answer: A geostationary satellite remains at the same point in the sky whereas a geosynchronous satellite returns to the same point in the sky at the same time.

Sheet1.Question: Name the type of cell divisions that somatic cells and gametic cells undergo

Sheet1.Question: Give two primary standards for acids and one primary standard for bases.
Sheet1.Answer:
Primary standard for acids (must be a base):
i. Anhydrous sodium trioxocarbonate IV, $\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{CO}_{3}$.
ii. Borax, $\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{~B}_{4} \mathrm{O}_{7} \cdot 10 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$.
iii. Sodium ethanedioate $\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}$.
Primary standard for bases (must be an acid):
i. Potassium hydrogen phthalate, $\mathrm{KHC}_{8} \mathrm{H}_{4} \mathrm{O}_{4}$,
ii. Ethanedioc acid, $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}$
iii. Benzoic acid, $\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{5} \mathrm{CO}_{2} \mathrm{H}$.

Sheet1.Question: The Lassaingne's sodium fusion test is used for the detection of nitrogen, sulphur and halogens in organic compounds. State what happens to any nitrogen and sulphur in an organic compound after fusion with sodium?
Sheet1.Answer: The nitrogen is converted into $\mathrm{CN}^{-}$ion. The sulphur is converted into $\mathrm{S}^{2-}$ ion.

Sheet1.Question: What is the main difference between the set-ups for simple distillation and for fractional distillation?
Sheet1.Answer: A fractional distillation set-up has a fractionating column between the flask and the distillation head.

Sheet1.Question: A cell detects that there is too much of a substance in its cytoplasm, so it makes a chemical messenger to inhibit the enzyme that is producing the substance. Explain why this is not a feedback inhibition
Sheet1.Answer: In feedback inhibition, a biochemical pathway is inhibited by its own end product. In this process the enzymes are not being inhibited by their own end product, but by a separate signaling mechanism.

Sheet1.Question: A cell biologist examined a number of slides of onion root tip in various stages of mitosis. Of 1000 cells counted, 692 cells were in prophase, 105 in metaphase, 45 in anaphase, and 168 in telophase. What conclusion can be drawn from these observations?
Sheet1.Answer: These observations give idea of the relative duration of each stage of mitosis -Prophase is longest, then telophase, followed by metaphase, and anaphase is the shortest.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: While travelling at a higher altitude, a person complains of dizziness and vomiting sensation. Which part of the inner ear is disturbed during the journey?
Sheet1.Answer: The labyrinth, which is an important part of our vestibular (balance) system is disturbed during journey to higher altitude.

Sheet1.Question: Methylamine has a pKb of 3.32 compared to $\mathrm{pKb}$ of 4.76 for ammonia. What accounts for the relative $\mathrm{pKb}$ values?
Sheet1.Answer:
Methylamine with pKb 3.32 is a stronger base than ammonia, pKb 4.76.
Basicity is due to the availability of the non-bonding electron pair on the nitrogen. The methyl group in methylamine is an electron donating group, thus increasing the electron density on the nitrogen in the methylamine.

Sheet1.Question:
Calculate the pressure in $\mathrm{kPa}$ of $64.0 \mathrm{~g}$ of oxygen gas in a $30 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ gas cylinder at $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
$$
\mathrm{O}=16.0 ; \quad \text { Gas constant } \mathrm{R}=8.31 \mathrm{Jmol}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Answer:
Consider the Ideal Gas equation: $\mathrm{V}=\frac{n R T}{P}$
$\mathrm{R}, \mathrm{T}$ and $\mathrm{P}$ are the same for all the gases. The volume $\mathrm{V}$ will be directly proportional to $\mathrm{n}$. Since the given mass of the gases is the same (i.e. $50.0 \mathrm{~g}$ ), the gas with the lowest molar mass will have the highest $\mathrm{n}$.
$\mathrm{NO}=30.0 ; \mathrm{HCl}=36.5 ; \mathrm{O}_{2}=32.0 ; \mathrm{CO}=28.0$
Hence CO will occupy the greatest volume.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: The volume of a given amount of an ideal gas is varied against its temperature at a constant pressure. How can the absolute zero be obtained from the data collected?
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{V}\left(\mathrm{y}\right.$ - axis) is plotted against $\mathrm{T}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}(\mathrm{x}$ - axis $)$. The line obtained is extrapolated to $\mathrm{V}$
$$
=\quad \text { 0, i.e. where the line meets the } \mathrm{x}-\text { axis }\left(-273{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: When the molecule $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{5}$ is heated it decomposes. Every 2 moles of $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{5}$ give four moles of $\mathrm{NO}_{2}$ and one mole of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$. How many moles of $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{5}$ would decompose to give 13 moles of $\mathrm{NO}_{2}$
Sheet1.Answer:
4 moles of $\mathrm{NO}_{2}$ come from 2 moles of $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{5}$
Therefore, 13 moles of $\mathrm{NO}_{2}$ will come from $6.5$ mole of $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{5}$
Hence, $6.1 / 2$ (or $6.5$ ) mole $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{5}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: By calculation, estimate which of the nitrogen fertilizers urea and ammonium trioxonitrate $(\mathrm{V})$ supplies more nitrogen to the soil. Support your answer with the appropriate figures. Molar mass of urea $\left(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{NCONH}_{2}\right)=60 ;$ molar mass of $\mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{NO}_{3}=80 ; \quad \mathrm{N}=14.0$
Sheet1.Answer: $\% \mathrm{~N}$ in urea $=28 / 60$ or $46.7 \%$ $\% \mathrm{n}$ in $\mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{NO}_{3}=28 / 80$ or $35.0 \%$ $28 / 60$ (or $46.7 \%$ ) is larger than $28 / 80$ (or $35.0 \%$ ), hence urea supplies more nitrogen per unit ( $\mathrm{g}$ or $\mathrm{kg}$ ) mass
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
Calculate the mass of $\mathrm{KOH}$ that must be dissolved in $200 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ to give a $0.25$ moldm ${ }^{-3}$ solution.
$\mathrm{K}=39.0 ; \mathrm{O}=16.0 ; \mathrm{H}=1.0$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{KOH}=56$
Mass of $\mathrm{KOH}$ required for $1 \mathrm{dm}^{3}=(0.25 * 56) \mathrm{g}$
Mass of $\mathrm{KOH}$ required for $200 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}=\quad(56 * 0.25 * 200) / 1000$ 
$$
=56 * 0.05=2.8 \mathrm{~g}
$$

Sheet1.Question: A system absorbs $34 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of heat and does $6 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of work in a certain process. What is the change in internal energy of the system in the process?

$$

Sheet1.Question: Two geometric isomers A and B which are organic acids have enthalpies of formation of $-5524 \mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$ and $-5545 \mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$ respectively. Which of the isomers is cis and which is trans? Give your reasons
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{A}=\mathrm{cis} ; \quad \mathrm{B}=\operatorname{trans}$
(i) Normally trans isomer is more stable than cis isomer
(ii) Enthalpy of formation of $-5545 \mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$ is an indication of greater stability than $-5524 \mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$
OR Conversion of A to B involving $\Delta \mathrm{H}$ of $-21 \mathrm{~kJ}$ is thermodynamically more favourable than conversion of B to A involving $\Delta \mathrm{H}$ of $+21 \mathrm{~kJ}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
Give the following gases in increasing rate of diffusion
$\begin{array}{llll}\text { (a) } \mathrm{Cl}_{2} ; & \text { (b) } \quad \mathrm{CF}_{2} \mathrm{Cl}_{2} ; & \text { (c) } \mathrm{SO}_{2} \text {. }\end{array}$
$\mathrm{Cl}=35.5 ; \mathrm{S}=32.0 ; \mathrm{F}=19.0 ; \mathrm{O}=16.0 ;$
$\mathrm{C}=12.0$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\quad$ Rate of diffusion: $\mathrm{CF}_{2} \mathrm{Cl}_{2}(121)<\mathrm{Cl}_{2}(71)<\mathrm{SO}_{2}(64)$.
Lightest molecule diffuses fastest, heaviest molecule slowest.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Why do network covalent solids have higher melting point than molecular solids?
Sheet1.Answer: Molecular solids consist of discrete molecules held together by weak intermolecular forces. Melting only breaks down these weak forces. Network covalent solids are giant molecules whose atoms are held by strong covalent bonds. Melting involves either breaking the strong covalent bonds or providing enough average kinetic energy to the very heavy molecules.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: State Lami's theorem.

Sheet1.Question: What is the difference in energy between a $200 \mathrm{~nm}$ photon and a $400 \mathrm{~nm}$ photon?
Sheet1.Answer:
$5 \times 10^{-19} J$
$$
\Delta E=h c\left(1 / \lambda_{1}-1 / \lambda_{2}\right)=6.63 \times 10^{-34} J s \times 3.00 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \times\left(\frac{1}{200 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{~m}}-\frac{1}{400 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{~m}}\right)=5 \times 10^{-19} J
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

$0.0125 \Omega m^{-1}=1.25 \times 10^{-2} \Omega m^{-1}$
$$
R=(V / I) / \mathrm{L}=\left(100 \times 10^{-3} V /(40.0 A)\right) /(0.200 \mathrm{~m})=12.5 \mathrm{~m} \Omega \mathrm{m}^{-1}
$$

Sheet1.Question:
Hydrogen gas can be made to react with nitrogen gas to produce ammonia. Give a balanced equation and calculate the mass of hydrogen in grams required to produce $1.7$
$\mathrm{kg}$ of ammonia. $\quad \mathrm{N}=14.0 ; \mathrm{H}=1.0$
Sheet1.Answer:
$3 \mathrm{H}_{2}+\mathrm{N}_{2} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}$
$3 \mathrm{~mol} \quad 2 \mathrm{~mol}$
$3^{*} 2 \mathrm{~kg} \quad 2 * 17 \mathrm{~kg}$
Hence, $2 * 17 \mathrm{~kg}$ of $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ can be made from $6 \mathrm{~kg}$ of $\mathrm{H}_{2}$
$1.7 \mathrm{~kg}$ of $\mathrm{NH}_{3} \equiv \quad[1.7 /(2 * 17)]^{*} 6 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{H}_{2}=\quad 300 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{of}_{2}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Answer:
mmole of base that reacted with the ester $=\quad(50-10)=40$

Sheet1.Question: The Breath analyzer, an instrument used by the Police to determine the alcohol level in the blood of drunken drivers contains $\mathrm{K}_{2} \mathrm{Cr}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{7}$ dissolved in tetraoxosulphate (VI) acid. Explain the chemistry of this test.
Sheet1.Answer:
(i) If there is any alcohol/ethanol present in the blood of the driver, it will appear in the person's breath
(ii) When the breath is blown into the tube/instrument the alcohol gets oxidised to ethanoic acid and the $\mathrm{Cr}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{7}^{2-}$ gets reduced to $\mathrm{Cr}^{3+}$.
(iii) The solution which is originally yellow-orange turns green due to the reduction of chromium in oxidation state $6+$ to $\mathrm{Cr}^{3+}$ ions
(iv) The intensity of the green colour measures the amount of the alcohol originally present in the breath.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Phosphorus $(\mathrm{V})$ chloride decomposes in a reversible reaction to give phosphorus (III) chloride and chlorine gas. At $100{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $100 \mathrm{kPa}$ pressure only $10 \%$ of the phosphorus $(\mathrm{V})$ chloride has decomposed. If the process starts with 1 mole of phosphorus (V) chloride, what is its mole fraction at equilibrium? Give your answer to two places of decimal
Sheet1.Answer:
$\quad \mathrm{PCl}_{5} \rightarrow \mathrm{PCl}_{3}+\mathrm{Cl}_{2}$
Initial: $\quad 1.0 \quad 0 \quad 0$
At equil $\quad 1.0-0.1 \quad 0.1 \quad 0.1$
Total number of moles $\quad=\quad 0.9+0.2=1.1$
Mole fraction of $\mathrm{PCl}_{5}=\quad 0.9 / 1.1=\quad 0.82$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: A radioactive substance has a half-life of $4.5$ years. How long will it take the substance to lose $75 \%$ of its activity
Sheet1.Answer:
Radioactive decay follows first order kinetics
$$
100 \% \rightarrow \quad 50 \% \rightarrow 25 \%
$$
After $2 \mathrm{t}_{1 / 2}$, only $25 \%$ of activity is left, and $75 \%$ lost.
Hence, time taken to lose $75 \%=4.5 * 2=9$ years

Sheet1.Question:
An experiment is performed where reactant $\mathrm{A}$ is converted into product $\mathrm{B}$. To study the kinetics of the reaction, the concentration of $\mathrm{A}$ is recorded over a period of time as follows.
|$\mathrm{t}(\mathrm{s})$  | Concentration of A |
|--------------------------|--------------------|
|      0                   |     $0.0050$       |
|      10                  |     $0.0045$       |
|      20                  |     $0.0042$       |
Calculate the rates for the $1^{\text {st }}$ and $2^{\text {nd }}$ ten seconds and the average rate over the 20 seconds.
Sheet1.Answer:
For $1^{\text {st }} 10$ seconds: Rate $=$ change in concentration/time Rate $=(0.0005 / 10)=5 * 10^{-5}$ moldm$^{-3} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$
$2^{\text {nd }} 10$ seconds
Rate $=(0.0003 / 10)=3.0 * 10^{-5} \mathrm{moldm}^{-3} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$
Average $\quad=\quad 4.0 * 10^{-5} \mathrm{moldm}^{-3} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
Consider the following electrode potentials $\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}, \mathrm{Fe}^{2+} / \mathrm{Pt}+0.77 \mathrm{~V} ; \quad \mathrm{Cl}_{2}, \mathrm{Cl}^{-} / \mathrm{Pt}^{-1.36}$ $\mathrm{V} ; \mathrm{I}_{2}, \mathrm{I}^{-} / \mathrm{Pt} 0.53 \mathrm{~V}$. Use the electrode potentials to determine which of the two reactions is spontaneous. Explain your answer
(a) $2 \mathrm{Fe}^{3+}{ }_{(\mathrm{aq})}$
(b) $2 \mathrm{Fe}^{3+}(\mathrm{aq})$
$+\quad 2 \mathrm{Cl}_{(\mathrm{aq})}^{-}$
$\rightarrow \quad 2 \mathrm{Fe}^{2+}(\mathrm{aq})$
$+\mathrm{Cl}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}$
$+\quad 2 \mathrm{I}_{(\mathrm{aq})}^{-}$
$\rightarrow \quad 2 \mathrm{Fe}^{2+}(\mathrm{aq})$
$+\quad \mathrm{I}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\quad$ For reaction (a);
Oxidation: $\quad 2 \mathrm{Cl}_{(\mathrm{aq})}^{-} \quad-\quad 2 \mathrm{e} \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{Cl}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}-1.36$
Reduction: $\quad 2 \mathrm{Fe}_{(\mathrm{aq})}^{3+} \quad+\quad 2 \mathrm{e} \quad \rightarrow \quad 2 \mathrm{Fe}^{2+}{ }_{(\mathrm{aq})} \quad+0.77$
$\operatorname{Emf} \quad=-1.36+0.77=-0.59 \mathrm{~V}$
For Reaction (b);
Oxidation: $\quad 2 \mathrm{I}_{(\mathrm{aq})}^{-} \quad-\quad 2 \mathrm{e} \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{I}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}-0.53 \mathrm{~V}$
Reduction: $2 \mathrm{Fe}^{3+}{ }_{(\mathrm{aq})}+2 \mathrm{e} \quad \rightarrow \quad 2 \mathrm{Fe}^{2+}{ }_{(\mathrm{aq})}+0.77$
$\mathrm{Emf} \quad=-053+0.77=+0.24 \mathrm{~V}$
Since the emf of the cell (b) is positive, reaction (b) is spontaneous
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What may account for the fact that solid sodium chloride is very soluble in water but silver chloride is not soluble
Sheet1.Answer: Dissolution of an ionic compound in water involves two factors. i) Lattice energy which is positive, ii) Enthalpy of hydration which is negative. In the case of $\mathrm{NaCl}$ enthalpy of hydration is larger than the lattice energy. So overall enthalpy change for $\mathrm{NaCl}$ is negative. The opposite is the case of silver chloride.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Answer:

For $2 \mathrm{CO}_{2}=4 * \mathrm{C}=\mathrm{O}$
For $3 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}=6 * \mathrm{O}-\mathrm{H}$

Sheet1.Question: A $6.0 \times 10^{14} \mathrm{~Hz}$ photon ejects an electron of kinetic energy $3.2 \times 10^{-20} \mathrm{~J}$ from the surface of a photocathode. What is the kinetic energy of an electron that can be ejected by a $3.0 \times 10^{14} \mathrm{~Hz}$ photon from the photocathode?
Sheet1.Answer:
Such a photon cannot eject an electron from the given photocathode
$K=E_{\gamma}-W=E_{\gamma}-\left(E_{\gamma}^{\prime}-K^{\prime}\right)=h\left(f-f^{\prime}\right)+K^{\prime}=6.62 \times 10^{-34} \mathrm{JS} \times\left(3.0 \times 10^{14} \mathrm{~Hz}-6.0 \times 10^{14} \mathrm{~Hz}\right)+3.2 \times 10^{-20} \mathrm{~J}=-1.7\times10^{-19}\mathrm{~J}$

Sheet1.Question: $200 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $0.090 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3} \mathrm{HCl}$ solution are added to $300 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $0.120 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$ ammonia solution. Name the species that will be present in the mixed solution, give their respective concentrations in moldm ${ }^{-3}$ and finally state the type of solution it is
Sheet1.Answer:
mmole of $\mathrm{HCl}=200 * 0.09=18$
mmole of $\mathrm{NH}_{3}=300 * 0.12=36$
When the two are mixed, 18 mmoles of $\mathrm{HCl}$ will react with 18 mmole of $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ to give $18 \mathrm{mmoles}^{2}$ of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$and $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$(or $\left.\mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{Cl}\right)$
Species present are $\mathrm{NH}_{3}, \mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$and $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{Cl}\right)$ Concentrations of $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ or $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$or $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}=\quad 18 / 500$
$$
=0.036 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}
$$
Type of solution: buffer weak base $+$ its conjugate acid

Sheet1.Question:
Consider the following half-cells with their corresponding electrode potentials;
$\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}, \mathrm{MnO}_{2}, \mathrm{OH}^{-} / \mathrm{Pt} \quad 0.59 \mathrm{~V} ; \quad \mathrm{Fe}^{3+}, \mathrm{Fe}^{2+} / \mathrm{Pt} \quad 0.77 \mathrm{~V}$
Determine if the following redox reaction is possible
$\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+3 \mathrm{Fe}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \rightarrow \mathrm{MnO}_{2}+3 \mathrm{Fe}^{3+}+4 \mathrm{OH}^{-}$
Give your reason
Sheet1.Answer:
For the reaction to be possible
We should have;
Oxidation: $\mathrm{Fe}^{2+} \quad-\quad \mathrm{e} \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{Fe}^{3+}-0.77 \mathrm{~V}$
Reduction: $\quad \mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}+3 \mathrm{e} \rightarrow \mathrm{MnO}_{2}+4 \mathrm{OH}^{-}+0.59 \mathrm{~V}$
Emf of the overall reaction is $0.59-0.77=-0.18$, which is negative.
Hence the reaction is not possible
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Answer:

Sheet1.Question: Calcium tetraoxosulphate (VI) has a solubility product of $2.5 * 10^{-5}$ at about $30{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Calculate the solubility of this salt in water and in $0.10 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3} \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$ solution. Account for the difference if any
Sheet1.Answer:
In water $\mathrm{Ksp}$ of $\mathrm{CaSO}_{4}=2.5 * 10^{-5} ; \quad\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right]=\quad \sqrt{ }\left(2.5 * 10^{-5}\right)$
$$
=\quad 5.0 * 10^{-3} \text { moldm }^{-3}
$$
In $0.1 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3} \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$;
$\mathrm{Ksp}=\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right][0.1]=2.5 * 10^{-5}$
$\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right]=2.5 * 10^{-4} \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$
Solubility in $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$ is lower, due to common ion effect.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: A flask contains $400 \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$ of $0.125 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3} \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$. What volume of $0.09 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3} \mathrm{NaOH}$ solution must be added to this solution to convert all the $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$ to $\mathrm{NaHSO}_{4}$ ? Moles of $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}=(400 / 1000) * 0.125=0.050$
Moles of $\mathrm{NaOH}$ needed $=0.050$
Let the volume of $0.09$ moldm $^{-3} \mathrm{NaOH}$ needed be $\mathrm{V} \mathrm{\textrm {cm } ^ { 3 }}$
$(0.090 * \mathrm{~V}) / 1000 \quad=\quad 0.05$
$\mathrm{V} \quad=\quad(1000 * 0.05) / 0.09=555.6 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$

Sheet1.Question:
Decane is a hydrocarbon. What is the molar mass of decanal?
$\mathrm{O}=16.0 ; \mathrm{C}=12.0 ; \mathrm{H}=1.0$
Sheet1.Answer:
Decane $\quad=\mathrm{C}_{10} \mathrm{H}_{22}$
Decanal $=\mathrm{C}_{9} \mathrm{H}_{19}-\mathrm{CHO}=108+19+29=156$
OR $\quad$ Decane $\quad=\mathrm{C}_{10} \mathrm{H}_{22}=142$
For decanal, decane loses $2 \mathrm{H}$ and gains one $\mathrm{O}$, hence $\quad=\quad 142-2+16=156$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
Magnesium metal burns in excess oxygen to give $\mathrm{MgO}$. Calculate the mass of $\mathrm{MgO}$ expected from $78.0 \mathrm{~g}$ of magnesium metal, assuming the yield is only $90 \%$
$\mathrm{Mg}=24.0 ; \mathrm{O}=16.0$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{Mg}+1 / 2 \mathrm{O}_{2} \rightarrow \mathrm{MgO}$
$24 \quad 16$
$24 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{Mg} \equiv 40 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{MgO}$
Hence, $78 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{Mg}=(78 / 24) * 40 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{MgO}=(13 / 4)^{*} 40 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{MgO}=130 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{MgO}$
For $90 \%$ yield, mass of $\mathrm{MgO}=0.9 * 130=117 \mathrm{~g}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text:
$\mathrm{NO}_{2}$ dimerises in a reversible process to give $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}$ according to the following equation:
$$
2 \mathrm{NO}_{2} \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}
$$
Sheet1.Question: In one such reaction a one litre flask was charged with 1 mole of $\mathrm{NO}_{2}$ and heated to $100{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. At equilibrium, it was found that $0.25 \mathrm{~mol}$ of $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}$ was formed. Find the equilibrium constant.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text:
$\mathrm{NO}_{2}$ dimerises in a reversible process to give $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}$ according to the following equation:
$$
2 \mathrm{NO}_{2} \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}
$$
Sheet1.Question: In another reaction the initial amount of $\mathrm{NO}_{2}$ was 2 mol. At equilibrium at $125{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, the amount of $\mathrm{NO}_{2}$ left was found to be $0.4$ mol. Calculate the equilibrium constant at $125{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
Sheet1.Answer:
$\quad 2 \mathrm{NO}_{2} \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}$
Initial: $\quad 2 \mathrm{~mol}$
Equil: $\quad 2-1.6$
If $0.4 \mathrm{~mol}$ of $\mathrm{NO}_{2}$ was left at equilibrium then $1.6 \mathrm{~mol}$ of it had reacted to give $0.8 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}$.
$\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{C}}=\left(0.8 /(0.4)^{2}\right)=0.8 / 0.16 \quad=\quad 5$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Preamble Text:
$\mathrm{NO}_{2}$ dimerises in a reversible process to give $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}$ according to the following equation:
$$
2 \mathrm{NO}_{2} \rightarrow \quad \mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}
$$
Sheet1.Question: State the LeChtelier's Principle and use it to determine the effect of increased pressure on the equilibrium between $\mathrm{NO}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}$
Sheet1.Answer:
When a system in equilibrium is altered by a change, of same condition, a change occurs to shift the equilibrium composition (or equilibrium point) in a way that tends to reduce that change of condition
In the equilibrium reaction the number of gaseous molecules decreases from left to right.
Increase in pressure will favour the forward reaction OR will shift the equilibrium position to the right.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Given $x^{2}+x y-y^{2}=10$, find $d y / d x$
Sheet1.Answer:
$d y / d x=(2 x+y) /(2 y-x)$
$[2 x+y+x d y / d x-2 y d y / d x=0,(2 y-x) d y / d x=2 x+y, d y / d x=(2 x+y) /(2 y-x)]$

Sheet1.Question: The current in a $2 \mathrm{H}$ inductor decreases from $5 \mathrm{~A}$ to $2.5 \mathrm{~A}$ in $2 \mathrm{~ms}$. Find the magnitude of the average emf induced in the inductor.

$2.5 k V$
$$

Sheet1.Preamble Text:
Nitrogen(II) oxide reacts with chlorine gas to give nitrogen oxochlorate (I) (or nitrosyl chloride) according to the equation:
$$
2 \mathrm{NO}_{(\mathrm{g})}+\mathrm{Cl}_{2(\mathrm{~g})} \rightarrow \quad 2 \mathrm{NOCl}
$$
In order to determine the rate law for the reaction, the following rate measurements were carried out
|No. | {$[\mathrm{NO}] / \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$} | {$\left[\mathrm{Cl}_{2}\right] / \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$} | Initial Rate $\left(\mathrm{moldm}^{-3} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\right)$ |
|----|-----------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------|
|1   | $0.10$                                  |  $0.10$                                                | $0.121$                                                          |
|2   | $0.30$                                  |  $0.10$                                                | $1.088$                                                          |
|3   | $0.30$                                  |  $0.20$                                                | $2.175$                                                          |
Sheet1.Question: Determine the order of the reaction with respect to nitrogen(II) oxide, NO
Sheet1.Answer:
Consider Experiments (1) and (2). By trebling the concentration of NO, while concentration of $\mathrm{Cl}_{2}$ remains constant, rate increases by a factor of $9(1.088 / 0.121)$
Hence the order is $2^{\text {nd }}$ order with respect to NO.
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Deoxyribofuranose is the sugar on which the nucleic acid DNA is built. Ribofuranose is the sugar on which the nucleic acid RNA is built. What is the difference between Deoxyribofuranose and Ribofuranose

Sheet1.Question: Equal volumes of nitrogen gas and an unknown gas at the same temperature and pressure weigh $2.80 \mathrm{~g}$ and $8.00 \mathrm{~g}$ respectively. Which of the following is the unknown gas; $\mathrm{NO}_{2}, \mathrm{SO}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{SO}_{3}$ ? $\mathrm{S}=32.0 ; \mathrm{O}=16.0 ; \mathrm{N}=14.0 ; \mathrm{C}=12$
Sheet1.Answer:
Equal volumes of gases at the same temperature and pressure contain the same amount in moles.
$$
\text { Moles of } \mathrm{N}_{2}=2.80 / 28=0.10
$$
The amount of unknown gas should be $0.10$;
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{NO}_{2}=8 / 46=0.17 \quad>\quad 0.10 \\
& \mathrm{SO}_{2}=8 / 64=0.13>0.10 \\
& \mathrm{SO}_{3}=8 / 80=0.10
\end{aligned}
$$
Unknown gas is $\mathrm{SO}_{3}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry
Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: The potential difference across a $40 \mathrm{mF}$ capacitor is increasing at the rate of $20 \mathrm{~V} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$. At what rate are electrons being removed from the positive plate of the capacitor?
Sheet1.Answer:
$5 \times 10^{18} s^{-1}$
$$
d N / d t=d Q / d t=(C / e) d V / d t=40 \times 10^{-3} F \times 20 V^{-1} /\left(1.6 \times 10^{-19} C\right)=5 \times 10^{18} s^{-1}
$$

Sheet1.Question: What is the difference between ecological succession and zonation?
Sheet1.Answer: Succession refers to the change in a community of organisms in a habitat over time, whereas zonation refers to the appearance of distinct zones or regions in a habitat at one time, where different communities of organisms live - due to the different conditions in those zones.

Sheet1.Question: Consider the following two half cells $\mathrm{Cs}^{+} / \mathrm{Cs}$ and $\mathrm{Ag}^{+} / \mathrm{Ag}$. Their respective electrode potentials are $-2.9 \mathrm{~V}$ and $0.80 \mathrm{~V}$. Can Caesium metal reduce silver (I) to silver metal? Explain your answer
Sheet1.Answer:
Consider the cell with the half-cells
$\begin{array}{lllllllll}\text { Anode/oxidation: } & \mathrm{Cs} & - & \mathrm{e} & \rightarrow & \mathrm{Cs}^{+} & +2.9 \mathrm{~V} \\ \text { Cathode/reduction: } & \mathrm{Ag}^{+} & + & \mathrm{e} & \rightarrow & \mathrm{Ag} & 0.80 \mathrm{~V} \\ \text { Cell reaction: } \mathrm{Cs} & + & \mathrm{Ag}^{+} & \rightarrow & \mathrm{Cs}^{+} & + & \mathrm{Ag} & 3.70 \mathrm{~V} \\ \text { A cell in which Cs reduces } \mathrm{Ag}^{+} \text {to } \mathrm{Ag} \text { will have a positive } \mathrm{emf} \\ \text { Hence Cs can reduce } \mathrm{Ag}^{+} \text {to } \mathrm{Ag} & & & & \end{array}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: $38 \mathrm{~g}$ of a certain gas that occupied $16.62 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ volume exerted a pressure of $95 \mathrm{kPa}$ at $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Calculate the molar mass of the gas. Assume $\mathrm{R}=8.31 \mathrm{JK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$
Sheet1.Answer:
Use the Ideal gas equation; $\mathrm{PV}=\mathrm{nRT} ; \mathrm{n}=\mathrm{PV} / \mathrm{RT}$
$\mathrm{n}=(95 * 16.62) /(300 * 8.31)=19 / 30 \mathrm{~mol}$
But $\mathrm{n}=\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{M}$, where $\mathrm{M}$ is molar mass
$19 / 30=38 / \mathrm{M} ; \quad \mathrm{M}=(30 * 38) / 19=60.0 \mathrm{~g}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
Consider the following electrodes with their corresponding potentials
$\mathrm{O}_{3}, \mathrm{O}_{2}, \mathrm{H}^{+}, \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} / \mathrm{Pt} \quad 2.07 \mathrm{~V} ; \quad \mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}, \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}, \mathrm{H}^{+}, \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} / \mathrm{Pt} \quad 1.21 \mathrm{~V}$
$\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{Na} \quad-2.71 \mathrm{~V} ; \quad \mathrm{Sn}^{2+} / \mathrm{Sn} \quad-0.14 \mathrm{~V} ; \quad \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}, \mathrm{OH}^{-} / \mathrm{Pt} \quad 0.851 \mathrm{~V}$
Give the following oxidizing agents in an increasing order of oxidising strength
$\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{Sn}^{2+}, \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}, \mathrm{O}_{3}$ and $\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}$
Sheet1.Answer:
The species that accepts electrons with higher potential is a stronger oxidizing agent.
$$
\text { Hence; } \quad \mathrm{Na}^{+}<\mathrm{Sn}^{2+}<\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}<\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}<\mathrm{O}_{3}
$$

Sheet1.Question:
If it takes $50 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of oxygen gas 20 seconds to diffuse through a pin hole into a vacuum, how long will it take hydrogen and $\mathrm{SO}_{2}$ gases to diffuse under the same conditions. In the case of $\mathrm{SO}_{2}$, you may leave your answer as a surd
$\mathrm{S}=32.0 ; \mathrm{O}=16.0 ; \mathrm{H}=1$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{SO}_{2}=32+32=64 ; \quad \mathrm{H}_{2}=2$
From Grahams law; Rate $/$ Rate $_{1}=\sqrt{ }\left(\mathrm{M}_{1} / \mathrm{M}_{2}\right)=\mathrm{t}_{1} / \mathrm{t}_{2}$
For hydrogen, $\mathrm{t}=\mathrm{t}_{0} \sqrt{ }(2 / 32)=20 / 4=5 \mathrm{secs}$
For $\mathrm{SO}_{2}, \quad \mathrm{t}=\mathrm{t}_{0} \sqrt{ }(64 / 32)=20 \sqrt{2} \operatorname{secs}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: A $10 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ flask contains $5.6 \mathrm{~g}$ of nitrogen gas, $3.2 \mathrm{~g}$ of oxygen gas and some unknown mass of argon. If the total pressure of the gases in the flask is $100 \mathrm{kPa}$ at $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, what is the partial pressure of the argon? Give your answer to one place of decimal. Ideal Gas constant, $\mathrm{R}=\quad 8.31 \mathrm{JK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ $\mathrm{Ar}=40.0 ; \quad \mathrm{O}=16.0 \quad \mathrm{~N}=14.0$
Sheet1.Answer: Moles of $\mathrm{N}_{2}=5.6 / 28=0.2 \mathrm{~mol}$ Moles of $\mathrm{O}_{2}=\quad 3.2 / 32=0.1 \mathrm{~mol}$ Partial pressure of $\mathrm{N}_{2} \& \mathrm{O}_{2}=(0.3 * 8.31 * 300) / 10=74.8 \mathrm{kPa}$ Partial pressure of the argon $=100-74.8=25.2 \mathrm{kPa}$

Sheet1.Question: Why is the intensity of natural selection on prey species higher than that of predators throughout evolution?

Sheet1.Question: A swimming pool measuring $50 \mathrm{~m}$ by $12 \mathrm{~m}$ by $6 \mathrm{~m}$ is filled to the brim with water from a stream whose water is known to be of temporary hardness. If analysis shows that the water contains $0.01 \%$ w/v Ca $\left(\mathrm{HCO}_{3}\right)_{2}$, what mass of the $\mathrm{Ca}\left(\mathrm{HCO}_{3}\right)_{2}$ can be obtained from the water in the pool?
Sheet1.Answer:
Volume of the swimming pool $=50 * 12 * 6=3600 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$
$$
=\quad 3.60 * 10^{6} \mathrm{dm}^{3}
$$
Since the water is $0.01 \% \mathrm{w} / \mathrm{v}$ with respect to $\mathrm{Ca}\left(\mathrm{HCO}_{3}\right)_{2}$,
$$
\text { Mass of } \mathrm{Ca}\left(\mathrm{HCO}_{3}\right)_{2}=(0.01 / 100) * 3.60 * 10^{6}=3.60 * 10^{2}=360 \mathrm{~g}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: A $5 \mathrm{~kg}$ object hangs vertically from one end of a spring of spring constant $500 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}$. What is the elastic potential energy stored in the spring?
Sheet1.Answer:
$2.5 \mathrm{~J}$
$$
U=\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}=\frac{1}{2} k\left(\frac{m g}{k}\right)^{2}=\frac{m^{2} g^{2}}{2 k}=\frac{(5 k g)^{2} \times\left(10 m^{-2}\right)^{2}}{2 \times 500 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}}=2.5 \mathrm{~J}
$$

Sheet1.Question:
Pure liquid nitroglycerin is very sensitive to shock. When it is shaken, it explodes according to the following equation:
$$
4 \mathrm{C}_{3} \mathrm{H}_{5}\left(\mathrm{NO}_{3}\right)_{3(\mathrm{l})} \rightarrow \quad 6 \mathrm{~N}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}+\quad 10 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{(\mathrm{g})} \quad+\quad 12 \mathrm{CO}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}+\mathrm{O}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}
$$
If the enthalpy of reaction is $-5.720 * 10^{3} \mathrm{~kJ}$, calculate the enthalpy of formation of nitroglycerin from the following enthalpies of formation
$\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{(\mathrm{g})}-242 \mathrm{kJmol}^{-1} ; \mathrm{CO}_{2(\mathrm{~g})}-394 \mathrm{kJmol}^{-1}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: Give the shape of the $\mathrm{OH}^{-}$ion and the hybridisation of the orbitals of oxygen
Sheet1.Answer: Shape of $\mathrm{OH}^{-}$is linear; $\quad$ hybridisation of the orbitals of $\mathrm{O}$ is $\mathrm{sp}^{3}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question:
Calculate the percentage increase in the volume of a balloon when the gas inside is heated from 27
${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $77^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ in a hot water bath. Give your answer to one place of decimal or 3 significant figures
Sheet1.Answer:
Use Charles' Law; Pressure is constant
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{T}_{1}=300 \mathrm{~K} ; \mathrm{T}_{2}=350 \mathrm{~K} ; \mathrm{V}_{1}=\quad \mathrm{V}_{1} ; \quad \mathrm{V}_{2}=\mathrm{V}_{2} \\
& \mathrm{V}_{2} / \mathrm{T}_{2}=\mathrm{V}_{1} / \mathrm{T}_{1} ; \quad \mathrm{V}_{2}=\mathrm{V}_{1}\left(\mathrm{~T}_{2} / \mathrm{T}_{1}\right)=\mathrm{V}_{1} * 350 / 300 \\
& \mathrm{V}_{2}=1.167 \mathrm{~V}_{1} \\
& \text { Change } \quad=\quad 0.167 \text { of } \mathrm{V}_{1} \\
& \% \text { Change }=0.167 / 1 * 100=16.7 \%
\end{aligned}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: The daytime sky on Earth looks blue on a sunny cloudless day. The moon is permanently cloudless. How does the daytime Lunar sky look and why?
Sheet1.Answer: Black; The moon has no atmosphere to scatter light to produce the sought of bright sky we have on earth.
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: When the light from a sodium lamp such as used in street lighting is observed through a transmission grating, a bright yellow line of wavelength of about $589 \mathrm{~nm}$ is seen. When the sodium lamp light is again observed through the grating but after passing the light through sodium vapour, a dark line is observed where the bright line is expected. What phenomenon accounts for this?
Sheet1.Answer: Sodium atoms in the vapour absorb photons of the same wavelength sodium atoms in the lamp emit and make transitions between the same set of energy levels
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: Why does the terrestrial sky look blue?
Sheet1.Answer: Rayleigh scattering varies as $1 / \lambda^{4}$ and so is more intense at blue wavelengths than at red wavelengths
Sheet1.Subject: Physics

Sheet1.Question: A Senior High secondary school boy hammered a nail in the bark of a mango tree at a height of one metre above the ground. After three years, he observed that the nail was at the same height although the mango tree had grown 3 meters taller. Explain the above observation.
Sheet1.Answer:
The nail was hammered at a point where vertical growth had stopped/further growth was confined to increase in width/diameter.
Vertical growth is confined to tips/apex/vertical apical meristem
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Organisms are known be closely related to their environment. How might global climate change result in the extinction of mammals?
Sheet1.Answer: The internal temperatures of mammals must always stay within the normal range. If the external temperature rises too high, it will be difficult for homeostatic mechanisms to control, which will cause the internal temperature of mammals to rise above normal and will result in death.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Why does the skin of some light-skinned people look redder when they feel too hot?
Sheet1.Answer: When we are too hot, blood vessels supplying blood to the skin can dilate (vasodilation). This allows more warm blood to flow near the surface of the skin, where the heat can be lost to the air, resulting in redder skin.
Sheet1.Subject: Biology

Sheet1.Question: Calculate the percentage loss in mass when chromium (VI) oxide is reduced to the chromium metal. $\mathrm{Cr}=52.0 ; \mathrm{O}=16$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{CrO}_{3} \rightarrow \mathrm{Cr}$ $(52+48) \quad 52$
Loss in mass is 48
$\%$ Loss in mass $=\quad=\quad(48 / 100) * 100=\quad 48 \%$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Standard Temperature $=0{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C} ;$ Standard Pressure $=100 \mathrm{kPa}$.

Sheet1.Question: When iron fillings are heated with excess sulphur, iron (II) sulphide is produced. If in one such preparation $6.6 \mathrm{~g}$ of the sulphide is obtained, what mass of iron fillings may have been used? $\mathrm{Fe}=56.0 ; \mathrm{S}=32$
Sheet1.Answer:
$\mathrm{Fe}+\mathrm{S} \rightarrow \mathrm{FeS}$
$88 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{FeS}$ is obtained from $56 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{Fe}$
Therefore, $6.6 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{FeS}$
$$
=(6.6 / 88) * 56=4.2 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{Fe}
$$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry

Sheet1.Question: What is the major difference, chemically between haemoglobin and chlorophyll?

Sheet1.Question: Find the energy stored in a $5 \mu \mathrm{H}$ inductor which carries a current of $2 \mathrm{~A}$.

$$

$$

Sheet1.Question: The solubility of a compound $\mathrm{X}$ with formula mass 70 is $0.14 \mathrm{moldm}^{-3}$ at $30{ }^{0} \mathrm{C}$. If 500 $\mathrm{cm}^{3}$ of a hot solution containing $22 \mathrm{~g}$ of the compound is allowed to cool to $30{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, how much solid will be deposited.
Sheet1.Answer:
Solubility of $\mathrm{X}$ at $30{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ in $\mathrm{gdm}^{-3}=70 * 0.14=9.8 \mathrm{~g}$
Solubility of $\mathrm{X}$ at $30{ }^{0} \mathrm{C}$ for $500 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}=4.9 \mathrm{~g}$
Mass of solid that will be deposited $=22-4.9=17.1 \mathrm{~g}$
Sheet1.Subject: Chemistry
